This game is a good example why Steam needs more review options than just only Positive/Negative. Hundred Heroes has some high aspects that are dragged down by the low ones.

[h1]Localisation[/h1]
Let's start with the biggest elephant in the room. The localisation is not good, in fact if I were to review the game purely about the localisation, it would be a Negative score without any second thought. The game is filled with huge amount of inaccuracies, the characters end up being more annoying in the English version compared to the Japanese one. They often crack cringe jokes or use sentences that are popular on the internet as memes, which makes the localisation feel very infantile. Statistically you get at least one localisation inaccuracy per cutscene in the first half of the game. Once you get to Norristar the frequency of inaccuracies decreases, but they are still present. I've personally gathered the localisation inaccuracies into a list, which you can find on the Steam's Discussion page for this title and make your own judgement about its quality.

This isn't the absolute worst when it comes to localisations. If a game Gotta Protectors, which is another title that the lead localiser for Eiyuden worked on is 1/10, then this game is 4/10. If we apply the school/university grading system to it, where you need at least 50% points to pass, then this localisation simply doesn't make it.

[h3]4/10[/h3]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The artstyle is very pretty and most likely it is the highest point of this game. The opening shot with the camera following the bird, or the Hishahn Palace during the night left quite an impression on me. Everything else was good too. This isn't the absolute peak that can be achieved with a 2D artstyle, but it gets the job done.

[h3]8/10[/h3]

[h1]Combat[/h1]
The combat very much in style of Suikoden 1 and 2, but it feels lacking. The major thing that I've felt missing from Eiyuden is the mechanic when multiple characters with roughly similar speed stat would take actions at the same time. This made the actual battles very dynamic and pleasing to look at. As a kid I was very impressed by it, and years later I appreciated this mechanic from the programming point of view. It was something that helped Suikoden stand out among other jRPGs and makes Suikoden's combat a 9 or maybe even a 10/10.

In Eiyuden there are moments where you might think that they've implemented multiple actions mechanic, but in truth it's just that certain enemies having very short attack animation (e.g. Aquasoul enemies). Because of that the combat's speed feels sluggish at times, which was pointed out by many players.

Battle Plan is a nice addition. It's nowhere near as good as Gambits from FF12 and it's not as smart as I'd want it to be, but it's better than nothing.
When doing the endgame content I've encountered an issue with Battle Plan where I couldn't find a way to set it up for Wayve to use Magic Barrage for multiple enemies, but use basic attack when there is only 1 enemy to emphasize on his crit build.
Battle Plan needs an option to program individual skills, instead of configuring the general playstyle.

The game offers you a satisfying amount of customisation options for the character, when it comes to stats and abilities that you can experiment with. For example I was able to customise Dijkstra from his default playstyle, to full support/buffer with high hp/defense at the cost of attack, which he never uses. In that aspect the customisation might be as vast as for example in Pokemon games, without dwelling to the EV/IV nightmare. But just like in Pokemon, the vast majority of the characters underperform, and you'll most likely just use 10-20% of all characters for combat.

[h3]7/10[/h3]

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
I've played on Hard difficulty, which doesn't feel that hard to begin with. Most bosses are pushovers and you can beat them easily on your first attempt. The damage they deal is lower from the damage you receive from mobs you encounter in the dungeons. Most of your recovery items will be spend on healing your team after fighting the mobs rather than during a boss fight. The only time when recovery items are needed during a boss fight is when you're fighting a boss who can apply hard crowd control on your team (Narungarde and Kraken).
There are also 2 bosses with attacks that can oneshot most of your characters (Elder Dragon and Dead Countess, but you'll most likely kill those boss before having one less team member will become an issue, so you don't even need revive potions.

The Hero's Trial Grounds, which serves as the endgame content is also way too easy. At this point you'll have your party members fully equipped with best gear and runes, so that the bosses you've encountered through the story will deal even less damage and die even faster. Hidden boss is an exception to that, but he shouldn't take you more than a few attempts to defeat.

[h3]5/10[/h3]

[h1]Music[/h1]
The music was good. Not bad, but not really great either. It would've been better if several villages didn't share the same theme, but this doesn't affect my score for the music that much.

[h3]7/10[/h3]

[h1]Plot[/h1]
Obviously this game's plot doesn't even stand close to the one from Suikoden 2.

The plot is fine, might be slightly worse than in S1 with how there are no serious consequences during the conflict. There are multiple moments where you might think that one character will be captured or killed by the enemy, only for them to show the middle finger and walk away like nothing happened.

The main villain gets more screentime than Barbarossa from S1, which is a plus. His motivation to start the conflict isn't that great though. He also is portrayed throughout the entire game to be this great schemer who is always one step before the others, but all he really does is show up on the battlefield with an army, after everyone thinks that it's over.

[h3]6/10[/h3]

[h1]Technical issues[/h1]
Throughout my entire playthrough I didn't expect many bugs or errors. There were few audio issues, like when the Fenrir boss roars but there is no sound, or how there is no audio when the main character is running, but you do hear the footsteps audio when moving through doors.

There was also a significant bug for the Shi'arcraft minigame which made the experience very unpleasant, and to my knowledge it still might not have been fixed.

There is a small delay when navigating through the UI or when a user input doesn't register for the first second after starting a battle, which is a mild inconvenience.

[h3]7/10[/h3]

[h1]Minigames[/h1]
Minigames take a significant % of your total playtime if you're planning on clearing them all. Except for the card battle which is fun, and beigoma which is okay, the others are either bugged (shi'arcaft race), emphasize on being afk (eggfoot racing, fishing), or are just unfun (cooking). The story for cooking minigame is fine though.

[h3]4/10[/h3]

[h1]Achievements/100% completion[/h1]
The game has plenty of activities to do. There's so many in fact that if you want to keep track of everything without getting lost, having a spreadsheet is a must. I'd say I prefer things like that over the grinding achievements, although there are some issues with how they were handled in this game.

The time distribution for main story/side activities if you're going for a 100% run is 40/60 from my experience. You spent quite a lot of time on the minigames and on collecting various recipies and so on. The thing I didn't enjoy about the collectibles are the star recipies, which have a random chance of spawning in a shop every 30 real-life minutes.

The minigames mentioned previously, which are also required for 100% completion are also on the weak side.

There are also few missable characters, which do count for a 100% completion.

[h3]6/10[/h3]

I wanted to address more details, but I already reached the character limit.

I give it a thumbs down even though I like it and consider it a decent JRPG because it fails to live up to Suikoden 2 in many quantifiable ways. Unlike most I'm going to list off some of the things Suikoden 2 does better and explain why it makes for a more compelling story.

Suikoden 2 starts you off with intrigue right at the start of the game, from the camp of a Border Scout unit called the Unicorn Brigade that's supposed be a safe job. Their mission ends soon and you can run around talking to troops who can't wait to return to their families. Unfortunately warmongers from within Highland launch a false flag operation in order to justify an invasion of neighboring Muse by slaughtering everyone in the Unicorn Brigade, except for the Player and Joey who escape by jumping off a cliff at a waterfall. Right before the plunge Joey makes a mark on the stone and invites the player to choose whether or not to make a promise to meet up there again once it's all over with if they're ever separated. This promise can affect the ending of the game.

Washed downstream and rescued, you're captured by a mercenary company who recognizes Highland soldiers shouldn't be in that area. After a few odd jobs they start to trust you and send you out to do some chores, with a minder of course, you're still technically a captive.

You will pass through Ryube Village, a chaming small tranquil town where you will witness events and meet and recruit characters early on. It's a serine little forest village at the base of a mountain, with a forest path behind it for fighting monsters and recruiting additional characters. This village will be passed through several times and leave an impression on the player that will be relevant to plot developments. 

The players's childhood friend and squadmate Joey will come to rescue him from captivity, they'll be paired together for much of the early portion of the game. Combined they have an unstoppable hero combo that makes short work of crowds of enemies, giving the player a gameplay reason in addition to a story reason to keep Joey in the party and feel attached to the character.

Joey and the Player return to Highland along with a travelling caravan containing two charming sisters and their... brother. Upon making it to the Highland the player and Joey reunite with family and you can do some exploring and talk to characters around town. Part of your agenda here is to clear your name after being falsely labeled a traitor. This humanizes the Highland and creates a sense of connection to it that will be relevant later. Highland isn't just some enemy, or it's leaders and army, it's where the player grew up, it's full of ordinary people living their lives. 

The two main characters are captured and sentenced to death by a sub boss named Captain Rowd, a serviceable B villain and minor antagonist. 

On their way to execution, they have an brief and interrupted encounter with the princess of highland, who stops and seems to take genuine interest in the plight of the boys, she can't interfere in military matters and the boys are quickly to silenced before they can plead their case, but this establishes her as a character of interest and further humanizes the Highland.

Rowd has the boys prepared for execution as the camera drifts up during his villain speech about the career advancement he expects following their deaths, while the Mercenary leaders sneak in and break them free.

The boys end up fleeing with the player's sister Nanami back to the mercenary fort, and the mercenary captains, Flik and Vik from Suikoden 1, are revealed to be total bad asses during the rescue. 

Events unfold as the Highland makes moves towards war. We're introduce to Luca Blight, a character the player would have had to turn back to see was responsible for the slaughter of the Unicorn Brigade, burning Ryube Village. The player has had enough experience in Ryube to feel the gravity of it's loss. Villagers that player may have interacted with lay dead around them as Luca Blight cuts down a woman's husband and forces her to crawl around acting like a pig humiliating her before killing her. This firmly introduces Luca Blight as a major villain and creates a sense of stakes for what Highland Victory could mean. 

He also lays waste to Toto village where Joey and the Player get their Sword and Shield runes. You encounter a small child named Pilika from an earlier visit to the village. On the first encounter she was enthusiastic about a festival and excited to meet new friends, on this encounter the village is in ruins, everyone is dead, and she is mute from trauma. Nanami adopts her and cares for her like a kid sister.

Events unfold towards Muse and Joey goes to meet with a Highland officer. Later you wait for him at the gates of Muse. The player can go on to bed but Nanami and Pilika stay up to wait for him. If you wait as well, despite being told to go to bed several times, it's a touching scene. It's also the last time Joey is with the player. After events further unfold the Highland attacks Muse and Joey assassinated the mayor of Muse as a Highland spy, switching over to the Highland side. This establishes Joey as a window into the Highland, it helps maintain a sense of intrigue.

Across the Inland Sea is where one of the Mercenary Leaders, Vic, has a showdown with the Vampire Lord Nekron from the previous game, it has it's own bitter sweet story about love, revenge, an unkillable monster, and an egotistical talking sword but at the end of it you get the ruins of his castle and fix them up. 

This is barely the first quarter of the game and several Game of Thrones level developments have occurred, to many it's where the main game begins but everything before this was important to set the stage.

[h1]Now let's contrast with Eiyuden Chronicle![/h1]
First there is no character like Luca Blight and there are no events like the burning of Ryube Village to create a sense of stakes. Any territory the Empire Controls seems relatively unharmed with no sense of stakes until halfway through the game when unethical human experimentation is revealed. 

By contrast Luca Blight dies like a beast in an extremely satisfying trap [b]Halfway Through[/b] Suikoden 2 and the game only gets MORE intriguing after. It takes that long for Eiyuden Chronicle to even give you a compelling reason to see the Dux as someone you couldn't just live with.

No one even dies when a nobody of a spy leads a false flag bandit attack on Noah's Village, buildings burn but everyone escapes and the village is rebuilt good as new so beyond a few scenes it doesn't have the impact it should.

The Dux has more of a corrupt noble feel than a true main villain feel, even as Emperor he seems more arrogant than menacing. He also seems to believe what he's doing is for the progress of mankind, and unfortunately, you have characters who will attack that goal automatically in dialogue. It's imbecilic, unethical human experimentation isn't the only path to progress, the Dux actually does have some good points if lens tech can power a tank it could be used to plow fields as easily as make monsters he just wants to weaponize it.

This game lacks the sense of stakes the burning of Ryube and Tito established, it lacks the intrigue the Sacrifice of the Unicorn Brigade or the Assassination of the Mayor of Muse established, it lacks the window into the other side that Joey provided.

Everything about Eiyuden Chronicle feels like it's going through the motions play acting parts of Suikoden 2 without understanding what made it compelling.

I have to stop here because of character limits, but I hope I've made my points well.

I like Eiyuden Chronicle. I really like the game, but it's being touted as a Suikoden successor and it fails to live up to that legacy in some crucial ways. The moral should be that if there's ever a successor to Eiyuden Chronicle learn from the things Suikoden 2 did better and use it to make a better game.

Hmmm...after browsing some of the user reviews, what else can be said, especially when I haven't beaten the game yet? 

Well, I like it quite a bit and certainly recommend it as exactly what it's store blurb says it is ("a modern take on a classic JRPG experience"). And yes it is, through-and-through; those who didn't play ED Rising won't be lost at all, and anyone who played Rising and liked the setting and characters enough will want to keep going. Rising of course wasn't a prequel, it was a Metroidvania spin-off that came out before this main big game did. I like this universe and hope this franchise sticks around with other instalments and genre spin-offs set within it (let Final Fantasy keep starting from scratch with its settings). 

So the only stuff I can add is that there's a few things haven't been mentioned in the reviews I've seen that ought to be: 

1) It has a bit of a slow start. I'd say it doesn't get going until about 8-10 hours in and I'm all for letting a story breathe and not be rushed, you will have to wait a bit before it shifts gears. There's some padding at the start that I haven't found too bad later on(or "so far since then"), but that abandoned mineshaft that leads to the abandoned fortress is a DRAG and could've been cut in half with nothing lost.   

2) If you liked the cast from EC: Rising and are anticipating that they come along ASAP, alter your expectations. I'm 32 hours in and I still haven't run into CJ, Garoo has popped up a couple times and just re-joined the party for the next big quest, etc. On that note...

3) With a cast that large, some of them you'll want to hang around, most are fine, and there'll be some you can't stand. Pick and choose who you like, they aren't all winners. Pretty much everyone loves the shi'arcs, of course, but Mellore shows up relatively early on, before the others from Rising (for some reason), and she's just as much of a blabbery bubblehead as she was in that game. Which leads to:

4) As you can probably tell from the art style and presentation, this is whimsy galore instead of grimdark. Depending on your liking of that sort of thing, some or even most of it lands, such as the aforementioned desert-dwelling sharks with their pirate-y speech patterns and hardcore scepticism that they ever had anything to do with water in their people's entire existence, and parts of it...really doesn't. Actual quote after a boss battle: "How could you defeat my monsters?!" "We have the power of JUSTICE on our side!" (UGH.) Thankfully I'd say it's more good than groan-worthy but YMMV. 

5) You WILL have to play a mini-game or two to progress the plot; one review on here went negative over the desert race. The controls are a bit wonky and it took a few tries more than I'd have liked, but it can be done. It did bring things to a halt though and I think most of us hate it when that happens.

6) The story (so far) is only slightly-epic. Quality wise, it's fine; not the worst at all, but you can sort of see how it could be more grand. On the other hand they can't all be, let's say, FF6, and that one got rather dark at points, and EC really doesn't seem to want to go too far in that direction. Probably just as well, going too epic and dark can bring about its own faults and failings too.

Thankfully, classic-style inspiration aside the grind part isn't that bad; just fight most of your random battles as they pop up and you'll be fine. The devs were wise enough to have auto-saves and recruit-able characters who take out the tedium (one allows you to teleport to previously visited locations, one allows you to change your party at save points, etc.), and sometimes you won't actually have to get into a huge boss fight after getting smoked en route to the encounter with decimated party members (I'm strongly referring to the part with Seign infiltrating the rune-lens lab with the rune-tank). 

Yes, recommended, and here's hoping the DLC and future stuff is legit good too!

If you're a fan of the original Suikoden series and love JRPGs, then this game is a must-buy. As someone who cherished the classic Suikoden titles, I initially hesitated to dive into this new release. I waited a few weeks after launch, fearing that it might tarnish my fond memories of the originals. However, I can confidently say that this game delivers an exceptional experience.

I rate it a strong 8.5/10.

Cons:

While the game does start off a bit slow, and there are a few missing features from the original series, these are minor issues. There are also some minor imbalances in the magic ability systems, and a few bugs and glitches that might prevent you from recruiting all 120 heroes.

That said, this is, in my opinion, the best JRPG available right now, thanks to the brilliant combination of the Hero system and town-building mechanics. I only wish I had picked it up on launch day. It took me 50 hours to complete while collecting all the heroes.

I truly hope a sequel is in the works. If crowdfunding were an option, I'd happily contribute.

This game took many of the wrong lessons from it's predecessor, and failed to deliver anything worthy of the legacy it shouldered. I wanted to love this game, but it was a chore to play, and there were so many questionable game play choices. The story was rushed, and fairly anti climatic. Spectacle was on full blast to hide the issues causing issues with the writing and world. So many of the characters are forgettable and interchangeable that I basically used the same 6 people start to finish. The game's magic system doesn't come into it's own until late game, but by then you're so invested in the physical attacks because Runelens have been mostly garbage until you get the god tier trap character that blows everyone out of the water. Why does this character even exist? He's so much more powerful than everyone if you use anyone else, you're only handicapping yourself for no real reason. I could rant on and on, but I'm just not going to... this game leaves me tired and disappointed. I kept waiting for the thing that would hook me into this world... but the game is over and I'm still waiting for the hook.

Die-Hard Suikoden 2 fan here and I would not recommend this game if you are hoping this would match or "succeed" it.  However, it is an ok rpg game if that is what you're looking for.  The story is very shallow, the combat system is boring, and the characters are not memorable. In fact, it felt like they tried too hard to squeeze in the 3rd protagonist, when it would have been just fine or better if they focused on two main protagonists.  

There isn't really much else to say.  I spent 85+ hours on the game trying to complete as many of the side quests and mini-games as I could before eventually just wanting to get it over with.  I made sure to get all 120 characters to unlock the best ending.  Got through all the cooking game and 95% of the beigoma.  Unlocked 99% of the castle nodes (had only 3 nodes left), cleared all of the proving grounds on both normal and endless modes, and got most of the playable characters to level 90+.   I would say that this is more of a shell of Suikoden 2 that's without a soul.

A fine spiritual successor to Suikoden 2 that does not fall below expectations. I hope many Suikoden fans share a similar view.

The story is well-written. I find it quite interesting, above average. However, it contains excessively predictable plots, fewer dramatic events, and fewer surprisingly cunning tactics. The link with the prequel, Rising, turned out to be fine. It gives a feeling just like when Suikoden 1 continued its journey in Suikoden 2.

The graphics are a well-done combination of 2D pixel art and 3D-empowered objects, especially the world map and towns. While retaining the old-school style of visuals, it also allows players with older models of PCs to enjoy the game without spending extra money on hardware upgrades.

The gameplay is fairly enjoyable, which means there are not many differences from the archetype. Despite this, the duel scenes and the warfare battles are deemed praiseworthy. While the duel scenes turn out to be more exciting cinematic shows than thrilling fights, the warfare battles offer unsophisticated tactical war play but can produce excitement through a Total War-like environment and characters' dialogues while engaging in combat.

The effort of the voice actors is highly commendable. Despite the large scale of characters, most dialogues are amazingly fully voiced, which, as a consequence, greatly raises the quality of the RPG game.

The vast diversity and quantity of mini-games offered in the game are hard to go unmentioned. In fact, there are so many of them available that only true hardcore players would willingly put in the time and effort to finish them all. However, the good thing is that normal players are only required to partially participate in mini-games as a requirement for story completion. The rest are considered optional. My favorites are the Theatre and Card Game.

The Theatre mini-game, however, is the most commendable one. As the player should have learned the personality and characteristics of each character from the dialogues and events, it is quite fun to assign them roles that are deemed to suit them well and expect to produce good results. The most thrilling part is that all theatre-performable characters have their own lines in every show and every dialogue, with varying levels of acting proficiency, and they are all voiced! In my experience, this is the most amazing aspect of this game.

Obviously, the English language used in the game is still sesquipedalian. The developer's English translator overused synonyms in the townsfolk conversations, which ruined the natural flow of spoken language and resulted in bizarre dialogue. This issue persists from the Rising prequel, which could indicate that the same translators continued their work on this game as well.

Several BGMs (Background Music tracks) are well-composed and memorable, especially those with chorus, which effectively add emotional value to the story.

As a backer, I am impressed and satisfied with this Kickstarter project so far. In comparison with the most-acclaimed Suikoden 2, even though several core elements may still be considered inferior to the magnum opus, the game surprisingly surpasses its inspiring masterpiece in many aspects. Thanks to the great effort of all the developer teams. Even as a humble backer, I am proud to participate in the birth of this emerging great franchise, and I look forward to supporting any interesting projects in the future.

If you liked Suikoden or JRPG's in general its worth checking out.

[h1] 不自由さと不便さは違う [/h1]

古き悪しきJRPGの伝統を引き継いでいないか？と思うくらい不便なUI、システム、そして薄味なストーリー。
ストーリーは物語の大筋だけ読まされている感じで細々としたディティールが無いので薄っぺらいし、主人公も故郷を焼かれたけど人的被害無しですぐに復興と、全然悲壮感が無いまま革命軍のリーダーとして立ち上がっててなんとも言えない。
キャラ描写もメインキャラ以外は仲間になったあとはほとんど何もない（せいぜいプロフィールをお金払って閲覧できるくらい）。敵キャラも名有りは序盤のボスと敵国4名、協力組織1+1名くらい？ボスはプラスアルファで道中にいる魔物や遺跡を守るゴーレムがいるが、シナリオ的にいなくても問題ないので本当にただ倒すだけ。
この辺りを無視してじゃあ戦闘を楽しもう、と思っても雑魚戦はエンカゼロ安定のバランス、ダメージ関連が大味すぎるシステムのせいでボス戦もうーん……
PS1時代に出ていたら佳作くらいの評価だったかもしれない。
今後不便なUIが改善されて、薄味シナリオが気にならないなら試しにちょっと手を出してもいいか……くらいのお勧め度です。
なお、不満の8割はシステム部分とUI関連に収束されます。

以下不満点抜粋
全般
・シナリオ進めていると起こる定期的なPT編成解除
・移動速度遅すぎ→ダッシュブーツ（アクセ装備）に1枠取られるのもサポに1枠取られるのも邪魔すぎ、かといって補正無しじゃ遅すぎて話にならない。
・ダンジョンや街でのカメラワークが悪く視点も変えられない→フィールド以外でカメラ視点動かせないのならいっそ完全固定でもよかったのでは。
・キャラが走るシーンで高速歩きモーションになる（走るモーションがあるキャラでも）。
・魔導レンズの設定が説明不足。ストーリーの重要要素なのに……

戦闘関連
・魔法のMP消費が尋常じゃない。序盤から終盤まで、魔法キャラでも攻撃魔法数発でガス欠する。雑魚戦で使っていられないバランス。
・作戦設定→優先行動に回復が無くても勝手に回復、宝箱解除を第一優先にしても無視して攻撃のみ。欠陥か？
・戦闘中、カメラが動いて臨場感出すのはいいけど、ときどき被ダメが見えなくなる。
・幻水と同じく相対経験値制で一定以上レベル上げるのが難しいので、お気に入りキャラが弱キャラだった場合に活躍させる方法が少ない。キャラ格差も大きい。ついでに適正レベルまで上げたら雑魚戦にほぼ意味がなくなるので、ダンジョンはエンカゼロにするアクセ装備が前提（エンカ率も微妙に高いし消耗するだけなので）。

アイテム、ソート関連
・消費アイテムに個数制限がある（例えば初期回復アイテムは上限6個で、7個持とうとすると持ち物欄を2つ圧迫する）。
・アイテム欄→消費アイテムと装備品やルーン（幻水でいう紋章、街でしか付け替えできない）が同じタブにある（その場で使えない物を一緒にされても邪魔）。
・アイテムソートに種別順がない（持ち物は初期or名前順、倉庫は物理防御or魔法防御or名前順等）。当然鎧や兜、アクセは混ざるしなんならルーンも混ざる。
・本拠地で装備品を買って付け替える際、全キャラから選ぶことになる→PTメンバーと本拠メンバーでタブ分けしたりPTメンバー優先表示がないため、多くのキャラから目当てのキャラを探すのが面倒。
・場所によってキャラの並び順が違う（鍛冶場とそれ以外）。統一していないのもだけど、ここにソート機能付けないんですか？
・アクセ屋の商品の並び→耐性アクセは弱効果一式＞高効果一式と並んでるのにステアップアクセはHP弱＞HP高＞MP弱＞高MPといった感じで並んでるうえ、一部ステアップだけ大きく離れたところにある。

その他
・世界観→いろいろなミニゲーム要素とかあるせいでどういう世界観か分からない（ベーゴマ、カードゲーム）。敵国もラスダンくらいでフィールドマップは無し、おかげで世界の広さもよく分からない。
・戦争モード→1ターンがやたら長くてスキップも高速化もできない。遠距離攻撃がないので接敵してスキル使って戦うだけ。
・一騎打ち→ただのローテーション作業（ほとんど攻撃→防御→攻撃→防御……としか動いてこない）。
・ミニゲームのベーゴマ→低レア＜（超えられない壁）＜高レアなので、高レアベーゴマ落とすモンスターを探す作業が前提にある、仲間キャラをコンプするには必須の苦行。
ベーゴマバトルのノリがホビーアニメみたいで世界観ガン無視、ストーリーにも合っていない。[strike]ベーゴマ投げてブーストスキル溜まり次第使うだけでそもそも面白くない。 [/strike]
・リアルタイム30分単位かかるあれやこれ（一部ミニゲームの進行、キャラ派遣による素材集め、ランダム販売アイテムの有無の更新）。特に派遣は大量に行う必要があるので、10時間くらい放置した。

良かった点
・BGMは全般的に素晴らしい。
・一騎打ちで『しかける』選択時の攻撃応酬のドットアニメはこだわりを感じる。
・取り返しのつかない要素が最終盤までない。

As a long-time enthusiast of the Suikoden series, I approached this title with a mix of anticipation and high expectations. The game itself is not without merit, boasting solid foundations that could have heralded a solid game. However, the experience is marred by character designs that miss the mark, dialogue that often feels unnecessary, and voice performances that detract rather than enhance. Beautiful sprites/graphics, but poor Level Design (lots of empty corridors and too much back and forth in some of the dungeons). I can't bring myself to recommend this game to anyone outside of those who appreciated the Suikoden serie.

Despite these shortcomings, I find myself content with the purchase, supporting the studio with a hopeful eye towards future improvements. I give this game a score of 6/10.

I look forward to a sequel that delivers a more refined narrative, improved combat mechanics, and a more polished realization of the game's ambitious features. The potential for greatness is there, and with more mature storytelling and thoughtful execution, the next installment could reach the heights this game aspired to.

If you are a fan of Suikoden games you will LOVE this one.

I will say that it has a very similar vibe to Suikoden 2. But I don’t personally see that as a bad thing. Suikoden 2 was fantastic and so is this.

The characters are fun. Some are quite annoying though (but I can be picky with that, so take it with a grain of salt).

Gameplay is great. Backgrounds and monsters look phenomenal! The amount of time and effort put into these is amazing.

Fully voice acted. Each of the 120 characters has their own lines, even if it’s just 1-2 lines. The fact that they put this much work into it says a lot.

I would also like to “counter” some of the points other people have made in their negative reviews.

1) Inventory Management. I see some complaints about this. Don’t even bother giving it any thought. As long as you’re storing extra gear/lenses and not carrying every piece of equipment with you, you will have zero issues. Later on you also get to upgrade your carrying capacity. I never once ran out of room.

2) Magic. I see people say that early game magic is weak. It is. Not sure if this was a bug or a balance choice. But most early game spells (Lv1-3 spells) don’t scale with your magic stat. So they do feel quite weak. As a DnD player this doesn’t bother me. Low lv spells are going to be weak 🤷‍♂️. But they still also have their uses. Like group damage or group sleep. Healing, buffs, etc.

3) Gameplay/Story. Gameplay is fantastic. Like I said, if you’re a fan of Suikoden, you’ll love this. And also again, the story has similar vibes to Suikoden 2, which I don’t think is a bad thing.

4) Weak Characters. I see people complain that many of the characters you recruit are quite weak. Not sure if maybe they didn’t get the memo that many characters don’t start to shine until 40-50+. There may still be some that just aren’t good (and I sound like a broken record here but…) many, MANY characters in Suikoden games are nearly useless. So it’s no surprise if a few up end weak here.

p.s. People really have no respect for Yoshitaka Murayama , sadly. They bash his final piece of work with such harsh criticism.

冲着精致的画风和经典JRPG味来的，但最后发现JRPG的精华没留多少，糟粕却几乎全有，倒也确实是经典的JPRG味儿了……
首先提醒一下，简中翻译是坨翔！千万不要用简中，要玩中文就用繁中。
画面场景乍一看很精致，但可以试试把景深关了再看看……总之开了景深看不清，关了景深很粗糙
角色立绘质量不错，但也不出彩，中规中矩。总计120名角色算是雨露均沾把能涉及到的元素都集齐了，不管是LGBT还是福瑞机娘统统都有，但这也导致单个角色的塑造挺薄弱的，更不用说感情戏了。而且虽说可能是想让每个人都能找到自己喜欢的角色，但最终结果感觉反而是喜欢的角色不一定有，讨厌的角色要素倒是几乎必有……最想吐槽的还是momo，明明那么可爱的外形却找了个男CV来配音，一口一个可爱即正义，但难道声音可爱就不是可爱了吗？还是喜欢凯莉的声音
不过大小姐真的是个好女人
剧情方面虎头蛇尾的感觉，高开低走，前中期的叙事节奏和演出表现都还不错，但从北星之后主线节奏就垮了，剧情进展变得很快，但为了收集角色和其他养成要素，却又不得不花大量时间去做各种支线要素，导致叙事变得稀碎，气氛也完全渲染不起来。甚至还断章，最终结局断在一半的地方，根本没把故事讲完，就想着出续作或者DLC骗第二波钱。
子系统玩法方面，出了主线出场的做的十分粗糙且很多设计意义不明的军团战系统，还有陆行鸟赛跑、料理对决、陀螺对战收集、卡牌游戏、钓鱼、温泉收集、图书收集等等各种深度不浅的系统，而且部分玩法为了收集角色还不得不去玩。这些系统都弄下来所花费的精力绝对比主线要多得多，也是导致主线节奏会变的稀碎的罪魁祸首，属实是JRPG的糟粕合集了，这些玩法但凡只加一两个都算是主线之余的休闲娱乐，全加上就纯属恶心人。
战斗方面，因为角色很多所以就需要讲究角色之间的战力平衡问题，很可惜这游戏的角色战力之间差距极大，而且很实在的是越往后加入的角色越强，但新加入的角色练起来也需要花时间，也就是需要单机刷刷刷了。战斗基本上靠SP技能和魔法。英雄连击也就是合体技，可以看出来花了大量心思做的，都有特有的技能动画，很多还做得很精致，但威力还不如单个角色自己扔个技能，基本上都是看一下技能动画然后再也不会用的。心疼一波画像素动画的画师。
还有，到了后期角色练度上去之后，怪物开始不经打了，最后一个BOSS都没过万血，而60级角色一个技能都能打三千了，主线到后面就完全没有战斗的爽快感了……所以，这游戏搞了个深渊出来……
最后差点忘了，唯一没什么可吐槽，全程水平在线的，大概就只有音乐了。

总之就是一个玩到中期都还能打8分以上，通关后却只能打不及格分数的游戏。

村山吉隆的梦幻再线。虽然买到游戏的时候惊闻大师已仙逝，在此表达哀思。
犹记得97还是98年（具体不记得了）夏天买到那本《电子游戏世界》特典，带一张幻水1的光盘，初看不识庐山真面目，暑假玩了人生第一个通宵，打了一晚上干掉魔龙挣得第一个根据地，然后兴奋的起了名字就睡了，再醒来读档，md，没存档！又来一遍，还是很激动。直到后来获得很多伙伴，根据地一再变化，当时真的被深深吸引。大地图的bmg现在听都会莫名激动，吸血鬼城堡boss在那弹钢琴的动画现在还能想起来！那是最初的幻想，最初的痴迷！
PS时代没有汉化，瞎玩一通过了幻水2，后来大学时代某大汉化了PC版的幻水2，那叫一个真激动！每个暑假都要通一遍。抓飞鼠几兄弟最有意思！这代的CD我每首都收藏了，最喜欢回故乡那首，特别悠然！和童年好友的宿命对决，后来直到玩到FF战略汉化以后后面复刻的PSP狮子战争才再次有类似的感悟，幻水最后的单挑实在是太宿命了！二代根据地最喜欢看温泉屋里每个角色的搞笑脸，以及厨艺大赛，解说很恶搞！
上面写了很多番外的话，还是回到这部来吧。总之，我想表达的是我特爱村山的这些设定，可惜，这部成了绝代之作，空留些遗憾。
我玩到拿到根据地就不往前推剧情了，到处找伙伴，升级基地，特别快乐！
小时候的快乐是真的快乐！现在四十多了，感觉人生最美好的时光都是在那些无忧无虑的时候，现在看尽了人世悲凉，少了笑颜，唯有这小时候的记忆再次涌上心头时才能莞尔一笑。
同一回合中，怪要前一个死掉，队伍才会攻击下一个怪。战斗机制也太落后了。

Eu queria muito poder recomendar esse jogo, mas infelizmente os problemas dele são maiores que os pontos positivos. O sistema de combate é extremamente básico, certas mecânicas são mal explicadas ou simplesmente não parecem fazer diferença, há um extremo desequilíbrio entre os personagens, e os minigames são TERRÍVEIS.

Mas o pior de tudo, foi que durante o combate final e zeramento, o jogo BUGOU, repetindo/parando em cenas, e descincronizando o áudio. Eu torço do fundo do coração para que o próximo jogo do Rabbit & Bear Studios tenha uma melhora drástica em relação a esse.

I grew up with Suikoden, Wild Arms, Chrono Trigger, just some of the best JRPGs that have ever been, and I've been chasing a high ever since. I will revisit those games maybe once a year, but I haven't found anything new that gives me that JRPG experience- until now. I am so deeply in love with this game, and I know I have merely dipped my toes in the water, and there is so much more to discover! THANK YOU Devs for this beautiful love letter!

As a lifelong fan of Suikoden, it breaks my heart to say NO to recommending this game, and believe me, I held out as long as I could (nearly 50 hours in) despite having concerns from the start. But it's time. I give up.

There's is a lot to love about it, for sure. The characters are unique and entertaining, the story and general gameplay beats definitely call back to Suikoden in nostalgic ways, the art-style and music are great, though not masterpieces. The voice acting is... "interesting"? There's some charming things here and there but a lot of weird and unexpected choices. If you're a nostalgia wh*re, then maybe this is for you.

But the game fails in the most fundamental way when it comes to RPGs: the gameplay. Now don't get me wrong, Suikoden has it's flaws and balance issues, but I would take them in a heartbeat over the mess that is Eiyuden Chronicle. I can't believe the same people were responsible. Eiyuden attempts to one-up and overcomplicate what Suikoden did (particularly with the rune system), which might not have been so bad if it WORKED, but it doesn't. Magic is easily the worst thing in the game from the beginning. Suikoden had limited uses of it's runes, but they WERE powerful. Whether you saved them for bosses or used them to take out single hard or groups of enemies, they were reliable. Eiyuden ditched the 'uses' in favor of MP, so you might expect that spells are a bit weaker, but more accessible, but no. For whatever barmy reason they made the MP costs ginormous (making you able to cast them even LESS than the limited uses in Suikoden), but the spells themselves (including heals) are like 5 times weaker, making them completely useless most of the time. They don't even LOOK aesthetically pleasing. Seriously, go watch a rune compilation of Suikoden 2 and then watch Eiyuden's. The difference is night and day. I've never seen an RPG make magic feel so unimpactful and like the worst thing you could use, but they managed it. They attempted to balance this with 'SP' a 'free' energy source that increases by 1 each turn but starts at a random (seemingly character-dependent) value each fight, which are used for special moves AND Combo Attacks (yeah, Unites aren't free anymore 'cause why let us have any fun?) but they often take so long to set up for a Combo Attack or special move that by the time you can use them, the battle's over or you've already taken a stupid amount of damage.
Then there's the balancing. Good lord. Again, Suikoden wasn't amazing at this AT TIMES, but Eiyuden's is all over the place. I've had world map enemies deal 1 damage and die in 1 hit, only to then go to the next dungeon in the same area and find that the most basic enemy inside near one or two-shots a party member, often before they even get a turn. In many locations it doesn't feel like you fight random weak enemies and then a boss, it feels like you fight a bunch of elite battles, then a boss (the bosses have often almost felt EASIER than the basic enemies in some cases). I wouldn't mind fights that take more strategy if I actually felt like I had OPTIONS. But with the way they butchered magic, limited things like Combo attacks and made many enemies feel so overpowered I don't know what they actually want us to do. Suikoden has always had bad characters and god-tier characters, but you could generally make any team work with a good balance. Eiyuden does not feel this forgiving AT ALL.
The reason I quit the game is because I reached the point where I could play another character's section of the game, and the party he is given is so trash tier (even after doing grinding and trying to get the best equipment and whatnot I could) and they are given the most horrendous enemies in a dungeon ever (fast, immune to all elements but one that you don't have in the party, and can near two-shot most party members). One of the characters had a 3 SP move that was supposed to be 'strong' but had a 50% frickin' chance to miss. She could start with 0 SP in the fight. So what the hell are you gonna do? Wait 3 turns for a 50% chance move to be AVAILABLE and then waste a turn trying to use it? I have no idea what they were thinking (said character also has humongous metal fists yet somehow does less than HALF damage of a girl who slaps enemies with her sleeves. I'm not even kidding). I had a battle where before most of my characters even acted, three 'Murdersoul' enemies shot at the same character and killed them instantly. The enemies are so ridiculously overtuned in damage that it makes many battles feel like a mini boss or at the very least an unfun slog. And after putting way more time and effort than I wished to into trying to make this section work, I've had enough. The final straw was when I used a particular Combo attack and FOR THE SECOND TIME in as many days, it bugged the game, resulting in a white screen where I could still hear and even interact with the game but couldn't see anything (I'd heard the game was riddled with bugs but this was the first I'd encountered, aside from it just running poorly...) so I had to close the game and lose all my progress in the dungeon for a second time. I held on this long because I love Suikoden but this is actually ruining my day now and at that point, even nostalgia can't save a game. I'm literally gonna go play Suikoden I and II instead. Mad respect for Murayama-san and the team and in SOME ways they did good, but I honestly have no idea what they were thinking or what went wrong here. It saddens me that this is Murayama's legacy and I hope to god the rest of the team can get their sh*t together and re-evaluate what made Suikoden so great, because this ain't it.

Gdy dowiedziałem się, że ma powstać następca Suikodena II strasznie napaliłem się na Eiyudena. Niestety, ani historia, ani gameplay nie zbliżają się poziomem do leciwego pierwowzoru. 
Po 15 godzinach mogę jedynie ocenić, że gra ma sporo irytujących momentów. W grze jesteśmy praktycznie prowadzeni za rękę. Nie ma sensu schodzić ze szlaku wskazanego przez grę. Już najbardziej absurdalne jest to, że po osiągnięciu konkretnego poziomu nie ma absolutnie żadnego sensu atakować słabszych przeciwników, ponieważ praktycznie nie dostajemy z nich expa. Ponadto, właściwie nigdy w tej grze nie czuje się silny i dobrze wyposażony. Każdy nowy obszar zakończony jest bosem, a zamierzeniem twórców było aby był on wyzwaniem. I zawsze jest, a to za sprawą sztucznie kreowanego skalowania. 
W grze brakuje chociaż namiastki dowolności. Brak teleportu w początkowej fazie gry i konieczność wielokrotnego eksplorowania tych samych obszarów tylko zwiększają irytację. Pewnie gdyby pominąć tą część, gra skróciła by się o kilka godzin. A jak wspomniałem wcześniej nie ma sensu wdawać się w walkę ponieważ nasi bohaterowanie nic na tym nie zyskują. Jak wcześniej wspomniałem, można się czuć permanentnie słabym. Mimo iż przeciwnik jest słabszy od nas o 20 poziomów i nie otrzymujemy od nego expa, to mimo to potrafi przywalić postaci z najmniejszymi odpornościami za 1/3 lub nawet 1/2 jej maksymalnego hp. Cóż, kupując spodziewałem się znacznie więcej. Nie polecam.

※以下は今後購入する人のためにも修正してほしい点を厳しめに述べます。
面白かったゆえにもったいないと思ったことがかなりあった。

①周回時の引継ぎ項目が少ない
装備アイテムの引き継ぎはやり込み勢にはありがたい。
1周に1個2個しか取れない最強装備も周回すればパーティ全員に装備できる。

ただしエネミー図鑑や魚図鑑、ミニゲーム関連の収集アイテムやミニゲームのクリア状況など引き継げない項目が多すぎる。
この手の要素は周回プレイがある場合、周回を重ねながら取り漏らしたものを回収していくのがスタンダードだと思うが、1周の間に集めきらないと実績が解除できず、また周回すると集めたものがリセットされてしまうのでやる気が削がれる。
今からでも引き継ぎ可能にすべき。

②意味のないミニゲーム
魚釣り・・・タイミングよくボタンを押すだけ、魚図鑑を埋めても報酬なし、周回時に魚図鑑リセット
カードバトル・・・強いカードを入れるだけで後は運、対戦相手を全員倒しても報酬なし、周回時に集めたカードリセット
ベーゴマバトル・・・強いベーゴマを使うだけで後は運、特に報酬なし、周回時に集めたベーゴマリセット
料理・・・45秒間Aボタン連打するだけ、特に報酬なし、周回時に集めたレシピリセット
特にカードに関しては同じカードが一定枚数被るとカードが光るという仕様があるのに周回したらそれも無に帰るのは正直意味が分からない。

報酬もなくミニゲームとして面白いわけではないのに実績を埋めたければ苦行を強いられる。
しかも①で書いたように周回に入るとクリアしてないことになるのでなんともやるせない気持ちに。

例えば料理ならレシピが一定数増えるたびに報酬をくれる常連客みたいなモブキャラを置くとか、魚なら図鑑が一定数埋まると報酬とか素人が考えてもこの程度のアイデアは出る。
エッグフットレースのみミニゲームとして若干抜けていて（簡易的な競馬の馬育成ゲームみたいな感じ）報酬もしっかりあり、また演劇や温泉はミニゲームではないがしっかり作られてる印象。
せめてエッグフットレースや演劇のようにすべてのミニゲームの報酬にユニークアイテムを付ければやりがいは出ると思う。

③装備アイテムのソート機能が不十分
現状防御力順で並び替えるのがベストになっているという意味不明な状態。
それでも防具とルーンが入り乱れたりしているので単純に種類順という項目を作ってほしい。
アイテムを装備するときに最初はソート順に並んでいるのに1個装備してそのまま次の装備を変えようとするとアイテムの並びがぐちゃぐちゃになるバグあり。探してる装備が見つけにくいし単純に気持ち悪い。

④同じ敵を同時に倒したときに同じセリフが被って爆音になる
これは初歩的なミスすぎる。さっさと直したほうがいい。

⑤ストーリースキップの方法が分かりにくい
自分の場合は3週目に入ってからネットで調べてやっと分かった。
2週目はスキップないのキツいなぁと思いながらプレイしていた。
使っているコントローラーによって違うと思うがBボタン長押しでできる。
ストーリースキップしようとしている場合、どのボタンが対応しているかガチャガチャボタンを押すので長押しは分かりづらい。せめて何かボタンを押したときに右下に～でスキップみたいな補足が出たほうがいい。

⑥たまにフリーズする
オートセーブはあるが正直セーブしてくれるタイミングが少なすぎてほぼ機能していない。
特に問題なのはボスラッシュを繰り返すエンドコンテンツでフリーズするともうやる気がなくなる。
しかも自分の場合フリーズの多くはそこで起こる。
敵が出現してからコマンドを選択する画面が延々出てこない場合と敵を倒してからリザルトが延々出てこないパターンがある。せっかく最強パーティを作ってもこれではエンドコンテンツに挑む気が起きないので何とかしてほしい。

以上。
ミニゲーム云々はさておいてもアイテムのソートやフリーズ、音声が爆音になるなど最低限のところは早く修正してほしい。そうすればギリおすすめするに変更してもいい。
追加コンテンツの実装すら大幅に予定が遅れているので、細かい修正はその後になるのかもはややる気がないのか分からないがとにかく今のままでは到底おすすめはできない。

會推薦原因純粹就是單純紀念百英雄傳的已故製作人當初製作此遊戲的初心以及期許該遊戲團隊可以有資金製作下一個更好的續作或者其他JRPG，要不然此遊戲以我的遊戲體驗其實不到推薦程度，以下就是優缺點分析介紹:
優點
1. 流利的戰鬥場景體驗，在人物放招式時接續都很流暢，看起來是有下一番苦工去打磨
2. 華麗的遊戲畫面跟怪物戰鬥繪圖，畫面用了HD-2D的表現方式，雖然比八方旅人還差一點點，但大部分場景呈現已經算不錯，而怪物戰鬥繪圖甚至比角色繪畫還更細緻，設置在戰鬥畫面表現細節上也有別出心裁的演出

缺點
1. 普通的王道劇情、悲劇的戰鬥遊玩方式，此遊戲在RPG這兩大重點要素竟然沒有下足功夫，只能淪為小品之作，只能說幸好自動戰鬥救了這款遊戲
2. 要致敬經典方式很多，可惜此遊戲選擇讓現在玩家難以接受的方式，有限的包裹容量加上一堆毫無意義的道具在跑迷宮時隨時都會塞滿包包的悲劇，根本讓人瞬間回到20-30年前玩RPG每打完一場戰鬥就得狂清包包的痛苦回憶
3. 此遊戲可以改名叫普攻英雄傳，因為大部人人物在沒有SP點數情況下就只能普攻，而魔法角色更是悲劇，只有少數幾名可以用，且用起來才是真的有感覺，大部分都是打雜而已
4. 英雄連擊讓玩家可以見識到甚麼叫做1+1小於2的效果，完成不知道製作組當初引進這個目的為何
5. 太多無謂的小遊戲體驗，雖然沒有強制性，但為了百英雄傳成就，還是有半強迫要求玩家完成，例如：釣魚真的讓人吐槽到不行，明明隔壁棚的軌跡系列就已經展示如何好好藉由釣魚系統來給玩家遊玩正面回饋，但此遊戲竟然還可以做到跟20-30年前一樣的水準，毫無意義的魚類名稱，永遠的魚肉回饋，真的慘不忍睹；而陀螺、料理就真的不予置評，因為真的玩不懂
6.遊戲優化方面雖然到2024/7版本已經有大幅改善，但用steam deck遊玩時，仍會看到少許場景卡卡的或者轉場動畫不順的問題，希望往後的DLC可以真的有效改善
7. 角色雖然很多，但真的可以上戰場沒有幾個，而且大部分的符文格子都已經被限制住，其實很難玩出很有趣的體驗

As an original backer, I wanted to love this game. It's a very pretty game—the art and music are great—and overall I enjoyed it. However, it suffers from poor quality of life in many areas, most notably in having mediocre gameplay and story. For this reason, I recommend waiting for a sequel which hopefully fixes the problems with the first. That, or grab it if it's heavily discounted and you've run out of other RPG's to play.

If you enjoy JRPG's, you'll probably enjoy this game with a nontrivial amount of frustration. If you don't want to collect every character, you can skip the worst offenses (the Beigoma and cooking minigames) and play only the parts you like. Note that you will miss out on the "true" ending if you fail to recruit every character, however. I did like the card game and the racing/breeding game, though the latter needed more polish to remove tedium and increase interactivity. The theater is fun, but it's not worth the hours of grinding to check shops for a rare script drop you need to unlock each play. As for the main story, look up where to find the dash ring; it's mandatory if you don't want to move like a snail. Also, grab two monster repel charms as soon as you can so that you can turn off encounters when you need to backtrack or get tired of the random encounters. Also, look up where to get Nell; you have limited inventory space that will plague you throughout the game, but it can be upgraded slightly through the castle system and once you find this character who is easily missable. See what I mean about missing quality of life features from the design?

The last point is my main disappointment: it suffers from its premise instead of finding an interesting way of making it work. It boasts 120 unique recruitable characters, but most get a crumb of development when you recruit them and then basically nothing for the rest of the game. There needed to be more route splits and mandatory requirements so that the story can flesh out what are otherwise gimmick-personality stat bots. There easily could have been three main arcs with each protagonist, developing about 20-30 characters at a time, with about 40 or so characters who just function for the main base. Instead, only about 20-30 characters that you must recruit and bring along at times get any dialogue and the other 100-90 characters get one or zero lines of dialogue. There's two route splits and one mission requiring three parties if I remember rightly, but these feel more like demos than actual implementations. 

TL;DR: It's a good looking game, but lacks a lot of quality of life so the gameplay suffers. The ensemble cast of 120 characters is poorly managed, as most are forgettable after recruiting. If you do want to recruit every character for the true ending, you have to suffer through a lot of grinding and poorly-made minigames.

I will try to be objective. If you are RPG Lovers but NEVER play Suikoden I and II, and didn't see this game as Suikoden successor, I say this game is great. It has huge variants of activity, great battle system with rune, skill, and combo, excellent graphics and effects, nice stories, and so on. You can say this is one of the best in RPG.

BUT if you are a Suikoden I and II fans and expect this as their successor (like me), i would say this game is still far beyond Suikoden I and II. The only things that surpass Suikoden II from this game is the graphics and lots of mini games. This is what I think lack in this game compared to Suikoden especially Suikoden II:

First is the story! The story is too 'light' and kids friendly. I personally love a story when you can see Luca Blight massacre a few city and the city will never rebuild. Lots of chances is miss if you don't do recruitment or anything before the town massacre. Also the thing about betrayal is big shock in Suikoden too. And not to mention the character costume also too 'safe' bro! We need Jane like character to enrich the story bro!

Second (SPOILER ALERT)  there is no sea boat riding in world map?! I know you replace it with something similar in dessert, but....

Third, so many character you can recruit in the same town. Is the town is too little or what? It feels like lot's of character are not supposed to be in that town or city, but because there is not many choice so the character feels like forced to stand there and got recruited.

Sorry for the hars review but as a standalone, this is a good RPG game. Well done!

The game starts out incredible and exciting, but then it nosedives so hard for me personally.

The story isn't great, it's not bad either. Generic bad guy hellbent on becoming powerful and conquering every nation. There's a LOT of characters, but they're all actually pretty unique in terms of dialogue and presentation. The pacing isn't too bad either. Traveling around and backtracking to check on new characters is a chore and a pain until you unlock fast travel halfway into the game.

The music is AMAZING and I absolutely love it, which is to be expected with Motoi Sakuraba and Michiko Naruke. They really set the mood for each town, dungeon, fight and scene.

My biggest gripe with the game comes in two forms. There's so many characters: some are great, some are terrible, and the rest are mediocre. Some characters are literally a pain in the ass to recruit, and they turn out to be the most terrible characters so the pay off isn't there at all. Some characters are good when you first recruit them, but fall off later. Some are terrible, but really spike in performance *much* later. The others are either mediocre, or just flat out terrible.

My other gripe with the game is magic. It's useless for 2/3 of the game, existing only to heal and buff your allies. My casters do triple the damage their spells would inflict, which is incredibly hefty in MP cost as well. There's not a lot of variety in magic either, with most of them being buffs or heals. AoE tickles the enemies, and single targets just isn't worth the MP cost when your auto attack can do triple its damage. From what I've gathered, magic doesn't become useful until late game and seeing how I'm nearing the end of the game and magic is only just starting to become useful, it just leaves a really poor taste in my mouth. I love magic, and it's an afterthought in this game.

Also I really, really hate the mini-games in this. They're either buggy and incredibly frustrating, or just a button masher which tires me out in my old age. None of them are fun at all, yet you need to push through a lot of them to recruit some characters.

If you don't mind spending the majority of your battles simply auto attacking and healing, occasionally using skills, with a generic story, a plethora of characters where some are good, some are terrible, and the rest are mediocre, and great music, then this game is for you. If you enjoy having variety in your party like magic and a lot of characters that have their uses, I'm sorry to say this game isn't going to do much for you.

I want to start off by saying I am a huge fan of the Suikoden franchise, and when I heard about this game I was ecstatic. If you are a fan of that style of game you will enjoy this game to a degree. In fact, for the first half of the game, you will be deeply invested in the gameplay, the characters, and the story. The developers do a very good job of setting up a high stakes, there is no winner in war scenario that grabs you by the collar and will have you playing for hours on end and not even notice the time. Where things start to take a turn is when the game opens up and gives you free rein of the world to go recruit, train, gather resources to build your base, etc. There is just TOO MUCH going on in this game. The Devs packed the back half of this game with SO many different mini-games, side quests that don't feel like they have any meaningful impact on the world-building, and a war games mechanic similar to the Suikoden franchise that is so easy it is painful. They try to make this easier on you by giving you two functions;

1) Quick travel.
2) A deus ex machina boss rush mini-game mechanic that can level up any character in the game at the snap of a finger. (Important for when certain characters are required for the story or for you completionists out there)

It just feels like the back half of the game was a smorgasbord of meh ideas instead of polishing a couple of really good ideas to give it a nice clean feel. 

Even though the game ran out of steam at the end it did still scratch that itch and I did feel the love for a franchise that hasn't been touched since I was in high school. It's out of love for the kind of game it strives to be that I do still recommend it, but only if you have a deep love for JRPGs and a love for the Suikoden franchise. If you can't check both of those boxes then I recommend staying away or waiting for a Steam sale to give it a go.

Fantastic game could have done without the cooking and button mashing.  

 Graphics 

 Eiyuden Chronicle is a game that prides itself on being a classic RPG aesthetic with modern quality of life improvements. The pixel graphics for the characters are beautiful and the dialog boxes with character portraits really help to portray the emotion of character. This in combination with voice actors really helped keep me immersed in the story. The 3d rendered backgrounds are also there and well done. Some might not like the mixture of pixel and 3d but I didn't mind it.  

Gameplay 

Classic RPG battle system with quirks and some balance issues. The battles are not hard, and you will quickly find a solid team to use that you will stay with for the game. However, I do wish more time were taken to balance the characters to make more of them viable. Honestly though most cases you can power level in the mystery room (endless boss fight mode) and bring who you want with Nowa, add Momo, profit.  

Story.  

It's a Suikoden based story line with plenty of side quests and recruiting. I do not want to give anything away, so I am keeping it brief. The bad guy is a bad guy, pretty one dimensional. The writers give him some motivation but don't worry it's not too deep, he is the bad guy and that is that. The characters you meet along the way are great and blend with the story well. I felt like the world was moving around me and I wanted to see how it played out keeping me immersed and interested in the overall story. 

Mini games. 

They are fine... The worst part about them is having to participate in two of them to get all 120 heroes. Cooking and Beyblade are clearly designed to play while you play the main story and I recommend doing that because I ignored them until the end and had to devote way more time than I wanted to so I could get all hero's acquired ending. I was not a fan of the cooking game, it would not have been an issue if the games were not 15-minute time gated and you had to button mash to get a gauge up, that was awful and not for me. 

At the end of the day Eiyuden Chronicle is fantastic, I played through the story, got all the heroes, and enjoyed the ride. The artwork, music and game play took me back to when I was twelve and played Suikoden 1 and 2 for the first time with my best friend. I loved those games with a passion and played each one multiple times. This game is not Suikoden and it does not have to be, I would not play this game thinking it's going to be as good as those two games. It's very much its own thing that is inspired by those two games and other classic RPGs as well and I personally am excited for the coming DLCs.  

If you read this far my complaints about the game are just nitpicks, I really do recommend this game to anyone who loves old RPGs but wants a few modern touches.

Slight edit, I played this game on my Steamdeck and it played with zero issues and was a blast!

If you're looking for old-school PS1/2 RPG goodness, this is your jam.  A spiritual successor to the Suikoden games, it hits all the notes.  It even has some of the older limitations (saving only at inns or at points in the dungeons, not even on the overworld map) that may drive you crazy to this day.  Still, it's an interesting world, decent music, and leaves the door open for further adventures.  I'm glad I played it and am waiting for the DLC to spend some more time in the world.  

One word of caution: If you're trying to 100% or at least find all the characters, then some of the mini-games are not fun, and you'll likely want to consult an FAQ to get everyone.  Still, definitely worth the price of admission.

Con la morte nel cuore, non posso che sconsigliare il gioco.
Pur volendo premiare l'impegno degli sviluppatori, infatti, il giudizio complessivo non può che essere negativo.
Per quanto il gioco si dichiari un atto d'amore verso gli amanti degli rpg di un tempo, probabilmente non considera che il pubblico cui è rivolto è gran parte ormai adulto, non più bimbo o adolescente e non può sorbirsi certe scelte banali o una trama che più piatta e noiosa non avrebbe potuto essere.

Il gioco è pieno di scelte di gameplay, bug minori o scelte stilistiche difficilmente comprensibili e fastidiose, delle quali ne cito alcune: le due linee di dialogo ogni volta che ci si teletrasporta (fastidiosissime); la scelta di introdurre la camera segreta, che fa schizzare i livelli dei pg e rende praticamente una passeggiata tutte le battaglie del late game; l'obbligo di introdurre spesso nel party alcuni pg fissi, con la conseguenza di "toglierli" dal party della gilda se in missione (a me è accaduto continuamente); la scelta di relegare alcune item fondamentali ai "rare find" dei negozi, che costringono ad attendere 30 minuti per poi salvare e ricaricare (davvero non capisco come si sia pensato che fosse una buona idea); oppure le linee di dialogo "urlate" che sballonzolano sullo schermo impedendo di leggere cosa ci sia scritto (ci sono interi dialoghi così, è terribile); la sequenza finale è buggatissima e rallenta terribilmente su molti dialoghi, incappando anche nel comico effetto di ripetere anche alcune sequenze della "battaglia finale" (evito spoiler).

Ma ritengo che la "colpa" più grave degli sviluppatori, come detto, sia di aver delineato una trama piatta e banalissima.
C'è l'impero brutto e cattivo che vuole conquistare la lega delle nazioni, mentre sfrutta il potere delle lenti. Punto, la trama è tutta qui. Non ci sono colpi di scena (non degni di nota, quantomeno), non ci sono sottotrame consistenti o sfumature più interessanti. 
Il gioco scimmiotta di fatto la trama di suikoden 1 e 2, ma senza avvicinarsi nemmeno lontanamente e ricalcando tantissimi clichè dei due giochi, con risultati quasi offensivi a mio dire.
Il duca aldric, il villain, è la bruttissima copia di Luca Blith, ma non ne rispecchia per nulla il carisma e la follia; non è folle, non ha personalità, è semplicemente un tipo antipatico e cocciuto che sogghigna sempre sotto i baffi.
Ho sperato fino alla fine di scoprire risvolti più maturi, interessanti, ma niente. La storia finisce così, con una banalità quasi scoraggiante, com'era iniziata.

Conseguentemente a una trama inconsistente, ci sono protagonisti piatti e senza carisma. Il protagonista principale, pur parlando, dice molto meno di quanto dicevano i protagonisti di suikoden 1 e 2 (che erano muti). Peraltro è di una inconsistenza imbarazzante anche dal punto di vista dei poteri, non si capisce quale potere abbia (se ne ha uno) ed è di una debolezza disarmante. L'ho tenuto in party giusto per la gloria.

Per il resto, il gioco ha anche idee interessanti, quali il teatro, lo sviluppo del castello, le corse dei cosi con le uova, o altre, ma sviluppate male.

L'unico vero punto di forza è la grafica, che ho trovato molto bella, un mix godibile di vecchio e nuovo che può essere il punto di partenza per un seguito che, però, sia fondato su presupposti diversi.
Un seguito dovrebbe ripartire da zero, con la stessa filosofia dei vecchi suikoden, ma con idee nuove, una trama matura e degna di questo nome, senza scimmiottare troppo il passato, ma rendendogli omaggio come merita.

I don't understand the negative feedback from some players. Asking for a game based on an old JRPG style will naturally result in gameplay that involves classic elements, such as early struggles with inventory management and long "back-and-forth" travels. The story itself revolves around resistance and the typical rags-to-riches grind. The game will be quite punishing to new players in the beginning, to give a sense of progression as you upgrade your inventory and travel methods. [Spoiler] You eventually get unlimited teleportation from town to town. [/spoiler]. The developers and the author chose not to change this approach because they aimed to recapture the essence of the Suikoden series, which they successfully did.

While the game perfectly satisfied my JRPG and Suikoden cravings, they made it easier, and the story feels lighter.

[b]Luka Blight is still the best villain.[/b]

The villains in this game lack the same level of violence, which reduces the satisfaction of defeating them. In the Suikoden series, you often saw gory scenes, like important characters getting stabbed during cutscenes, fueling your desire to defeat the villain. Eiyuden fails to capture that intensity.

Remember in Suikoden how some characters could only be recruited during specific events and interactions? You had to trigger these events before progressing the story, or the characters would become inaccessible for a while. [b] Or completely miss the chance of recruiting them. Thus, Failing to recruit all the characters and unlocking the true ending. [/b]I want that kind of anxiety of having to use ALOT of saving slots for each chapters. Eiyuden doesn't follow this approach.

One thing that annoys me about this game is how you can still travel to towns that have been captured by the enemy. In Suikoden, you couldn't enter towns that were under enemy control, which was important for the story's sense of revolution. It made you feel the pressure from the opposing side and added to the planning of character recruitment. Eiyuden misses this element, which detracts from the overall experience.

Overall, This satisfy my craving as it captures the essence of suikoden. ALSO, FYI. They will be adding DLC for side stories of the characters, which I think is very good!

I'm very pleased with this game. The amount of care and content is quite impressive, and it kept me engaged and entertained the whole way through. It isn't quite the classic that Suikoden was for me, but it definitely scratched the itch and kept me engaged the whole time. :) 

Recruiting all of the characters was fun, and even [spoiler]beigoma[/spoiler], my least favorite mini-game, had a corny enough side plot with it that I enjoyed it, and it also didn't take long. 

The combat is only okay, as it doesn't feel like anything except basic attack damage and skills scales properly off stats. Magic ended up being basically only for healing, barring a couple of top tier spells that were spammed at the beginning of boss fights.

Progression is well balanced, with good catch-up mechanics for characters who are falling behind. Money for upgrading characters is plentiful.

My favorite part, and what left the most impact for me, were the cinematic duels. The mechanics weren't exactly clear, but I really enjoyed the experience of them regardless. They are extremely cinematic, well choreographed, and made me excited for every time the break gauge is filled up, so I could see what visual spectacle was coming up next.

The story is pretty good as well. Not revolutionary, but a nice political drama story. 

If I was ranking this against the Suikoden games, I'd rank them as follows:
Suikoden II
Suikoden
Suikoden V
Eiyuden
Suikoden IV
Suikoden III

It can definitely stand with them, though it definitely hasn't left the mark that my favorites did. 

As for the localization... It's fine. It's even really good in some places, though it can be pretty funky sometimes. It's definitely not game ruining, though I'm a pretty chill guy. If you're a Japanese purist, it might bother you.

There were also a few bugs, but the devs are patching most of them, and also, I remember playing Suikoden II. For all the wonderful memories I have of that, it had a huge number of bugs and exploits, and things that just didn't work as intended. The minor bugs I encountered were nostalgic for me, if anything, but, of course, I would rather there not have been any. 

For a small studio's first game (even if some of the team is very experienced), I think it worked out really well. They don't have the resources of Konami behind them anymore, after all. The money they raised on Kickstarter isn't actually that much compared to the cost of developing a game.

TL;DR Very good game. Lots of love and care. Not a 'forever classic', but definitely worth the time and money. (Full disclosure, I was a Kickstarter backer.)

困难模式一百小时全成就，终于敢评论这游戏了
我真的很喜欢这游戏，会给一个“好评”；但因为steam的评价是“推荐与否”，所以给“不推荐”
除非和我一样是古早JRPG脑+子供向爱好者+重复劳动享受者+坐牢大师，否则不推荐
[b]——缺点真的太多了！！！！[/b]

先说缺点：
1、游戏底层设计古早，这些一部分是我能忍受的甚至喜欢的，但放在这个时代确实是缺点。无法更改键位；ui交互差，特别是出售、装备、强化武器，非常折磨人[strike]铁匠铺前按a的游戏.jpg[/strike]；采用存档点机制，无法随时存档；自动存档不智能，存档频率低；怪物没有血条显示（虽然可以根据名字颜色判断剩余血量）；遇敌暗雷；战斗过慢，所有的战斗演出均无法加速或跳过（鉴于官方说以后会改那我也认为这是个缺点了）；为了配合游戏性将很多同类游戏的基本功能（编队、传送等等）与角色绑定，导致前期很容易劝退——虽然更像是游戏特色，但总得提一嘴
2、缺乏引导和机制介绍。重灾区是战斗系统，例如元素属性克制、物理属性作用、角色攻击频率（虽然只要是双持角色基本上一次平a就是两下）等等。很难想象已经全成就+无尽50层的我现在都不明白这游戏的各种属性克制到底是怎么回事，也就是打无尽的时候才会提到某某boss弱某某元素属性
3、缺乏内置笔记系统。居然除了主线任务线列表之外没有其他任务列表！没有、任何、列表！你是一个以收集英雄为主线重要节点的游戏啊！！！我也不要求把接了的支线自动记录的功能了，就单独给我一个笔记系统也行啊！！！非得要人时不时用外置笔记本吗？时不时切出去记笔记是很能保证游戏体验吗？[strike]好吧我承认全成就之后回头看记的满满当当的表格还是很有成就感的[/strike]
4、简体中文翻译极差。不推荐任何人使用简中翻译（此外几乎所有简中攻略都基于繁中翻译编写）
5、剧情降智，叙事节奏不流畅。剧情、特别是前期，完全不能带脑子看，后期的情况有所好转，但又都合主义严重，只能说氛围到了也能谅解吧；很大一部分英雄标签感严重，且缺少背景介绍（虽然可以通过占卜、队伍对话、温泉对话等等了解角色的细节设定，但确实没有剧情）；一些英雄的加入过于草率，缺乏剧情铺垫；在我看来主角的工具人属性有些严重；叙事节奏因为三可控主角的三视角设定，牺牲了很多，时常会出现想看ab的剧情但主线唐突切换到c视角的情况——还连队伍角色一起换，鉴于这游戏大部分角色强度不是很行，很多时候非常痛苦
6、地图设计稀烂。大量无任何收集要素的死胡同、民居和拐角，有些甚至连个npc都没有？？野外地图这点配合暗雷机制，只能说在搞人心态方面有一手的
7、小游戏缺乏游戏性和游玩价值，且重复度和肝度过高。小游戏有钓鱼、赛车、烹饪（收集食谱和做饭）、陀螺（收集陀螺和对战）、卡牌对战（开卡包和决斗）、蛋蛋兽赛跑（培育和赛跑）等等，但几乎都是我玩过的游戏内置小游戏里最没游戏性的那档（赛车我愿称之为负游戏性）；烹饪、陀螺和打牌剧情非常子供向（和既视感过强），一部分人可能无法接受；小游戏的道具奖励很差，但又与主线绑定性过强——特别是烹饪和陀螺，硬性要求游玩完毕游戏的大部分内容才能走完美主线。以及捏猫猫的，打牌成就要打120个人[strike]甚至包括各路boss和最终boss[/strike]，你杀了我吧哥们
8、豪华包内容货不对板。本体页面写着“美术设定集超过60张”但实际上只有48张（不过亚兰工艺包商店界面写的就是48张）
9、dlc剧情还不出我好急我好急我好急

再说说为数不多的优点：
1、主角人设个人很喜欢，一些角色个人觉得很有记忆点
2、画风很好看，像素做得很精致，人物动作和战斗动画很不错，以及我挺喜欢战斗运镜的但很多人说晕
3、某些bgm很好听。个人非常喜欢据点发展阶段的bgm（需要指出的是游戏ost只有17首）
4、某些演出很不错[spoiler]指诺瓦和塞恩的夕阳战斗[/spoiler]
5、量大管饱。抛开主要的回合制战斗外还有茫茫多小游戏。还都涉及到人物的故事支线。游玩强度只限主线（完美结局）范畴内我都是能享受的
6、（除温泉对话和右下角队伍聊天外）全配音
7、剧场和温泉对话真的很有趣
8、困难模式脚打。感觉困难五锁才是真正的“困难”模式

总而言之还是很喜欢的。主线过程堪称愉快，但全成就过程非常痛苦，希望全成就的大伙量力而行[spoiler]如果真有想全成就的大伙某些地方找不到攻略欢迎来问[/spoiler]

Le jeu vise principalement les fans de Suikoden 1 et 2 et si on ne les a pas connus on risque évidemment de ne pas comprendre les nombreux clins d’œil qui pourront refroidir certains joueurs non familiers de la licence. Principalement les personnages en pixel qui ont été gardés dans ce style, et en tant que grande fan de Suikoden 1-2 j'adore, c'est ce qui me rappelle le plus ces jeux. Mais c'est vrai que ça peut faire un peu chelou au milieu d'un monde 3D et surtout des monstres qui n'ont pas du tout la DA des persos, même s'ils restent très bien faits, faut garder du recul. Le scénario est axé sur la guerre et bien que sympa, il manque vraiment de réalisme et d'un côté cruel qu'avait pleinement les premiers Suikoden. 

Mais il est quand même sublimé par une BO magnifique, des personnages touchants, et il arrive à marquer sans problème; notamment au travers de certaines scènes impressionnantes. 
Donc pas mal de défauts c'est vrai, d'où la note globale j'imagine, mais perso ça ne m'a pas du tout gâché l'expérience et j'ai réussi assez souvent à me retrouver un peu dans mes réminiscences de Suikoden. 

Je recommande largement, particulièrement aux fans de Suikoden qui cerneront mieux l'intention, s'ils gardent à l'esprit que c'est pas vraiment un Suikoden mais plus un Suikoden-like. C'est la dernière oeuvre de Yoshitaka Murayama (RIP) et c'est un bel hommage de donner sa chance à ce sublime jeu.

120명 동료 다 모으고 진엔딩 봤습니다. 120명 모아야하는 압박감에 사놓고도 시작하는 것에 망설였지만, 120명을 다 모으지 않으면 플탐 채우지도 못하고, 뭔가 밋밋한 걸 느꼈습니다. 그리고 동료마다 짧게나마 스토리가 있고, 특정 동료끼리의 유대감도 있어서, 모으는 재마가 생각보다 쏠쏠했습니다. 몇 동료는 얻는 과정이 약간 복잡했습니다. 검색해보면 잘 정리되 가이드가 있으니, 가이드 보면서 동료 모으는 걸 추천드립니다. 이런 수집?이 큰 비중을 차지하는 게임이라, 수집이나 비밀 찾아내는 것을 좋아하고JRPG의 향수를 느끼고 싶으시면 추천드립니다.
개인적으로 옥토패스 트래블러랑 비교가 됐습니다. 옥트는 전체가 픽셀그래픽으로 겜플부터 배경, 캐릭터, 액선, 감성 전부가 하나의 완성된 작품느낌이라면, 백영웅전은 3D와 2D를 섞은 거라, 가끔은 이도저도아닌 느낌이 들었습니다. 그리고 전투부분을 보자면, 옥트는 약점공략과 버프로 댐지뻥튀기를 하면서 희열을 느꼈는데, 백영웅전은 6명(그리고 서폿 +1)이나 포함된 전투인데도 뭔가 화끈함이 크게 느껴지지 않았습니다. 연계공격도 딱히 전투에 큰 도움이 되는지 모르겠습니다. 
2000년에 이런 게임이 나왔으면 대박이겠지만, JRPG답게 이런저런 요소 많이 넣으면서 정말 열심히 만든 게임이라는 것이 느껴져도, 다듬어야할 부분이 여기저기 많았습니다. 일단 3D랑 2D의 조화로움을 더 신경쓰면서, 6명이라는 전투인원의 활용도를 생각해봤으면합니다.

If you want to scratch that Suikoden itch, this is the game for it.

At some point in playing Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes, I had a glimmer of hope that this would scratch that nostalgic JPRG itch. Sadly, this was not the case due to a whole host of archaic game design decisions. As a game designed as a successor to Suikoden, there are so many missed opportunities to create a title that can shine on its own.

The story is so generic that JRPG fans have seen it a million times before, and there are no standout moments of writing which sets it apart from other titles. The start of the game is painstakingly slow and linear, with the open world only accessible after 15-20 hours. The 3 "main" characters are one-dimensional, and the sequences where the other two characters take the lead are so contrived that it saps away any momentum the story has. It really doesn’t help that you have to hear the “poo-bee” sound every time Marisa appears, which is intended to be endearing but achieves the opposite effect.

The other characters are a bland menagerie of sameness, with some that are borderline copied from Suikoden. There is little to no balancing in the game, and some characters are auto-includes the second you recruit them, while others are so underpowered you never want to see them again (most notably Seign and his Imperial posse). There are some fairly interesting characters with their own time in the sun, but the majority receive an average screentime of 0.1 seconds before being stored away with the rest of the items at the inn.

The combat is insultingly easy even at hard difficulty, and having the auto-battle function just reaffirms the fact that these encounters are so braindead they can play themselves. Although the difficulty of the initial bosses was higher, this was primarily due to the lack of character and skill options. In fact, this doesn’t really improve as you progress with the game as there really isn’t a good amount of variety in the character movesets, especially in non-damaging skills like healing and buffing/debuffing. I understand that the Suikoden series was designed as a casual gameplay experience, but that doesn’t give this game an excuse to not make the combat more engaging or thoughtful.

Probably the most egregious oversight is the hero combo system, where due to the turn and SP costs, combos almost never exceed the damage output of the characters attacking individually, nor do they provide any unique effects, making the whole thing a pointless inclusion. There is also a criminal decision to have some runes, magic options, and even characters that only become accessible at the final dungeon, which gives you next to no time to experience them.  

Although I have been very critical of Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes, I recognise that this is a crowdfunded game without a large budget, and that Yoshitaka Murayama who has led and directed this project, as well as the Suikoden series, was not in the best of health and has sadly passed away before the game’s release. What they have achieved in this context is still worthy of some praise, and by all accounts it is a feature-complete game which presents decently and is worthy of its asking price. The game would still appeal to nostalgic fans looking for a familiar experience. The 2.5D presentation is charming, and the townbuilding aspect does give a sense of your Alliance cause growing in size and strength. The music is decent, but certainly doesn’t hold a candle to the OSTs of the Suikoden series.

Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes has certainly emulated the letter of Suikoden to a fault, but has not brought any significant iterations to the formula since 1998, and stops short of recapturing the spirit of what makes the originals a timeless classic. Had Konami released their remake version at a similar time, this game would struggle to stand against the legacy of its legendary predecessor.

I just 100% the game yesterday and decided to make a review now.

First lets start with the biggest complain a lot of people are talking about the "localization",
to be honest with you yes there are some weird translation in the game but not all of them, as an ESL I can completely understand what they are trying to say for example i think the right sentence should be "Are you sure you want to entrust this [u]dangerous mission[/u] to this boy?" but the game put it like this "Are you sure you want to entrust this [u]mission with high consequence[/u] to this boy?", yea its weird but I believe you would understand it too, most of the complain comes from people(I dont believe these people speak perfect english anyway) that hate specific company so the complain basically not because of the bad localization but more because of the hatred towards the specific company.

But that doesnt mean the game doesnt have a negative point, the are a few things that I dont like from the game:
1. There are so many hidden information like what each type of attacks(slash, throw, trust, etc.) do, each of characters magic affinity, and as simple as elemental weaknesses.

2. Almost every single things in this game are RNG based, it wont bother you if you're not aiming to 100% the game, but if you do it would be such a pain in the ass it is super annoying.

3. Most of basic information like how many characters you already recruit, how many treasure chest you opened, etc. tied to your building facilities, for example if you wanna know a monster information like what are their weakness and dropped items you have to go to the library in your base, you cant access all of those information from the game menu.

And things that a like from the game:
1. I love the base/city building with characters recruitment system when you recruit certain character a new facility will be available, games with similar mechanic like this that I also love on steam are ni no kuni 2, digimon world next order,  ys 8 and suikoden 1&2(hopefully it will release this year).

2. Much like suikoden this game has over a hundred characters to recruit, even though there some useless/joke characters but each of them are unique and you can build the characters however you like for example I make nowa the MC become support character for buffing and healing the party.

3. Theres no need to grind level, gaining a level is super easy in this game thats why if you are playing on normal difficulty(which i pick)  it will be super easy(i love easy game), even though you dont have to grind level but you still need to farm for certain items

4. Its fully voiced! I dont know about other people but Im so amazed by the voice acting in this game especially the theater minigames, this minigame will make you played a certain play like red riding hood, romeo and juliet and you have to pick over a hundred character to play s specific role and every single character with every single role are fully voiced you can try so many combinations of role like putting a beastmen as little red and a kid as the wolf.

I would say if you love suikoden you might feel a little element of suikoden in this game, you might not love it as much as you love suikoden but Im sure you will enjoy playing it.
I pre-order the Deluxe one but If you really not sure about buying it, buy it on sale i recommend buy the standard one, because I dont think the story dlc worth it.

Note : if you set aside the hatred, Im pretty sure you would enjoy the game.
