This is a game that I have been waiting to come out since it was announced that they were making it. As a huge fan of Suikoden I been looking for a RPG that would scratch that itch and even though this game is basic, it defiantly did scratch that itch. For those of you who just want a quick answer, yes I would recommend buying this game and for the rest of you please enjoy my detailed review. 

Graphics/Environment: 7/10

The game does look good with a classic RPG vibe. It is a 3D world and characters are 2D sprites. You have an over world where you travel on a big map to towns or dungeons and then there is the town or dungeon itself when you enter it. The over world makes the world feel vast and large which I like because it makes the world feel more real instead of having everything piled up on top of each other. The bad part is it is big so until you unlock fast travel, which is a little deeper in the game than I would have liked, it means going anywhere for any reason will take time. Once you unlock fast travel it is the classic once you been there once, you can go there again.  Even on the PC the graphics are not perfect. You still have pop in and the occasional texture issue. They are all small issues and just need a bit of polish on the dev side to take care of. I did like the light and water effects and the rune magic looks good as well. The way some things walk/move is a bit weird, especially the way some monster that walk to you in combat, but I got a laugh out of it more than anything. 

Sound: 8/10

Not really to much to say here. Everything sounds good and is synced well. All of the sound effects are solid. The reason it has such a high score is the voice acting. It is top notch and never do I feel like they phoned it in. The music is just OK. It gets the job done and there is a lot of it but there is only one or two songs that are a really good and stick out. 

Story: 6/10 

I hate to say it but the story is just OK. Without giving away any spoilers, the game really does not invoke any emotion into the player. The game plays it very safe in that regard. The villains are all lacking something and even the insults are lacking. To give you an example one of the villains wears a mask so the person in your party calls them mask as an insult which is not much of an insult. The villains have no edge to them is the best way I can describe them. They do very little to make you hate them. One of them does something that should have made you hate him about a quarter of the way into the game but the game itself doesn't follow through with it. I know that sounds weird but if you play the game and get to that point, you will know exactly what I mean. The only thing that evokes any emotion is the ending and even that is not as good as it should have been or could have been. The story is lacking but it was good enough to keep me play until the end. 

Combat:9/10

Best part of the game is the combat system. It is a classic turn based RPG and you can use normal physical attacks, magic that cost MP, special attacks that use SP, items that can heal and later use magic attacks and finally gimmicks. In some boss battles you will have gimmicks. If a boss has this it will be under normal attack and it allows you to use the environment in some way to get an advantage. Like using rubble to dodge a super attack and take no damage or using a crane to drop a bolder on the boss for big damage. Some bosses don't have any gimmicks but the ones that do are all different and they all help you in some way to beat a boss. There is also a gimmick in random encounters but those are just to open treasure chests. The other cool thing is some characters have different things they can do for the defend slot. Most just defend but some charge to make their next attack more powerful, others evade so they have a higher chance of dodging an attack, others have magic shields that stay up until they are attacked and so on. The battles give you lots of options especially once you recruit most of the people. Another thing they did really well for combat is controller rumble. It happens rarely so when it does happen, you know it is for something important.

Final Score 7/10

The game is solid, fun and defiantly worth while. Like I said earlier, if you are a fan of Suikoden then this is a must play. With over 100 people to recruit into your army, you always have someone new to look for and to rotate in and out of your squad. The only other complaint I have is the mini game Beigoma. It is basically Beyblade and the game forces you to play it a lot if you want to recruit everyone. The reason I did not deduct for this mini game is because some people like it and if you are one of them then playing it a bunch is no issue. I did not like it at all and don't want to “let it spin” ever again but odds are I will if I decide to tackle new game plus. This game does have multiple endings and you will more than likely have to play through more than once to get all the endings and Achievements if you are the type of person that goes for that. The good part is that does add to its replay ability especially on a game where one play through can easily be over 70 hours.

All of the Suikoden games were some of my favorite games growing up.   I was not much of a FF player, and with those games I liked the intense choices you could make.   The army battles. For people that enjoy the older style RPGs with great story, this is definitely for you.

All in all, definitely a game I would recommend it for anybody that enjoys a good story and an old school RPG.

Eiyuden Chronicle é o sucessor espiritual de Suikoden desenvolvido pelo seu criador, Yoshitaka Murayama.

Coisas que eu gostei no jogo:
1- A história, apesar de não ser tão incrível quanto a do Suikoden 2 ou do 5, ainda sim é boa e tem uma boa construção de mundo e personagens bacanas.
2- Sistema de batalha com 6 personagens bem divertido; as batalhas de exercito são legais.
3- O jogo é lindo visualmente. A trilha sonora poderia ser melhor, mas não é ruim.
4- Muito conteúdo extra, minigames e personagens para recrutar que fazem o jogo durar mais de 60 horas.
5- Você pode usar o teletransporte dentro das cidades e ele fica disponível bem cedo na história, facilitando a navegação e agilizando o recrutamento de personagens.

Alguns problemas que eu tenho com o jogo:
1- Você tem 11 personagens no grupo, sendo 6 lutadores, 1 de suporte e mais 4 na reserva. Infelizmente, apenas membros obrigatórios do grupo podem ser colocados na reserva, o que torna essa função inútil na maior parte do tempo.
2- Atualmente, o jogo possui alguns lags que ocorrem após o duelo na ponte e depois da batalha com o ultimo chefe. Esses lags chegam a durar 5 minutos e deixam o áudio fora de sincronia.
3- A história é meio apressada na parte final (depois do Castelo Harganthia).
4- O sistema de duelos é bonito de ver pelos efeitos de pixel art dos personagens, mas como mecânica não é muito bom. É tipo um "pedra-papel-tesoura" onde você só tem 2 opções e a terceira é um "Limit Break".
5- A tradução é mediana, mas a maior parte da culpa é dos tradutores da versão em inglês que tomaram muita liberdade com os diálogos. Na versão brasileira, NPCs de qualquer gênero são referidos como "Aldeão". O efeito de tremedeira nas caixas de diálogos é horrível e só serve para atrapalhar a leitura.

I wanted to like this game. My save file has about 30 hours on it, so I feel I gave it a fair shake. The game is decent but has glaring issues. 1- The problem I call the "we have FF12's gambit system at home" problem; it works terribly. 2- So many times you get a cutscene, take one step and then another cutscene. I love games with a lot of cutscenes, but the weird in and out pacing irks me (personal problem) Seriously, just make that one slightly longer cutscene! 3- Some of the recruitments feel obnoxious and genuinely unfun to suffer through. Between backtracking for the umpteenth time to a zone you outleveled 20 hours ago, camping a shop for a random chance for an item you need to deign to spawn in, becoming more and more depressed as RNG continues to laugh in your face as you fail to catch the one fish you need over 65 times... etc... It got to a point where I felt dread at having to get new characters instead of excitement. Especially when you consider how little fleshing out the game does for each character due to its quantity over quality approach. Déjà contrairement à beaucoup je ne viens pas de Suikoden 1 & 2 mais bien de Suikoden Tierkreis sur NDS, ce qui fait que mes attentes sont peut-être ailleurs. Cela dit Tierkreis est pour moi le meilleur jeu de la console et un si ce n'est mon RPG préféré, c'est pourquoi il ne m'a pas fallu beaucoup de temps pour soutenir Eiyuden Chronicle sur Kickstater.

Pour le coup les premières heures ont été agréables : introduction des persos, combats, premier donjon puis on arrive dans la première grande ville et petit à petit la désillusion prend place.
Premier élément, le recrutement des héros est à la limite du ridicule. Peu, voir aucun effort réalisé sur la narration du recrutement : "Oh tu es venu me parler, ça doit être le destin, ça te dit que je t'accompagne ?" ... mais non ! T'es qui au juste ? C'est simple en 3h de jeu j'avais déjà recruté un Samuraï, un Yakuza et une magical girl, bonjour la cohérence. Je ne me sens absolument pas impliqué émotionnellement dans mes héros et c'est d'autant plus vrai pour Nowa qui manque cruèlement de profondeur. Il se retrouve chef d'armée alors qu'il est présent dans la ligue que depuis 6 mois, tu ne vas pas me dire qu'il n'y a pas quelqu'un de plus qualifié ?! La rivalité Seign Nowa me fait penser à une mauvaise adaptation de la rivalité Yuri et Flynn dans Tales of Vesperia.

Les combats sont agréables et pour le coup les animations sont vraiment belles, l'option Auto est bienvenu même si l'intérêt de laisser le jeu jouer à ma place m'échappe un peu.

Pour ce qui est des graphismes, j'ai eu un bug qui m'a bloqué en 1080p, obligé de télécharger un patch sur Github pour monter en 1440p. Cela étant dit, le jeu n'est pas moche loin de là ! Cependant les textures sont trop lisses. On se croirait dans un château de playmobile ou toute la végétation serait en plastique ce qui n'arrange rien à la sensation que j'ai d'être minuscule dans un monde beaucoup trop grand. Vouloir faire de grandes villes c'est bien dans la théorie, mais si dans la pratique 95% des maisons sont fermées et que la taille de la ville nous oblige à courir plusieurs dizaines de secondes pour aller d'un point à un autre, cela ne fait que desservir le gameplay. Pareil pour les villages qui semblent nombreux mais eux aussi bien vides. Et je ne parle même pas de l'idée d'avoir à condamner l'emplacement d'une rune pour pouvoir courir à une vitesse décente.

Pour le reste ce sont des erreurs souvent relevées par d'autres comme la carte des donjons qui est révélé des le début plutôt que l'utilisation d'un brouillard qui se dissipe au fur et à mesure de l'exploration.
Les cutscenes entrecoupés de moment où le jeu nous laisse déplacer nos personnages de 2 mètres avant de relancer une cutscene, pourquoi nous redonner la manette si c'est pour nous la reprendre juste après ?
Les duels, je ne comprenais rien jusqu'à ce que je me rende compte qu'ils étaient scriptés.
L'équilibrage de certains persos qui sont bien plus fort que d'autres.
Enfin et surtout l'UX/UI des menus qui est atroce, on n'a vraiment pas envie de rester dedans.

Finalement tout ces défauts peuvent être outrepassés si derrière il y a une histoire qui peux nous tenir en halène et des héros avec qui on aime jouer. Mais avec le peu d'effort réalisé sur la narration qu'il y ai 20 ou 100 héros cela ne change rien au fait que tout ceci me passe à côté, et je pense que c'est ce qui m'a le plus frustré dans ce jeu. Un bon résumé serait : beaucoup de quantité mais assez peu de qualité. J'aurai préféré avoir 2x moins de lieux et 2x moins de persos mais un travail plus appliqué sur ce qui reste.

Having run a 50+ hour playthrough of this game I can confidently say it's a fairly competent JRPG, there are both a slew of positives and negatives. If you were a fan of Suikoden i could confidently recommend the game, HOWEVER, there are various hiccups that not every JRPG fan might enjoy.

[h3] POSITIVES [/h3]

[list]
    [*]Fantastic visuals; excellently crafted 3D environments and animations. Duels stand out in particular
    [*]The battle system from Suikoden makes a triumphant return, with several additions that add a twist on the classic formula. You might notice it's a tad slow at the start but soon picks up upon meeting new allies and gaining some levels
    [*]A large variety of side activities which very quickly take up a majority of your time
    [*]Character growth through the runes lens system allows for effortless customisation of party members, so feel free to pick your favourite crews and mix and match with little worry
    [*]General optimisation/convenience: The party convoy allows for you to bring story characters along without having them in your combat party OR a certain feature later allowing you to divine the locations of recruitable characters 
    [*]Strong story with decent characterisation of it's main cast, as per the nature of these games there are simply too many characters to get super in depth with each member's backstory. But our free main contenders: Nowa, Seign, and Marisa, are fun people to play as. Many take issue with the localisation of Eiyuden and while I can see where this comes from, nothing in the writing truly took me out of the experience. HOWEVER.
    [*]Backers being incorporated into the environment and as soldiers is cute
[/list]

[h3] NEGATIVES [/h3]

[list]
    [*]Voice acting is a definite hit or miss. JP VAs are consistent, but the EN VAs on occasion miss certain cues in combat animations they were likely not informed of. Some line delivery can also be very dry. Credit where credit is due though, despite the large cast every character has voiced lines for different events and side activities 
    [*]Certain major side quests are just tedious and LONG. Beigoma and Cooking I'm looking at you -_-
    [*]While every character is usable, the disparity in certain character's personal skills and overall stats are absurd. Certain characters immediately delegated to the trash bin despite me liking their designs.
    [*]Character designs and splash arts range from excellent to half baked. Given that there are more than 100 of em' i can't complain too much, but some characters got some wack ass anatomy that really sticks out
    [*]The war strategy game is just a waste of time. Doesn't really require any strategy or thoughtful thinking and environment isn't even a factor - and perhaps most disappointingly there aren't unique models/animations for major characters on the battlefield, the rune tank being the key exception. Also no speed up option
    [*]While the 3D environments are pretty there is very little to explore in the overworld, certain combat areas can also feel quite empty - despite full scale combat occurring in the locale at the time
    [*]DLC doesnt need to exist, and should really be a part of the main game 
[/list]

[h3] POTENTIAL IMPROVEMENTS [/h3]

[list]
    [*]Base movement speed is UNGODLY slow. The movement speed with the dash boots should be the default speed
    [*]x1.5 speed in combat option. While I personally had no qualms with the overall speed, I can see why people complain about it
    [*]Descriptions for character stats
[/list] 

[h3] OVERALL SCORE: 7/10 [/h3]

Eiyuden Chronicle is a spiritual successor to a game series I love: Suikoden. If you like Suikoden, you'll probably like Eiyuden Chronicle. That might not be helpful comparison because Suikoden never quite caught on like other RPGs of its era, so its understandable if you've never played those games or maybe even heard of them. But the short version of this review is that. If you like Suikoden, you'll probably like Eiyuden Chronicle.

So now for the longer version. I feel very conflicted about Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes. On the one hand, it's so much like Suikoden that my nostalgia for those games is doing a lot of heavy lifting to help me look past the game's flaws. On the other, I recognize newcomers to this game probably are going to be put off by a lot of stuff. Eiyuden Chronicle is a turn-based RPG where you recruit over 100 heroes, build up a castle base, and follow the story of these heroes as they fight against a powerful enemy. I'll start with the things I really like about this game.

The world, story, and characters for Eiyuden Chronicle are all stand outs in this genre for me. I played the prequel game, Eiyuden Chronicle: Rising, and thought that game was fine. Nothing particularly special but it established an interesting world. I felt this way about Suikoden and I feel the same about Eiyuden Chronicle in that it feels like the world should be incoherent but isn't. The developers have thrown a lot of things they think are fun or interesting into this world that somehow work together. For example, many of the characters are anthropomorphic animals but there are also elves and dwarfs. Even though it seems like this should create some inconsistencies in theme or tone, it just makes the world seem bigger and more interesting because it has all these different thing in it.

The story isn't anything particularly special in its broad strokes; it's mostly a story of good triumphing over evil and an underdog winning when the odds are against them. But the moments within the story are strong and unique. With so many recruitable characters, not every character will get a strong arc but it's fun to follow the ones that do as their relationships grow and change. There are some weird and interesting twists that keep things interesting. It also sets the story on a grand scale which contributes to the world feeling big and complicated.

The character recruiting and base building aspects are probably what was most unique about Suikoden when it first came out and in the decades since I haven't seen many games duplicate that success. And here Eiyuden Chronicle shines too. Even when a character isn't super deep, they will always have a cool design or contribute something to the base, so you'll want to seek them out and you'll get excited when you enter a town and you see that sweet, sweet unique sprite standing there waiting to be recruited. The rhythm of the game usually goes: complete a main story mission, recruit a bunch of characters. And that's a great rhythm. Plus all the characters are voice-acted which is wild to me for a game of this scale. And even more impressively, the voice acting and writing is great, with maybe one or two characters that might rub you the wrong way. A pretty good ratio considering how many there are in the game.

The turn-based combat is also a highlight for me, although it is missing some of the quality of life tweaks that older-style RPGs like Eiyuden Chronicle benefit from. Battles can sometimes go a little slow or drag but there are items and options for avoiding fights if they're getting too frustrating. Because you can have up to 6 characters in your party, plus a support character, there's a lot of room for experimentation. The battle animations are fun and flashy and the hero combo system, where different groups of heroes can team up for an attack are a lot of fun to test out, while you're trying to build a team that synergizes well. You can customize a character's armor and accessories, upgrade their weapon power, and modify their runes which give active benefits like new spells and passive benefits like increased stats.

If you can focus on those areas, you'll probably have a good amount of fun with Eiyuden Chronicle, especially if you like RPGs. Unfortunately, to recruit all the characters and get the best ending, you have to do Eiyuden Chronicle's minigames, which are the least interesting parts of this game. There are a lot of minigames in Eiyuden Chronicle and I'm sorry to say I didn't really enjoy any of them. We're living in a golden age of minigames where some games have minigames that eclipse the main game or go on to be spun off as their own standalone games. So it's hard to look at Eiyuden Chronicle's fishing mingame where you wait for an exclamation mark to appear above your character's head and then press the button and feel any kind of excitement. That fishing minigame is something video games had mastered years and years ago and even with nostalgia, it just isn't compelling (although the fish are very weird and silly which I appreciated). Of all the minigames, beigoma (it's like battle tops) was my least favorite (with cooking coming in a close second) and the theater was the best. With the theater, you put on a play where you cast your characters in different roles and somehow it's all voice acted which is an incredible achievement. 

The insult to injury here is that there isn't usually a big benefit to doing any of these minigames, especially considering the time you have to put into them, so once you've tried them, you probably won't go back. This is where Eiyuden Chronicle is too close to its inspirations. It adds things that it doesn't really need that slow things down in an unfortunate way. My best advice would be to do only what you have to with the minigames and then leave them behind for the much better parts of this game.

So that's the long review. They don't make games like Eiyuden Chronicle anymore, for better and for worse. I think people who enjoy RPGs, especially turn-based RPGs, will enjoy this one if they stick mostly to the main story, character recruiting, and base upgrades. Una Gran Decepción

Después de esperar con ansias "Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes", lamentablemente me encuentro muy decepcionado. Aquí están mis razones después de más de 50 horas de juego:
Pros:

    Banda sonora: La música es envolvente y se adapta bien a la atmósfera del juego.

Contras:

    Sonido: Increíblemente, no hay sonido de los pasos. Esta omisión básica rompe la inmersión y hace que el mundo del juego se sienta incompleto.
    Minijuegos: Los minijuegos son insulsos y carecen de cualquier tipo de desafío o diversión. Se sienten como tareas obligatorias y no aportan nada a la experiencia general.
    Magias: Las magias no tienen sentido. En ocasiones, los hechizos hacen mucho daño y en otras apenas quitan 1 de vida sin razón aparente. Esta inconsistencia es frustrante y afecta negativamente la estrategia del juego.
    Desincronización: En la parte final del juego, los sonidos están completamente desincronizados con lo que ocurre en pantalla. Esto no solo es molesto sino que arruina por completo la experiencia del clímax del juego.
    Bocadillos de diálogo: La decisión de mover los bocadillos de gritar por la pantalla es la peor ocurrencia que he visto en un juego. No puedes leer lo que los personajes están diciendo hasta mucho después, lo que dificulta seguir la trama y entender lo que está pasando.

En resumen, "Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes" prometía mucho, pero se siente como un producto incompleto y lleno de decisiones de diseño cuestionables. A menos que se realicen mejoras significativas, no puedo recomendar este juego. Hay muchas otras opciones en Steam que ofrecen una experiencia más pulida y satisfactoria.

The game, while enjoyable, stubs its own toe by having too much at times; The age old quantity over quality dilemma.  This feeling is amplified when you experience parts where you wanted more of that, and instead see other elements that felt unnecessary, or rushed into the final package.

—
The overall story is fine for what it is.  Though at times it felt as if it wanted to come off as a story about 3 main characters…when it never truly lends itself to that.

I am fine with it being a story revolving around just a primary character, or the ambitious story telling Suikoden 3 did where you trade off between multiple characters.

It felt odd at times that the game tried to pull a Suikoden 3 aspect of storytelling, but it felt forced.  Elements that felt unfinished or unnecessary at times.

You end up more teased with their other supposed main characters then getting anything memorable; because the bulk of the game still follows 1 main character.
—

The combat is serviceable.  Clearly they changed the rune system from Suikoden into MP points.  So similar to those games, you’d horde that resource for tough fights or namely boss fights.  

Was not a fan of the equip-able rune-lens system however, as it ended up feeling quite restrictive with how little flexibility many of your characters ended up having.  You’d rarely ever be able to change off their default skills for other options due to how they set it up.  

The stats of your characters also was a pet-peeve, how some of the characters I wanted in my party due to their look/theme/personality I ended up holding off, because they would be severely gimped in comparison to others.  
Presumably characters had different stats scaling at later levels, but you spend the grand majority of the game without the means to get them to those levels…so once more, I was not a fan of having to shelve characters because they felt too hindered compared to others.

The team combos sadly felt underwhelming.  In my experimenting, it felt as though you lost out on damage from doing them; there were some expectations, like the AoE base ones. It's understandable they do less, but to more foes.  So for many of them, the only reason to use it was for watching a cutscene.  Just didn’t make any sense why they would go this route.  A number of methods could have been done to fix this, even if it meant buffing them up and limiting them to once per combat or something of the like.
—

The game had a lot of mini games.  Yet few felt enjoyable.  They should have removed half of them if it meant more time spent to improve upon the ones kept.

—

While it was a small part of the game, the tribute to the dueling system from Suikoden felt great in its later fights.  Well, the gameplay of it was simple, but for a visual treat it was quite enjoyable watching the [break] sequences play out.    

—
The main story battlefield events were underwhelming from a gameplay aspect.

The story they told during the fight was fine, when narratively you had the odds against you, or how your strategist would come up with twists throughout the fights.

But experiencing it through the gameplay was disheartening.  Was always on a small grid where you were forced to start all your troops in 1 spot, just marching forward.

—

Ultimately I feel my review comes off far more critical of the game.  Yet I still want it to succeed so that we can inspire other game developers to make these traditional RPG games.  They are tougher to pull off, and I'm not sure they appeal to the majority of gamers, yet I hope they never die off.

This is a more-or-less fantastic re-envisioning of Suikoden for the modern era. The story beats are recognizable but not predictable, the characters are a good mix of feeling super-fresh and familiar, and they did a good job bringing back the best mini-games and making new ones. Minimal fourth wall breaking, good challenge (in hard mode), castle-building feels good (and even a touch meatier than Suiko 2, I think I like having to recruit a person *and* build their shop separately), large-scale combat feels good (it seems very limited the first time you do it, it expands nicely). Music good, though a few tracks feel *so* reminiscent of Suiko 2 I found myself just wanting to hear those tracks instead out of pure nostalgia; graphic style feels about perfect, though on occasion backtracking in areas with fixed camera angles can feel odd.

I waited a *looooooooooong* time for this game, long enough to get excited, lose all expectations, and do it all again. Suikoden II is my favorite JRPG of all time, and I was worried that after 25 years, even its creator would have trouble recapturing that magic. He did not, and the game serves as a wonderful memorial for a gifted storyteller. With a minimal amount of love and patches this could easily be a 9/10, though even as it is I gotta give it a 8.5/10.

it lacks a bit of suikoden's intuitiveness. maybe it's because its just expected people have strategy guides now, but doing a full-on "find everything" playthrough has had a few very weird curveballs that i needed some help with. there's also two different questlines involving two different minigames which are similarly a bit obtuse; i'm not sure why but the cooking minigame feels *far* more punishing than suiko 2's was, despite being essentially the exact same thing. little to no guidance on what most characters want (unless you spend a lot of time with the seer taking notes), extremely limited recipe option, and very picky judges who don't seem to know what they want - for instance, a character who says they like "chopped up steak thrown on a grill" but hates kebabs. or a character who says they love sweets but hates the ice cream i serve for dessert. meanwhile beigoma's actually sort of fun but could've used more guidance on mechanics, clearer ideas of what monsters are worth farming for their tops, and just a *little* more fleshing out. meanwhile, there's also a pretty cool card game, but nobody seems to want to play it, whereas there's at least one rando NPC playing beigoma in every town. i'm still digging the story, the characters, and the main combat system, but after spending a few days struggling with two minigames just to recruit characters i felt like it was flaws that needed mentioning.

oh, and i still hate the auto-battle function. characters will randomly use very powerful consumables, spend all their mp, and completely ignore half the directions you gave them in the battle plan menu, which itself is poorly laid out and poorly explained. in suikoden, "auto" just made every character attack, and i can't for the life of me set this up to do the same very basic concept, much less properly implement any of the "use an AOE spell if there are at least X enemies" sort of functionality that should be doable with the (bad) options given.

Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes,
Est un excellent JRPG au tour par tour.
Grâce à sa très réussie campagne Kickstarter, ce remarquable jeu a vu le jour.
Si vous avez aimé la série Octopath Traveler, ce jeu en reprend les mêmes mécanismes.
Avec une histoire où l'on relate le passé de chaque personnage avant qu'il ne rejoigne notre équipe,
Des combats stratégiques au tour par tour avec une équipe de 6 personnages, dont 3 sont en première ligne et les 3 autres en appui.
Une gigantesque carte a exploré (avant qu'on ne débloque la téléportation),
Des mini-jeux de toupie tournante Beigoma (Beyblade) 3,2,1 Hyper Vitesse ! , 
                       de jeu de carte 
                       ou encore un jeu de cuisine 
Le nom du jeu, "Hundred Heroes", est tout à fait approprié, car il y a 120 personnages à débloquer.
Si vous êtes un amateur de JRPG classiques, ce jeu est idéal pour vous.
Voici une pensée pour Yoshitaka Murayama, qui n'a malheureusement pas pu assister à la réussite commerciale de son jeu avant son décès.

I'm a bit mixed on this game. I think it is worth checking out for Suikoden fans as it does have the same vibe from those games. However, I feel like for most it won't click. Personally I did enjoy parts of the game, but it has some major issues. From story issues to poor balancing there are enough frustrating aspects that I can't really recommend this to most.

First of all the story is terribly paced. I understand they are doing the whole "collect over 100 characters" thing which is difficult to balance, but the main story and cast needed more focus. From the beginning they want to push Nowa and Seign's friendship but they never flesh it out properly and it's very forced. The guardians are an interesting group that feel half fleshed out. The elves are barely there at all. The dragons are under utilized. Basically no group really gets enough time to shine. Really the only character they gave enough time to was Perrielle who IMO came off odd - almost like what a Twitter warrior thinks they would do in medieval times. Nowa is bland and uninteresting which works as the self insert character but not so good on his own. Seign gets a few moments but he's mostly in the background. Marissa was boring and generic - I was expecting more from all 3 cover characters.

The gameplay is okay. They needed a 2x and 3x speed imo as the battles are very repetitive. Auto battle is nice on easier fights. Fleeing is worthless as it fails more often than not and puts you in a bad spot if you aren't careful. The characters are not balanced well at all. I understand it's impossible to balance everyone perfectly but some are terrible and others are amazing. Most of the mini games are poorly balanced and overly easy or difficult. There's just enough frustrating aspects that it pulled me out of the game one too many times and I gave up on getting every character because of the cooking mini game that never ended and the bayblade rip off that was terribly implemented.

Despite my negativity here, I will say I did still have fun and I did beat the story. The core gameplay mechanics of building up a castle and collecting characters worked for me and was enjoyable. The characters I used in battle were fun - although swapping out ruin lenses was a pain because of limited inventory and limited places you can change them and limited slots per character. I feel like the process to swap characters, equipment and runes needs to be streamlined if they want more people to experiment. I felt the MP system was a bit off as you'd use a large amount of MP and get very little damage/healing. They did release a patch half way through my playthrough and it was a bit better. The overall story does work well enough even if the characters feel generic. The voice acting was pretty decent. I would say if you have GamePass to try it there but full price will be too much for most people IMO.

Aber nur mit Bedenken! Einfach zu viele unnötige Hindernisse bei den QoL. Manche Dinge waren früher auch nur nervig. Es gab eben keine besseren Lösungen dafür. Da fühle ich mich nicht an die "guten Alten Zeiten" erinnert. Die meisten Figuren die ich bisher rekrutiert habe, da ist es praktisch egal wen ich im Team habe. Beim Balance gibt es da auch immer wieder Probleme in den Kämpfen. Nichts weltbewegendes, dennoch verbringt man ja eine Unmenge Zeit damit. Das nervt mehr als das es stört, was es so schwer macht es wirklich zu kritisieren. Selten wird ne Persönlichkeit vorgestellt, die man weiter verfolgen würde. Aber alle kommen mit nem guten Start beim Vorstellen. Mich interessieren fast nur die "Helfer", und auch da ist mir unerklärlich was manche Boni fürn Sinn machen sollen, Auch technisch wäre das polieren besser gewesen als so viele Mini Games ohne echten nutzen. Die fühlen sich auch nicht wirklich in die Spielwelt integriert an. 

Das ist meckern auf hohem Niveau, das Spiel macht durchaus auch Spaß. Boss-Fights sind echt unterhaltsam. Aber immer wieder muss ich mich motivieren, anstatt mit Eifer zu starten. Das meiste ist ganz gut, aber irgendwie ist das ein massives Auf und Ab, ohne so zu wirken. Eben schwer greifbar finde ich. Alles wirkt auch als wäre man hoch motiviert an den Start gegangen, aber dann hat man es "9to5" zu einem Ende gebracht.  

Mein vorläufiges Fazit: Nostalgisches RPG, aber es wurde mir zu viel von den, schon damaligen Problemen mit übernommen. Und es wirkt auch immer wieder monoton. Dennoch möchte ich es allen empfehlen die JRPGs mögen. Ich werde es sicher noch zu Ende bringen, und das wird mich wohl noch einige Std. kosten.

Nachtrag mit Spoiler: 

[spoiler] Man konnte sogenannte "Heldenkämpfe" freischalten. Beim ersten Mal sprangen meine Helden nach nur einer Runde von Level 50 auf 60. Ab diesem Punkt war kein Kampf mehr "belohnend", nicht mal mehr Bosse in Dungeons. Im letzen Dungeon bin ich vor den Kämpfen geflohen weil sie nichts lohnenswertes mehr gebracht haben, außer Geld. Doch dafür haben sich die Auto-Kämpfe nicht gelohnt, da sie durch die technischen Fähigkeiten und ihre Animationen unnötig lang waren. Ich hab das noch nie gemacht, im letzten Abschnitt gab es immer gute Gegner mit lohnenswerten Loot oder Exp in JRPGs.  Generell waren die letzten Abschnitte total monoton und wirkten lieblos. Nicht mal mehr nen gutes Rätsel, Nen Raum mit X-Mal hin und her, inkl mehr Fights als üblich. Das war nervig, selbst mit dem passenden Ring für weniger Fights. Ich habe nicht mal grinden müssen, so das man dass als Grund für den hohen Level nehmen kann. Ab ca. Level 60 ist das Spiel einfach nur noch durchrennen. Am Anfang war noch richtig "aufpassen" und auf Heilung achten nötig. Der Endgegener war nen Witz, und mit 60er Chars im Automodus machbar. Und was dann kam war einfach nur Ufff...

Ich bin enttäuscht, auch in einigen anderen Punkten wie oben schon erwähnt. Besonders von den letzten 10% des Spiels. Trotzdem bleibt der Daumen hoch, weil eben auch viel unterhaltsames im Spiel ist. Doch DLC oder ein weiterer Teil, nur dann, wenn er in nem Sale wäre. dafür ist hier vieles einfach lieblos zu einem Ende gebracht worden. Und ich liebe hier die Mischung aus 2D/3D, und das Kampfsystem, eben JRPG. Das macht für mich ganz viel wieder gut.  [/spoiler]

Etant un fan de la première heure des suikoden (surtout les 1 et 2) j'attendais beaucoup de Eiyuden Chronicle, qui a tout d'un suikoden 6 soyons clair (sauf le lore géopolitique).

Au final je suis partagé, le jeu est plutôt bon mais clairement pas au niveau des premiers suikoden. Si je devais donner un classement (en tenant compte de leur date de sortie)  je dirais : 2 > 1 > 5 > Eiyuden > 3 > 4

Certains aspects du jeux sont très réussis, voici la liste de ce que j'ai aimé :
- Le développement du château, très bien pensé  (sauf sur un point sur lequel je reviendrais) et mieux que dans l'ensemble des suikoden. C'est le gros point positif du jeux pour moi.
- Les très belles musiques du niveau d'un suikoden, ainsi que les très bon doublage (japonais pour ma part)
- La DA, les graphismes, très efficace
- Beaucoup de personnages à recruter, encore plus que dans suikoden, avec des persos bien barrés comme on aime
- Le système de guerre qui est pas mal bien que très peu tactique. On voit qu'on est dans une guerre de grande ampleur. C'était le point négatif de suikoden 2 pour moi (le seul d'ailleurs)
- Le jeu de carte, qui parait mauvais au premier abord, mais qui se révèle très sympa au final, une très bonne surprise, tout comme le jeu de course, que j'ai beaucoup aimé
- Les races comme les hommes requins, kangourous etc. Très sympa et ça change des elfs.
- Beaucoup de chose à faire, à collectionner, à customiser. Les pièces de théâtres sont réussis également.
- Le personnage principal parle enfin. ENFIN. C'était insupportable les persos muets des suikoden.

Dans les aspects négatifs :
- Le scénario est très en dessous d'un suikoden 2, 5 et même 1. On est au niveau d'un suikoden 3 sur ce point (mais au dessus du 4 qui est le pire)
- L'antagoniste n'a absolument pas l'aura d'un Luca Blight (suikoden 2, et encore moins de l'autre antagoniste du 2 no spoil) ou d'un Barbarosa Rugner (suikoden 1). Et même pas d'un Godwin de suikoden 5. Et d'une manière générale les ennemis ne sont pas à la hauteur d'un Neclord, ou des généraux de suikoden 1.
- Il y a un manque d'évènements marquants. Dans suikoden 1 on sentait le côté désespéré dans les premières heures, et le côté tragique du scénario. Et je ne parle même pas de suikoden 2 qui est magnifique sur ce point. Le scénario est trop lisse, trop convenu, trop manichéen, trop gamin en fait. 
- Absence de personnage à fort charisme (Viktor, Flick, Mathiu, Gremio etc.), même si Seign et Marisa sont sympas. La quasi totalité des personnages n'ont aucun background.
- Equilibrage très étrange, les magies sont particulièrement faibles par rapport à leur coût en MP. Le système de Spell Slot des suikoden était MILLE FOIS MIEUX que celui des MP de Eiyuden. Pourquoi avoir changé ça ? C'est un très mauvaise idée. C'est d'autant plus incompréhensible que ça marchait très bien dans les suikoden. De même les combos n'ont quasi aucun intérêt sauf un ou deux.
- Certains jeux sont pénibles sur la longueur, comme les beigoma ou la cuisine. Ils sont pourtant indispensable si on veut les 120 persos et la vrai fin. La cuisine par exemple, quel intérêt de demander au joueur de marteler la manette pendant 1 minute. Dans quel monde c'est intéressant de faire ça ?
- Les villes manquent cruellement de vie. En 2024 ça le fait pas. On dirait un RPG des années 90 là (et encore, certains font mieux). Les PNJ sont trop statiques et trop peu nombreux, on ne se croirait pas du tout dans une capitale quand on entre dans une grande ville. je ne m'attendais pas à un witcher 3, BG 3 ou un RD2, mais là ça fait vraiment suikoden 1 et ce n'est pas un compliment.
- Le sound design est très mauvais. Ce qui renforce le sentiment d'absence de vie. Dans une ville on doit entendre du bruit, des oiseaux, du vent, bruit de pas etc. Il n'y a rien ici, j'ai même cru que le jeu boguait chez moi, mais non. Même quand des oiseaux s'envolent il n'y a pas de bruit, ni même quand on ouvre une porte. C'est incompréhensible.
- Pas mal de bugs, certains mineurs, d'autres très pénibles. Chez moi le jeu crashait de temps en temps lors des combats, et à 100% lors d'un boss ce qui me bloquait le jeu. J'ai passé la résolution en 1920 * 1080 et je n'ai plus eu aucun crash depuis (j'étais en 1440). Avec pourtant une RTX 4070...
- Les traductions étranges. "Les nabots" ?? Sérieusement ? qui a traduit ça. Après m'être renseigné il se trouve qu'en anglais ils les appellent les imps (pour imperials) ce qui forme un jeu de mot. Et en français ils ont traduit imps qui veut dire lutins en nabots. Pas mal de bizarrerie de ce genre comme un personnage qui demande de lui amener une rune de courant (alors que c'est torrent), toutefois ça n'empêche pas de finir le jeu et c'est pas dramatique. 
- Il est facile de casser le jeu avec le château, quand on développe la salle mystérieuse. Je suis passé du niveau 40 à 60 en 5 minutes. Avec des ennemis dans l'histoire au niveau 40, et un boss de fin calibré pour du 60 - 65. En continuant cette salle mes persos étaient invincibles, et pire, j'ai vu le boss de fin avant de l'affronter dans le scénario... (car la salle est un ré affrontement des boss, même si on a jamais rencontré le boss avant). Cette salle n'aurait du être réservée qu'au post game, mais il est très simple de la construire au 2/3 du jeu cassant tout l'équilibrage.

Non mi dilungo troppo, finirei per ripetere quanto detto da molti altri ma in breve a livello di gameplay e contenuti per me ci sta tutto.

こういうたくさんの仲間が勢ぞろいして巨悪と戦うみたいなゲームが好きだったので「幻想水滸伝」を知らずにプレイしましたが、個人的には非常に楽しむことができました。

ほかでよく言われているように、主にシステム周りでの不自由さだったり不満はあるんですが、私はいい面も悪い面もトレードオフになると思っていて、批判的に見れば悪くなるし、作品に対して肯定的な立場から見れば許容できるものだと思います。

私がそのあたりのよくある不満に躓くことなく最後まで楽しめたのは、やはり近年まれにみるほどの圧倒的な作りこみを前に、作品に対して純粋に敬意を感じ、「真剣に向き合わなくては」と思ったからです。ゲーム全体のスケールとしてはある程度コンパクトにまとまってはいるものの、それを補う圧倒的なコンテンツ量と、物語のフェーズに合わせて変化していくインタラクションの様子は本当に見事でした。何よりもキャラクター一人ひとりが魅力的であり、王道のストーリー自体にも共感がもてたので、仲間とのかけあいや物語の起承転結を楽しみに、前のめりに向かっていたというのもあるかとおもいます。

以下、簡潔な所感となりますが、
・前半の戦闘バランスやシステム周りの不自由さは、仲間を味方にした後半での「カタルシス」になったこと
・サブキャラクターの描写量の少なさは、プレイヤーの意思で役割分担ができるロールプレイイングの余地
・シナリオや戦闘描写の多面的なアプローチで、ボリュームを抑えつつ作品世界を重層的に描くことに成功している

もし判断に困っている方がいらしたら、こういう見方をしたプレイヤーもいるということをお伝えしたいと思いました。

最後になりますが、やはり現代の感性で作られたゲームと比べたら、確かに色々と融通が利かなかったり不親切さを感じたり、時代遅れと感じる部分が多いのは確かです。そのようなユーザービリティはプレイヤーにとって非常に重要な要素だと思っていますが、一方で、これは持論ですが作品自体の面白さの本質というのはそういうものの他にあるんじゃないかなとも思います。面白さの本質というのは、究極的には作り手の一生懸命なものづくりの姿勢と、クリエイティビティによってつくられるものと私は思います。百英雄伝はクラフトマンシップに満ち溢れた作品だと思いますので、JRPGが好きな方には是非おすすめしたいとおもっています。

When I found out this had a kickstarter, I was absolutely thrilled and excited.  I played all the Suikoden's in my teens and really loved them all even after the Suikoden 3 was critically not well accepted.  I still enjoyed them.  
Suikoden 1 and 2 are my favorite games of all time even ahead of FF7 and 10.  

I have to say, this game was a MASSIVE LET DOWN.  The Suikoden stories were so rich with character development and storyline and everything had a place.  You had to definitely do some RNG stuff like gambling so you could upgrade your weapons and buy armor, but it felt purposeful.  The one on one duels were set for pivotal moments and the field battle took some strategy and really some forethought.  Even the culinary battles had a little more to reason than what we experienced in Eiyuden Chronicle.

This game just missed on everything important.  Story line; character development and a general sense of purpose.  It's got no soul I think is the best way to put it.  It WANTS to be Suikoden, but it just added all those components and just hoped it worked.  Not a great sign for the sequel they want to do UNLESS they spend the time to actually develop a cohesive storyline and give a damn about the characters.  I personally did not give a single shit about a single character and that's 50 hours commitment to get this knocked out.  The beigoma game is a slow and repetitive and mostly RNG.  The card game is fun so props to that.  The army fights were a joke and rarely did you have any actual control of what was happening unlike previous suikodens.  The duels were just there...no reason sense of purpose.

All in all, just a massive disappointment.  They missed what made Suikoden so good.  On the plus side, the maps were STUNNING to look at; A+++ on visuals.  The map design were needlessly huge for no reason for it to serve literally 0 purpose...just forces you to run more to get into more random fights.  Also, what's with the unnecessary talking for carrie on EVERY SINGLE TELEPORT.

Yeah, I think I am done.
The whole game is just so ... mid. I've got other, better games to play.

[h1]At last the spiritual successor to Suikoden is here[/h1]

[h2][u]Overview[/u][/h2]
 [i]Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes[/i] is a spiritual successor to one of my favorite RPG series of all time, [i]Suikoden[/i]. As such, it has a lot of expectations behind it and for the most part it played it safe with some very obvious homages to the [i]Suikoden[/i] games. This is a bit of a double edged sword, however. While they borrow some great tropes and story beats, I can’t help but feel like I’m just pointing at the game going “hey remember that from [i]Suikoden 2[/i]!?” and the constant comparisons sort of damper the game as its own thing. Especially because Eiyuden makes a lot of questionable decisions so when comparing it to [i]Suikoden[/i], it doesn’t always come out on top. That said, reality is there won’t ever be an actual [i]Suikoden[/i] sequel so this is the best we’ll get and it’s still a very enjoyable story and game worth playing for any fan of the original series.

[h2][u]Story[/u][/h2]
I honestly found the very start a bit slow. But after about an hour when it opens up and lets you start recruiting characters, I started to love the game. From then on, it only got better as political events that shape the world and story occur and so on. Like the [i]Suikoden[/i] series, the story revolves around a political conflict in which you play as an underdog faction of ragtag heroes that slowly builds up power over time through many recruits. Not all recruits are fighters either and some are cooks, librarians, etc and help manage your town. I think it’s neat to show the importance of everyone working together to keep the faction going and not just the generals fighting the wars (although certainly they get most of the screentime).  

Unfortunately, I do have to say while I enjoyed the overall story and the primary antagonist, it really falls short of the [i]Suikoden[/i] plots. It largely boils down to a severe lack of stakes. I never really felt in danger. Towns may get taken over and yet you can still just walk right in and recruit people. A town may get burned down and still there a few days later. Where are the actual consequences of the ongoing war?

Characters and side stories varied. Some had barely any story before joining while others had involved side quests. Overall, I think they’re cool and fun and the variety was nice.

[h2][u]Presentation[/u][/h2]
I don’t really care about voice acting but the game has it. I thought it was OK. I’m impatient and tend to read faster than they speak so it means nothing to me. I did like the music and the overall presentation of towns, characters, etc. It’s really fun to see so many stray cats roaming the towns too.

[h2][u]Gameplay[/u][/h2]
A majority of my frustrations with the game resides here. I enjoyed my time with it, but could not help but constantly feel there are a ton of Quality of Life (QoL) issues throughout the game that actively pissed me off. Only for some enjoyable moment to make me forgive the game again. Then get pissed off by something else again. I was constantly going back and forth.

I get that the game is purposely invoking old-school RPGs but that should never come at the cost of being an active detriment to enjoying the game. First, the game is a turn based battle system with a return to the 6-character party. I love that. I also like that you can shove story-required characters into the reserves and ignore them. What was frustrating is the changes to the battle system. First- the overall speed just feels so slow. In [i]Suikoden[/i], everyone would attack at once and the combat felt extremely snappy. In Eiyuden, it just feels so slow! Secondly, the beloved unite system seems horribly balanced or bugged where you’re better off just using two individual attacks than combined attacks most of the time. The combined attacks just do terrible damage and are not worth it. This sucks, half of the appeal of the unite system was to try out interesting combinations to pull off big damage as well as observe the fun animations. Thirdly – magic is strangely balanced. Early on, MP is difficult to recover outside of Inns and magic as a whole seemed underwhelming outside of healing. In the late game, magic finally takes off and is great to use (at least for the extremely OP Momo lol). I really miss the unique magic system of the [i]Suikoden[/i] series which had limited casts at each level. This allowed you to still use magic on trash mobs while conserving the big spells for bosses. With the MP system, mages are more likely to just spam normal attacks for all trash encounters in order to save everything for the big bosses. Just feels way less magical. Also no double beat rune????

For other QoL issues - inventory management is rough early game, lack of bulk selection for selling/appraising/weapon sharpening, etc. Just so many weird little choices.

Also hope you aren’t a completionist. The grind for that is painful (and still ongoing for me). Beyblade minigame was painful and everyone hates it. Ship racing game terrible controls.  Card game is actually fun but not “win 120 times” fun. The theatre is actually a wonderful side feature and I love it.

Duels and war systems were a major let down and each felt more like interactive cutscenes.

[h2][u]Specs[/u][/h2]
No issues.

Operating System: Windows 10
Processor (CPU): Intel Core i5-3570K CPU @3.40GHz
Graphics Card (GPU): NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1070
Memory (RAM) 16 GB

[h2][u]Summary[/u][/h2]
If you’re into headquarters building with recruiting tons of characters, you’ll probably enjoy this. There is also an interesting political storyline that’s more complicated than the typical “good vs evil” story of many turn based RPGs. It’s a great game, but definitely temper your expectations in comparison to the series it was based on. Keep in mind also that the game intentionally brings old school vibes and this means a return to save points and a useless auto-save that only works when you go to the world map (prepare to lose hours of progress if you rely only on the auto save). I promise though, it is a good time and a fun game if you’re able to look past the flaws and focus on the character collection and story.

你能接受當年JRPG的老舊(各種意義來說)風格的話 這款還蠻推薦的
劇情中規中矩，蒐集人物以及看著主城逐漸壯大過程很有趣

[b]Note to Suikoden fans[/b]: You can play this game without having played the prequel and still understand it. It’s really a matter of preference. Rising is a lighthearted, quest-a-thon, action JRPG. I would’ve liked if both games were Suikoden-like, but that’s because I like more serious stories and turn-based JRPG combat. A lot of people found the prequel’s battle system and gameplay fun, so if that appeals to you, then you should play the prequel. You can read [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Ceaseless_Duality/recommended/1658290]my review of Rising[/url] for more perspective. 

[u]Information[/u]
    • The Eiyuden Chronicle games are intended to be a spiritual successor to the Suikoden series. 
    • The battle system of Hundred Heroes is very much like Suikoden. Turn-based. Up to 6 party members in battle, two rows. Characters that have some kind of relationship can do combo attacks that are known as Hero Combos. Those with runes can do special, magical attacks or healing/buffs. Random enemy encounters. 
    • Difficulty settings: Normal Mode or Hard Mode. This game’s Normal Mode seems built more for experienced JRPG players.
    • Player can freely roam on the world map. 
    • Fast travel is unlocked after recruiting Carrie, a character who knows how to teleport. 
    • Gameplay involves War Battles and Duels, similar to Suikoden’s. 
    • The HQ is a large castle. Upon improving it, the player can add several shops and services after acquiring materials for building [i]and[/i] the correct character recruit to operate it. 
    • Fishing mini-game is simple. Player presses X (or its equivalent) when an exclamation point appears over Nowa’s head. 
    • Cook off mini-game involves choosing an appetizer, main course, and dessert for random recruited characters of the castle as judges. Getting to know what characters like is the key to winning. It also involves smashing X to fill a timed gauge. 
    • It’s too annoying to describe the card game in detail. Please just watch a video somewhere, if you’re interested in knowing about it. The player can build a better deck of cards to increase chances of winning.
    • The beigome (spinning top battles) mini-game is fairly simple. Collect better tops to increase chances of winning. Press X at the right time to do a good spin, then smash X when the tops battle.
    • There are two different racing mini-games. One involves breeding egg creatures to improve their stats, then they automatically race each other. The other racing mini-game involves manually guiding a sand ship in the desert.
    • Theater mini-game. The player casts characters for roles in various plays. If the acting is good, one can receive an S rank and a special item. If the acting is bad, it’s good for a laugh. 
    • The POV is highly focused on Nowa, only occasionally showing Seign or Marisa’s POV. (Thus, it isn’t like Suikoden III, which equally shared POV with three protagonists.)
    • Please be aware that [b]this game is intended to be played with a controller[/b]. My PS5 (DualSense) controller worked perfectly for it.

[u]Praises[/u]
    • Ten languages available for interface and subtitles (though, for some reason, Latin America Spanish isn’t available like it was in the prequel). 
    • The English voice acting was good. Some better than others, but overall, I was happy with it! I like the different accents. There is American (with variations), British (with variations), Scottish, Spanish, Australian, and a few I’m not sure about. Also, stereotypical pirate. (I don’t know if Japanese voice actors ever attempt other accents that aren’t just different Japanese accents.)
    • The story is much more interesting and serious than the prequel. It is also reminiscent of Suikoden story plots, as they always revolve around war. My favorite part of such stories is getting people to realize that the only people that ever benefit from war are the rich and powerful. 
    • Great character development of characters central to the story. Similar to the Suikoden games, this story shows that “enemies” in war are people just like anyone else and that many people can be changed by war. 
    • Decent humor. We can’t just have the doom and gloom of war; there are spots of humor all throughout the story. The duel between Nowa and El Alicanto is over-the-top and hilarious.
    • The music is good (again). They got Motoi Sakuraba!
    • The backgrounds are even more elaborate than the prequel’s were. I’m grateful that they allow the player to disable Depth of Field, because that blurry stuff messes with my head. 
    • The castle (Alliance HQ) is plenty big, with several improvements to be made over the course of the game. Nowa can decorate his room and the castle. 
    • [i]Unlike[/i] Suikoden, [i]nothing is missable[/i] in this game. (In Suikoden, it was super easy to f*ck up one’s file and have to start over again, because for a lot of recruits, there were small windows of opportunity to get them.)
    • One of my favorite mini-games in Suikoden was the theater plays. They did a fairly good job replicating the experience in HH. I find it addicting to see all the different outcomes.
    • Femboy character unapologetically wears feminine clothing and aspires to be [i]the cutest[/i].  
    • An achievement for talking to animals. Lots of cats, dogs, and other cute creatures can be found roaming around each town. :3
    • A capybara humanoid character runs the hot springs. THAT IS SO F*CKING CUTE!

[u]Complaints[/u]
    • Pressing [i]any[/i] key on the keyboard skips the cinematic intro to the game, so I was unable to get screenshots of it. 
    • While recruiting Douglas, it’s really unnecessary to make the player get “fresh” iron ore. He asks for 10 iron ore and even if Nowa currently has it in his inventory bag, Douglas won’t take it. You have to get it after talking to him. 
    • The sand ship racing mini-game is terrible. The track boundaries aren’t visible. The only guidance the player has is to go for these blue orbs that boost speed, but if you hit a boundary it forces you to [i]slowly[/i] turn around; sometimes, in the [i]wrong[/i] direction. 
    • Some theater plays don’t have voice acting.
    • The game doesn’t autosave frequently enough. Lost an hour’s worth of progress, because during all that time, there was no autosaving. 
    • Teases possible romance between Nowa and [spoiler]Perrielle[/spoiler], but nothing comes of it. [i]Boring.[/i]
    • What few romantic pairings or confessions there are, they’re all heterosexual. 
    • Tokenism. Are there dark-skinned people? Yes, [i]but[/i] there are 120+ characters and only a handful are dark-skinned. Are they as important or have the same amount of power? No. While Marisa is a main character, she is not on the same level as Nowa or even Seign. This is a marginal improvement from Rising, which had no dark-skinned characters at all. 
    • Overpriced, cash-grab DLC content. Story segments as DLC, which is the ultimate offense for a JRPG. Story-related stuff should always be included in the game. Could be the greed of the publisher though. 
    • Several typos. Mainly, the names of cats and dogs. Were these backer names, and people were derps, and didn’t capitalize their names? Pfft, I would’ve capitalized them for the game anyway. 

I’ve missed the Suikoden games for years. I played and completed the main five games in chronological order of the series’ story (for funsies), back-to-back, in 2011. (Never got a chance to play Suikoden Tactics.) Konami has abandoned the series after the DS game Suikoden Tierkreis didn’t sell particularly well. (I haven’t played that game either.) Thus, I am [i]delighted[/i] to say that this game filled some of that void. It might not be as good as what it aspires to be, but it was a damn good attempt. I highly recommend it to Suikoden fans and JRPG fans who still like turn-based combat.

Insgesamt ist das Spieltempo sehr sehr langsam, sodass ich nach einer Weile einen Trainer verwendet habe um das Tempo auf x2 zu setzen. Ebenfalls nervig sind die Skripte für das Theater ... diese gibt es nur als seltene Funde in den Itemshops (mir fehlten am Ende 2). 

Alles in Allem wenn die oben benannten Bugs behoben werden und vielleicht Ingame ein Turbomodus eingebaut wird, würde ich das Spiel 100% empfehlen. Aktuell nur 80% für Hardcore Suikoden-Fans

Ratings: 
Story - 6.5/10.0 ( Quite generic except some parts, there's too many similar competition in the market. )
Music - 6.5/10.0 ( Had a few good music pieces but overall forgettable. )
Art - 10.0/10.0 ( They went all in with the artstyle & animation. )
Gameplay - 7.0/10.0 ( Minor design flaws in combat gameplay here & there, Mini-games and base building add some points but could be improved as well. )
Voice Acting: 10.0/10.0 ( Perfection, for the Japanese voices.)
Translations: 4.0/10.0 (It's kind of bad for the English subtitles. Just glad that my Japanese listening comprehension skills are pretty good.)
Pricing - 10.0/10.0 ( Worth every dollar spent if you're not rushing the game from start to end. Take your time to do side stuff, level characters & experience the game as it is. ) 
Overall - 8.5/10.0 ( It's rare to have an almost complete game at launch these days without bugs. So I'm rounding the points from 7.7/10.0 to an 8.5/10.0 score. But still, comparing to Suikoden 1, 2 & even 5, they're considered to be more well polished games.)

[b]幻想水滸伝2.5[/b]
本作は幻想水滸伝シリーズの主要スタッフが開発した精神的後継作ということもあり、あらゆる面で幻想水滸伝（特に2作目）が意識されています。
100人以上の仲間、ドット絵キャラ、仲間を集めて強大な敵に立ち向かうシナリオ、6人PTのコマンドバトル、発展できる本拠地、多彩なミニゲーム等々…。
それでいてグラフィックは今風になり（2D-HDみたいな感じ）、イベントはフルボイスと、まさに現代にアップデートされた幻想水滸伝と言える作品に仕上がっています。
特にボイスはかなり力が入っており、あらゆる場面で喋りまくるのは本当にすごいです。
全体的に「こういうのがやりたかったんだよ」と思えるものになっており幻想水滸伝ファンは懐かしい気持ちになることでしょう。
誰が呼んだか幻想水滸伝2.5。

[b]不満点も多い[/b]
前述のように素晴らしい点は多いものの、不満点も多いです。
アクセサリーがないとダッシュもできなかったり、アイテムの所持制限がキツかったり、キャラ性能格差がひどかったり…。
昔のRPGをそこまで再現しなくてもという気持ちになる部分が多々あり、幻想水滸伝未プレイの方にはオススメしづらいです。

それでも90年代のJRPG（特に幻想水滸伝）好きには刺さると思うのでそういった方にはオススメです。

計100点。

To preface the Suikoden series, especially 2, is my favorite series of all time. While i had high hopes for this successor series, i was also skeptical if they could truly recreate the magic that the original series had. I can say with confidence to all Suikoden fans out there that this game delivers. It's not without its flaws, has any Suikoden game were really, but i think with some tweaking they may have gold with this new iteration. I'll start with the pro's. 

The very first thing i really began to notice about the game was how close to Suikoden 2 this game feels. There are some similar story beats, etc. but its a feel thing that's kinda hard to describe. It's almost like playing an alternate version of that game. The finale imo might be one of the most epic in a Suikoden or semi Suikoden world I've experienced. The mini games are hit and miss granted but the card game was descent and im a huge fan of the cooking battles so it was nice to see that expanded upon even if it was only slightly. The game looks amazing and it's what i imagine Suikoden could've become in an alternate timeline. Colorful cast of characters maybe a few too many repeats of the same archtype, but all in all there are some characters here that caught my interest more so than over half the Suikoden library. This game is a nostalgia trip back to the good ole 90's rpg days and they really nailed the feel of this game and the whimsy of the world. 

Now for the cons. I understand this is not a Suikoden game and by that standard maybe this criticism is unjust, but one thing that series i feel always did pretty well was overall pacing of the game and its story beats relative to you having time to recruit, cook, race, etc. This first iteration of Eiyuden imo struggles heavily with pacing. It feels has though it starts to tell a fairly compelling story and then all of a sudden youre at the end of the game. In fact i could've beaten the game without ever having fully upgraded my castle due to how late in the game you get to upgrade the castle. While i think things like max level weapons etc., should be time gated relative to story, it sucks that you have to go out of your way and slow your progression in the game to grind out materials for an upgrade and you're already at the end of the game anyways. The only other big criticism i would have for the game would be how little field battles were used and the lack of challenge presented by them. One of my favorite things about say Suikoden 2 was that you could spend half an hour managing your units and then another hour if you wanted to in the actual tactical battle. You could be precise or be lazy about it and still win, but just having the depth to it that it had really made those moments shine. In Eiyuden these moments don't scratch the same itch and lack the depth of the Suikoden series. There are small QOL things that need fixing such has long wait times for upgrades, etc. It's nothing Suikoden fans haven't dealt with for ages and overall there are some improvements. 

This is a love letter to the previous series that for fans will absolutely scratch that nostalgia itch. It did for me. 8/10
If you liked Suikoden you'll likely enjoy this as well.  Closest any game has come to recapturing that feel in my opinion.  Certainly not perfect, but very fun.

This game is awesome! It scratches that itch for an old turn based jrpg perfectly. Not too grindy. Plenty of options for play styles. And side content....so much side content! After having been burned by way to many early access and big budget games its refreshing to see someone create a game that really feels like they get what the player is after. It is reminiscent of old final fantasy without feeling like a direct rip off.

Only gripe (and trust me its a silly one) is when you beat the game they list literally everyone. Every contributor and backer. Which on the one hand is great, thanking the community that helped support such an awesome game, but on the other you can only set it to three times speed and it takes a while to get through the thousands of names haha. So yeah not really a complaint, more a caution for when you beat the game.
