Ich habe mich auf das Spiel richtig gefreut als es auf Kickstarter angekündigt wurde weil ich Suikoden I und II viele Male durchgespielt habe. Umso enttäuschter war ich dann als das Spiel nicht ansatzweise halten konnte was es versprach. Die Story ist unglaublich generisch und lieblos. Einige Wendungen kommen plötzlich und sind absolut unglaubwürdig. Das man zum Beispiel zum Anführer der Stadtwache wird und später dann der Anführer des Widerstands. Es kommt zu schnell und ist total lieblos geschrieben.

Auch kommt der Eindruck auf das viele der Charaktere sehr farblos und generisch gestaltet sind. Man kann jetzt argumentieren das auch bei Suikoden I und II einige Charaktere blass waren. Das stimmt aber hier ist es die breite Masse und sogar einige der Hauptcharaktere. Das ist ziemlich traurig weil ich das Spiel wirklich mögen wollte. 

Das Kampfsystem ist so wie man es sich von Suikoden erwarten würde. Es ist ganz in Ordnung. Das Magiesystem ist etwas komisch. Es skaliert recht schlecht. Die Anfangsmagie ist teilweise ziemlich schwach sodass es kaum einen Unterschied macht ob man die Autoattacken nutzt oder Magie.

Ich habe dann irgendwann nach dem Angriff auf die Burg das Interesse am Spiel verloren. Was ziemlich viel aussagt weil ich eigentlich die Spiele die ich anfange auch zu Ende bringe.

Mich reizen die DLC Ankündigungen überhaupt nicht weil ich gar nichts mit den besagten Charakteren verbinde.

Ich kann das Spiel bei dem Preis-/Leistungsverhältnis wirklich nicht empfehlen.

Ich hoffe das Konami seinen Arsch hochkriegt und endlich Suikoden I und II released.

[h1] Wasted Potential [/h1]

[h2] Summary: [/h2]
Straight to the point, this game has some good aspects like good town/battle music and SOME good characters with interesting personalities/motives/background, but the [b] amount of bad game-design decisions [/b] is what brings the whole experience down and makes this game hard to recommend in its current state, so unless you are willing to put-up with the list of negatives that I have mentioned below, then don't bother getting this game and maybe wait for a sequel with better gameplay (assuming the developers take all the community criticism into consideration for the sequel).

[h2] Negatives: [/h2]
1) [b] Selecting all characters moves at the start of the turn [/b] rather than "one at a time" as each character's turn is up, which ruins strategizing and leads to bad targeting if the targeted enemy dies too early or conversely deals too much damage to the party.

2) [b] Leveling-up and save points doesn't heal party characters, [/b] which is such a bother and forcing you to heal constantly throughout the game by carrying 10 million healing items or going back to HQ to heal.

3) [b] Can't save anywhere or whenever I want directly from the menu, [/b] which again is such a bother as it forces you to "keep going" until you either find a save point or abandon the current dungeon you are in and go back to HQ to save.

4) [b] Can't see enemy health [/b] (an outdated stupid omission that needs to stop from some JRPGs that continue this trend) as well as [b] not being able to see what my characters are targeting after selecting a move but BEFORE confirming all moves [/b] to initiate the turn (so many times I had to cancel and re-select moves for all 6 characters because I forgot what each character was going to do for the turn). This problem would have been already resolved if problem number 1 above was corrected.

5) [b] Switching party members is SUCH A CHORE [/b] and it would have been WAY EASIER if ALL recruited characters were considered "attendant characters" that can be switched in-out at ANYTIME and NOT being forced to do so by speaking to a "certain character" each time you want to do a basic thing (which is a trend throughout this game unfortunately).

6) [b] Being forced to go back-and-forth between town/dungeon over and over and OVER again to save, change party, equip runes, heal for free and so on. [/b]

7) [b] Magic is UNDERWHELMING in this game and MP restoration is such a TEDIOUS TASK to deal with throughout the game. [/b] (Relied on "physical attackers" for majority of the game to be honest)

8) [b] Most Enemies have A LOT OF HP and deal A LOT OF DAMAGE even when your characters are properly leveled-up [/b] and with how BAD the HP/MP healing works in this game, you can see how all this leads to an unpleasant experience overall.

9) Even worse, [b] running away from battles is CHANCE-BASED [/b] (except when you are extremely highly leveled), so most of the time you are going to try to escape, FAIL, and then take A LOT OF FREE DAMAGE from all opposing enemies until the turn ends and EVEN if you manage to run away the 2nd time, now you have to HEAL AGAIN either through items or going back to HQ for the 10 millionth time (absolute STUPIDITY and unnecessary punishment for the player).

10) [b] Can't upgrade or unlock new rune slots, [/b] meaning that SO MANY characters (particularly early ones) become USELESS later on because they can't equip higher level runes or can't equip as much runes as later recruitable characters.

11) [b] No log text history [/b] to view past conversations with different characters.

12) The [b] 1 vs. 1 [/b] battles are BORING and feel RANDOM/ANNOYING to complete. Also, other modes like [b]  "War Mode" are such a TEDIOUS CHORE to deal with [/b] and NOT the "standard turn-based" JRPG that I want to experience (really wish that "War Mode" was a [b] skippable cutscene [/b] that I can skip and move on from to the next proper standard turn-based battle that I bought this game for).

[h2] "Short Version" Solution to ALL These Negatives: [/h2]
Learn from [b] The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel quadrilogy, [/b] which is THE [b] GREATEST JRPG FRANCHISE [/b] that I have ever played and has already solved ALL of these problems that I have with Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes.

[h2] "Long Version" Solution to ALL These Negatives: [/h2]
1) Selecting moves should be done "one at a time" once each character's turn is up.

2) Leveling-up or interacting with a save point should AUTOMATICALLY fully heal the HP/MP of all party members.

3) Saving should be accessible AT ALL POINTS from the main menu.

4) ALL enemies HP (regular or bosses) should be visible at all times.

5) Even if only 6 party members are allowed to battle, remaining recruited characters should be switchable/accessible AT ALL TIMES from the main menu and NOT being forced to talk to a certain character back in HQ to do so.

6) Equipping runes should OBVIOUSLY be accessible AT ALL TIMES (just like equipping armor).

7) Magic attacks needs a MAJOR BUFF in this game to be of any use and MP restoration should be made easier outside of only using MP items (using other commands like guarding/physical attacks that don't require MP should allow some MP recovery automatically for that particular turn).

8) Enemies HP/damage output needs to be re-balanced on Normal difficulty.

9) Running away SHOULD WORK 100% OF THE TIME (like in "Monster Hunter Stories 2" for example) OR you should be able to completely TURN-OFF field encounters (like in "Bravely Default" for example).

10) All 8 Rune slots should be unlockable/upgradable for ALL CHARACTERS as the story progresses.

11) Have a log text history button (like in "The Legend of Heroes" OR "Fire Emblem Engage") to view past conversations at any time.

12) REMOVE "1 vs. 1" boss battles and make them standard "1 strong boss vs 6 party members" and also make "War Mode" OPTIONAL/SKIPPABLE for those who don't like it and don't want to be forced to play that mode.

[h2] Closing Thoughts: [/h2]

In the end, while I do think that this game has some positives worthy of praise, the sheer amount of negatives is just too much to ignore, so my hope is that this "harsh" review sends a message to the developers that future entries in this franchise NEED to be better in many aspects and maybe then, the Eiyuden Chronicle franchise will become a worthwhile recommendation from me.


[b] Final Rating: 6/10. [/b]
Juego muy de nicho, enfocado al JRPG clásico. Es cierto que la traducción es un desastre, y tiene varios bugs, pero fuera de esto es un título muy disfrutón.

Dopo 80 ore di gioco su Steam Deck, mi sento di dire che il gioco ha molti aspetti, purtroppo nessuno di essi curato in modo a mio parere sufficiente.

- La trama: non c'è bisogno di dire che in un GDR la trama sia un aspetto fondamentale. Molto lineare, a tratti scontata e prevedibile, il team non ha voluto osare in alcun modo su questo punto: l'impero ha mire espansionistiche e l'eroe di turno assembla un manipolo di coraggiosi pronti ad aiutarlo per evitare il peggio. 

- Il roster dei personaggi: Nel gioco ci sono tantissimi personaggi, ma solo pochi di loro (i principali e qualche comprimario) ricevono davvero attenzione, mentre gli altri si riducono a mere macchiette con una sola sfaccettatura di personalità; il metodo di reclutamento della maggior parte personaggi si riduce, nel migliore dei casi, al portare loro un oggetto chiave, mentre altri ad "Ehi, mi sembri una persona affidabile. Ti va di unirti a noi?" dopo aver soddisfatto alcuni prerequisiti (come un certo livello, altri personaggi già arruolati etc.). Soltanto alcuni personaggi hanno vere e proprie missioni per essere assoldati che danno loro profondità, per poi purtroppo essere gettati nel dimenticatoio una volta completate tali storie. Certo, esiste un modo per sbloccare le storie dei personaggi (rigorosamente in forma di blocchi di testo da leggere), ma questo non mi ha fatto affezionare di più a nessuno di loro. Decisamente troppa carne al fuoco rispetto a quanta se ne possa gestire. 

- Personalizzazione: a livello di personalizzazione nel gameplay, ogni personaggio ha una "lente runica" che gli conferisce (a seconda del personaggio, e non modificabile) da 4 a 8 slot per inserire delle rune. Alcuni di questi Slot saranno permanentemente occupati con abilità personali, mentre altri avranno una "forma", che consentirà di inserire un determinati tipi di rune: potenziamenti passivi quali bonus a statistiche e resistenze ad alterazioni di stato, bonus passivi in base a determinati condizioni (primi turni di combattimento o quantità di SP rimanenti) o accesso a determinati tipi e livelli di magie. Riguardo a questo punto arriva la delusione: molti dei personaggi si rivelano decisamente poco ottimizzati (se non addirittura inutili) rispetto a ciò che dovrebbero fare. Un piccolo esempio: un personaggio con valore basso di attacco fisico ed elevato di attacco magico possiede un attacco base fisico e deve utilizzare molte magie per infliggere danni; un altro personaggio, a parità di valori, può contare su un attacco base magico, che gli permette di rimanere efficiente senza consumare MP, potendoli utilizzare quando realmente necessario. A peggiorare la situazione ci si mette il fatto che il primo conta 4 slot rune, mentre il secondo ne può utilizzare ben 7. Da dire anche che molti personaggi non possiedono abilità proprie, dovendo fare affidamento su quelle ottenute tramite le rune, ammesso che abbiano slot in cui poter inserire tali abilità. Ulteriore pecca di questo sistema è il fatto che abilità e magie assegnate non interagiscono in alcun modo tra loro, né sullo stesso personaggio né tra personaggi diversi. 

- Il sistema di combattimento: il più classico dei sistemi a turni senza alcun guizzo di innovazione, in ogni round di battaglia ogni partecipante effettuerà un'azione (o più azioni nel caso di alcuni boss), con ordine dipendente dal parametro di rapidità. Purtroppo però siamo ben lontani dai fasti del sistema: le opzioni in combattimento si dividono tra magie che consumano MP, non ricaricabili, e abilità che consumano SP, di cui se ne recupera uno per turno. Ciò significa che le magie saranno utilizzate con il contagocce e soprattutto in modo curativo, mentre le abilità saranno utilizzate ogni volta che ciò sia possibile. A peggiorare il tutto ci si mette l'estrema semplicità dei combattimenti (almeno a difficoltà normale), che si riducono a mettere in formazione i personaggi che picchiano più forte ed attaccare gli avversari nell'ordine esatto per non fargli effettuare neanche un'azione: sono sempre bastati due attacchi (a volte uno se il personaggio è forte e ben ottimizzato) per eliminare un avversario. Inoltre, determinate combinazioni di personaggi danno accesso alle "combo eroe", azioni per cui più personaggi utilizzano la propria azione per effettuare un attacco speciale combinato. Purtroppo, selezionando il semplice comando "attacca" si infliggeranno più danni anche rispetto alle combo a bersaglio singolo.

- Le battaglie campali: anche qui un sistema che sa di raffazzonato e non sufficiente: si dovranno disporre le proprie truppe in griglie quadrate 5x5, muoverle avanti ogni turno (o aspettare che siano le truppe avversarie ad avvicinarsi), e limitarsi ad aspettare quando queste combattono tra loro.

- La parte gestionale: ad un certo punto del gioco saremo chiamati a fondare e sviluppare una città con l'aiuto dei personaggi reclutati e tramite la spesa di materiali, che permetteranno di sbloccare farming automatico di materiali e baqua (denaro), mercanti, bonus passivi e alcuni minigiochi. Sistema molto classico, ma si avrà bisogno di alcuni oggetti rari dei negozi che può essere frustrante ottenere.

- I minigiochi: tanti, troppi, e decisamente poco curati: la maggior parte di loro si riducono a premere il pulsante A quando richiesto o a premerlo ripetutamente per un certo periodo di tempo.

- I negozi: di norma non ci dovrebbe essere nulla di male nei negozi. Il problema dei negozi delle varie città è che essi avranno una probabilità variabile tra il 5 ed il 20% di vendere oggetti rari (con nome blu e segnati da una stella) ogni volta che si apre il menu del negozio. Questo è vincolato ad un timer di 30 minuti, dopo i quali sarà possibile effettuare un nuovo tentativo di far apparire l'oggetto.

- Grafica: Gli sprite 2D dei personaggi e le loro animazioni sono ben fatti e curati; le ambientazioni 3D, al contrario, non sembrano essere andate molto avanti rispetto ai primi anni 2000.

- Quality of life: decisamente poche funzioni per il 2024: non esiste alcun modo di accelerare il combattimento; lo spazio nella borsa è limitato, ed ogni volta che si otterranno oggetti al termine di una battaglia ci sarà la scelta su cosa scartare, senza possibilità di inviare nulla al magazzino o di utilizzare oggetti curativi per fare spazio sul momento senza sprecare nulla; la formazione di battaglia si può cambiare solo alle locande, e cambiare equipaggiamento e rune equipaggiate sarà un fardello notevole ogni volta che vorremo cambiare personaggi, senza contare il fatto che si potrà fare esclusivamente nella città fondata dal personaggio; il potenziamento delle armi richiede un'animazione di circa 5 secondi dal fabbro, moltiplicato per 15 livelli di potenziamento delle armi e per oltre 50 personaggi se si vuole potenziare tutto; menzione onorevole per il teletrasporto: si ottiene relativamente presto nel gioco (dopo circa 15 ore), ma per la fine del gioco stesso si avrà l'incondizionata voglia di mettere le mani al collo del personaggio che dà questa funzione, in quanto ad ogni utilizzo si avranno due linee di dialogo (una alla "partenza" ed una all'"arrivo") che, sebbene all'inizio siano anche simpatiche, dopo le trentesima volta iniziano a diventare irritanti.

Ho aiutato a finanziare questo gioco su kickstarter (al costo di 4000 yen, circa 23 euro) e non mi pento di averlo fatto. Tuttavia, non posso esimermi dal rimarcare quanto, per il prezzo base di 50 euro (più 25 per i DLC), questo gioco non sia assolutamente sufficiente sotto nessun punto di vista: basti guardare il relativamente recente Chained Echoes, che con un budget Kickstarter di soli 130.000 euro riesce a portare un'eccellenza del genere sotto molteplici punti di vista; qui al contrario con un budget di quasi 3 milioni posso dire che l'esperienza lascia l'amaro in bocca per ciò che sarebbe potuta essere, e che purtroppo si può ridurre alle parole "occasione sprecata".

Overall pretty good! I wouldn't drop $50 unless you're a Suikoden 1 and 2 fan. Sticks to pretty simple Gameplay of turn taking JRPG, 0 brain cell war battles, and pretty forgivable rock-paper dueling systems.

at first its like, 'yay suikoden, finally'.  after a while, "idk meh".

let's see, this review is clocked at about 31 hours and I've been playing on hard mode.  And its not the localization that bothers me - I'm actually not sure why so many people whine about it.  I mean its nothing to write home about, but its not that bad.

For me, I generally play jrpgs for the battles.  And I think this is what's buggin me.  For one, there are some weird balacing issues in the game.  For example, more than once I'll just mow down every enemy left and right only to get to the boss who's somehow a giant pain in the ass - hard mode seems to give the bosses tons of hp and the battle more or less ends up being how many potions I brought with me.  Literally every game I've ever played with intense boss difficult spikes like that just turn me off.  And the way the experience works, you won't be able to level up or really go buy some better armor, its just - well, the boss is gonna hit me like this, in this really static pattern, so I better just buy a bunch of potions, yawn.

And, speaking of buying potions - you get very little mp and everything costs a lot of mp.  So maybe I'll get a small handful of magic heals if i don't use magic to attack at all and then I'll once again, have to dive into my pile of items (which you are limited in how many you can carry, mind you).  You basically can't use magic, or maybe this is the one jrpg that eludes me as to how I'm supposed to use magic in battles.  "0h great, i casted a magic attack on a regular enemy, now i have 3 heals left and have to use potions on the boss or run my butt out of the dungeon and go buy some more"

If you don't turn off magic use in the auto battle settings, you'll basically burn 100% of your magic on the first couple groups of enemies.  If you do turn it off, you might get lucky enough to heal a couple times or attack a couple times on a boss.  Tons of fun - you can't even experiment cause you're just always out of mp.

there's an sp system that recharges as you fight - but its kinda boring.  Most characters have one or two moves (maybe they get more, but i'm 30 hours in and most characters have one or two moves).  When you only have one move, the pattern is always like: regular attacks until you have sp, use the move, rinse and repeat (and use potions since you don't have any mp ever).  There's just no room to really do anything at all.  Blame it on hard mode?  maybe, or maybe its just kinda boring after a while.

the 'war battles' are just, what's the point??  like i played all the suikoden games - the wars were super fun, you felt like you had some agency and got to do some stuff.  In this game, it feels like you're just wasting 20 minutes until the game decides to move on with the script.  Like you don't have to win, you don't have to survive, you just play a couple rounds of this slow battle with little to no strategy, and then you have to watch some more cut scenes.  like why?  why not just watch the cut scene since playing the battle has no point and you can't really lose.

i got to the part where I had my base and could collect characters.  I started to enjoy it but that's mixed with some story on rails segments with the other main character (the red guy is the freeform one moving about the world and collecting characters and the blue guy has some stuff where you're locked into a specific place and dungeons and whatever).  basically, i did some plot event with the red guy and then the game was like "okay now you should play the blue guy and catch up the story" - but when it put me as the blue guy, i'm just stuck in this dungeon without enough resources and a low level where i don't get any xp from the monsters or very much money, so I think I've spent a few hours grinding enemies in a dungeon to just,  like "kill a few guys, get money, spend 10 minutes running back to the only town i have access too, load up on potions, run 10 minutes back in, rinse repeat".  I mean its just total ugh - my heroes are clearly under powered for this area i'm stuck in, but i can't get xp and i can't level them up in the over world where the red guy is and yea - this isn't a challenge so much as its just GRIND.  It wouldn't be so bad if I could use magic or if the inn's weren't 3~ battles worth of money (the inns will be like 1800 gold or whatever and you'll get <1000 per fight).  So its just, GRIND GRIND GRIND GRIND where I get no xp, no money, and have to constantly run back and forth to slowly inch my resources up enough to beat the boss of the dungeon.  Is this hard, or is it just annoying.

I wanted to like this game, I really did.  But the balancing issues are all over the place and you never know if its gonna be pointlessly easy or just some ridiculous grind for no reason.

ugh, and this drives me crazy, but there's HELLA lag when flipping through the menus.  You go to the menu screen and you have to use the shoulder buttons to get to the equipment or items or whatever, and it like, takes FOREVER.  its just a dumb menu, just GO to the next page, right now, don't make me wait, just GO.

anyways, I think i'm giving up on this one, or maybe i'll try again if they update it and address the balancing issues.  But  yea, just not feeling it.  they say this is a game for jrpg fans, but I feel like they missed what's good in the classic jrpgs that inspired this game.

There's some kickstarter drivel that I can't stand.  Animals are named for no reason, they're people's pets.  

Beside a main story quest NPC, there's a painting of some "Brandon" guy wearing clearly modern clothes.  Immersion-shattering.

When people face sideways, their body is turned 45 degrees away from the camera, but their head is turned 90 degrees.  All standing poses are like this, ALL of them.  Even most WALKING poses are like this.  It's weird, off-putting, and ugly.  

MC's weapons are bizzare.  Two hooked staves?  And his starting skill has him spazzing out like a schitzo.  

Some healer joins your party and spent every post-combat shouting like a maniac, then "whoops, teehee, excuse me" or whatever.  It was almost funny exactly one time, and then made me roll my eyes when it happened after the next fight, and the next, and the next...

I just can't enjoy whatever the hell this is.  Suikoden 1&2 were masterpieces.  Even _four_ was better than this.  This is trash.

To preface: I never grew up with Suikoden, the series this is a spiritual successor of. If anything is a standard carryover from that series, I wouldn't know.
TL;DR: The combat won't blow you away and mechanics and other such things are rarely explained well enough in-game but the story is definitely worth playing the game for, in my opinion.

Anyway, it's really solid in a lot of aspects. Stuff like the music and the story is great and the battles, while not the most engaging a lot of the time, is still good enough to keep me interested all the way through. There's a lot of side content like a card game, notBeyblade, two types of racing minigames, and a theatre but most of it felt, to me, more like an afterthought than something they planned on adding from the get go. 
 The Beyblades are easily the worst among these. You can choose where to start during the start but that never seemed to matter, and the Beyblades have elements and stats that [i]also[/i] didn't seem to matter if you just made sure to use the same "rarity" as your opponent. 
 The theatre was great though because all the characters you recruit have voice acting for most of it (I noticed one or two didn't, for some reason) so you can make some really funny setups in that.

 But the meat of it all: the combat. I must say that it felt really basic. Practically none of the physical characters I actually used could equip the skills I kept finding so I had to make do with basic attacks for most of them and the magic felt very underwhelming, enough so to make me only use the water spells for the entire game as that's where you will find the party heal that doesn't scale with the magic stat and instead just does 40% on everyone. 
 I played on the harder difficulty and never felt I had to actively engage in the rune equip system, nor did I ever level grind as I despise doing it.

There were a handful of times where I felt explanations from the game were lacking. I actually read tutorials but take the Beyblades for example: 5 stats, they probably do stuff, but what? The game never says more than "keep in mind the stats". 
 Or take the secondary battle mode you do a couple times throughout the story. Apparently if you addign someone to only have cavalry, they will have more movement. Only reason I knew that? The boss of the second-to-last one does that against you.
 So be prepared to look some stuff up as the game surely won't tell you, even though it has a help section in the menu.

整體來說，喜歡幻水的朋友玩起來會很有當年的感覺吧，遊戲一開始比較有些刻意進度緩慢，包含走路速度被刻意弄慢，中期有特殊支援夥伴可以讓隊伍加快速度，以及有瞬間移動的夥伴之後，整體玩起來就比較好一點，大部分時間主要是在找夥伴，以及建設根據地，相輔相成，雖然有些人或覺得作業感重，但其實慢下心來玩還算不錯的。戰鬥的平衡有時候得習慣一下，敵人打我們的數值和我們使用魔法的消耗值都較高，絕大多數還是靠物理。小遊戲部分尚可，劇情部分平鋪直敘，但能夠聽到許多聲優的表現，還是很讓人高興。

《百英雄传》是一款众筹开发的JRPG游戏，它的正式版已于2024年4月20日发布。从理性上来说，它不值得JRPG爱好者们这么多年来的等待，因为它存在难以置信的陈腐和过时的问题，几乎占据着游戏的所有流程。但从感性上来说，《百英雄传》又显得无比珍贵，对那些正在（或已经）步入中年的“幻想水浒传”粉丝而言，它的确是一款无比珍贵的游戏，就连那些足以劝退新生代玩家的致命缺陷，也更像是对精神前作的全盘致敬。
  《百英雄传》有着《歧路旅人》在前，很多朋友习惯性地将游戏中“2D角色”加“3D场景”的表现形式统称为“HD-2D”，却忘了“HD-2D”最大的优势并不是简单的“立体光照”或“粒子特效”，而是促成玩家完成“臆想”的表现方式——在更多时候，我们看到其实是“过程”而并非“结果”，就像画面中的两个角色随便碰撞了两下，玩家就能在脑海中生成一场激烈的交锋那样。
  角色都相当精致，光影效果也很出色，比如在微弱的光亮下，路边水池会呈现出微微的反光，潮湿的地面能将篝火的影像反映在石砖上。此外，游戏中的各种场景运用也相当到位，比如城镇充满生气，城楼前人来人往，马厩里的马还会摇尾巴，这些细节都让游戏世界更加真实生动。同时，游戏针对不同场景精心设计的音乐，也为玩家带来了更强的沉浸感。
  在游戏机制方面，《百英雄传》是一部以回合制 RPG 为主的作品，玩家控制由六名角色构成的小队，战斗前后可以更换参战角色，每个角色都有不同的属性值和技能，让他们能够有别于其他角色。 例如「莲」是高攻低防的战士；而「加尔」则是坚实的肉盾，他的攻击力也不错，但不能使用魔法。玩家在构建队伍时需要权衡这样的优缺点，《百英雄传》的可选角色有一百多个，他们可以与你并肩作战，或者在你的基地中承担某种职责。这有点像士兵版宝可梦，但如果你想达成全收集，每个角色都有不同的加入条件。 有些可能是一对话就加入，有些让你在变强之后再来找他们。
   总的来说，《百英雄传》是一款非常有特色的 RPG 游戏，它的剧情、角色、战斗系统和画面都有着独特的魅力。但它依然值得一玩。如果你喜欢 RPG 游戏，并且对复古的画面风格和回合制战斗系统感兴趣，那么《百英雄传》可能是你的不二之选。

Haven't gotten as far in the game as most of the reviews, but what I've played has been pretty fun. I don't think I've met a character yet that I've disliked, and I think I've found around 30 of them so far. There are definitely some characters that are better in battle than others, but I don't think there's any that can't find some sort of niche. It's easy to get comfortable with a given team, and I don't think this game means to do that. The rune system is pretty interesting, but I'm not sure how long it'll last. Every team I've been on has a Water rune somewhere in it, and some of the non-magic, non-locked runes don't seem like they're doing much. 

My biggest gripe with the game is the controls. Everything feels intuitive, and I believe this game was built with game controllers in mind. However, it's got the tiniest dead zone recognition. After I finish moving a joystick, there's a decent chance your lead character will just move off in a seemingly random direction until you flick the joystick just right to get it to stop dead center. I haven't had this issue with other games I play on controller. Hopefully they add a bit more support for controller dead zones in a future update.

Overall it's good. Nice cast of characters and some of that old-school JRPG charm (whether you love or hate it). Can't universally recommend it, but if it sounds like it's up your alley then go for it.

I backed this during the kickstarter campaign and was hoping for something similar to Suikoden 2 but definitely did not get that.

It's pretty pathetic, honestly. I would've been happy with a fishing mini-game similar to Stardew Valley or anything else....not just pushing a single button and you instantly catch it. 

Recruiting feels very shallow - with only a very few characters that need certain requirements to be met for recruiting. I did not find any compelling stories with any of these recruit-able characters. Combat can mostly be won with just using Auto battle. Magic is pretty useless and doing combos with your different character combinations is also not very needed. Sad.

All in all, it could use another 2 - 3 years of development for more polish and to find its soul. In its current state, it feels very lifeless and generic. Again, the best I can describe it is, it just does not have a soul.

Overall, would not recommend, especially at $50....

No, it's not going to live up to best of the Suikoden franchise (Suikoden 2), but it's certainly as good or better than some of the lesser entries (Suikoden IV). If you are a fan of those games, or old JRPGs in general, you'll probably find this one worth your time. It gives a really good taste of what a modern Suikoden [i]could be[/i].

The story is good, though sometimes a bit unmemorable, and there are a lot of likable characters. The voice acting is fantastic (seriously, kudos to the voice actors) even though the dialogue itself often goes on a little longer than it needs to. The artwork is beautiful, and the battle mechanics are what you would expect, with some quality of life improvements over the games of old (such as a configurable auto battle system for when you're just fighting through trash mobs). 

So, sure, maybe not game of the year material, but I'd definitely buy and play a sequel.

It's a great homage to Suikoden, with a bit of a Trails of Cold Steel feel. I've heard a sequel is in the works, which is great news!

The big draw is there are over 100 recruitable characters to join your battle party, or fill jobs at your growing HQ. Ultimately, it is a JRPG with a war plot, so there are also strategic battles with characters controlling units.

The dialogue is fun, and makes the characters seem unique. Don't let the "bad localization" people convince you it's trash, it's just not as direct of a translation as some would have wanted.

A very solid start spoiled by a horribly drawn-out endgame. Overall not a terribly unique game in the sea of great JRPGs we have access to, but I would still recommend it to anyone looking specifically for a Suikoden-like.

[b]Total Playtime[/b] - 55 hours
[b]Character Art & Animations[/b] - Fantastic. 10/10.
[b]Environment Art[/b] - Good
[b]Voice Acting (English)[/b] - Overall very good, though the script is often lacking.
[b]Story[/b] - Decent JRPG story. Nothing gamechanging, and does drag quite a lot.
[b]Core Gameplay[/b] - Basic JRPG, doesn't add anything to the genre.
[b]Difficulty[/b] - Easy. Rarely do you ever have to worry about element/type advantage in combat. Money starts pouring in after a few chapters and you can buy an infinite stock of the highest tier healing items.
[b]Minigames[/b] - Mixed bag, pulled down primarily by a severe lack of user input or skill required. Card game is incredibly easy but at least there's user input. Spinning top minigame is terrible in every way. Racing minigame is at least cute, but takes too long to resolve. War minigame takes [i]so long[/i] and doesn't require any skill.

The first 10 hours of my playthrough were [i][b]fantastic[/b][/i]. The game has all the classic charm of a Suikoden-like: you recruit the people, you get the town/castle, you upgrade the buildings, etc. The plot started out interesting enough to keep engaged, though it is your basic "bad guy empire" story.
The next 20 hours of the playthrough were [i][b]fine[/b][/i]. Recruit more and more unique NPCs, upgrade more and more facilities at the base, unlock more and more areas as the story progresses. A decent loop of plot->explore->upgrade->plot that kept me engaged.
The final 25 hours of the playthrough were [i][b]abysmal[/b][/i]. Aside from a few comedic interactions between some of the more lovable recruited NPCs, the final half of my playthrough felt both rushed and drawn out. There's a 50/50 chance that each next plot point will either thrust you into a 2 hour block of dialog (maybe broken up with a war minigame, which is just dialog with animations) or a dungeon that takes 2 hours to complete because it's a series of long, long, [i]long[/i] hallways with a thousand random encounters.

Following the legacy of a series that had decades of work poured into nearly a dozen games and spinoffs is no easy task.  This game seeks to fill a void left behind by a long running fantasy world that has been abandoned by the owners.

At the start of playing Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes I enjoyed playing a game of spot the comparisons.  The tropes, story beats, character archetypes, every similarity between it and the early Suikoden games I could.  There are plenty to be found, and as I played I was wondering if the game would actually stand on its own.

By the end of the game, I feel like I've come to appreciate the world more as its own.  I'm spending less time focusing on the similarities between the series whose legacy has come to a sad end, and more thinking of the legacy that might be started.

I really hope in another decade we can looking at the Eiyuden Chronicle series as one that grows just as vast and intriguing as its predecessor was.  That what we've delved into so far is just a small piece of a bigger world ready to expand wherever the imagination can take it.

If you want a game that has a bevy of the qualities the early Suikoden games offered, I wholeheartedly recommend this for you, and I truly hope Rabbit & Bear Studios continues to explore the world they've introduced us to in the future.

It's hard not to compare Eiyuden Chronicles: Hundred Heroes to the games in the Suikoden series, considering it is the clear spiritual successor. Therefore, I won't attempt to describe the game entirely on its own; instead, I will draw direct comparisons so that fans of the Suikoden series, who are likely the target audience, can understand exactly what to expect from Eiyuden.

Let's start with the story:
The three main characters are likable heroes with reasonable but mostly unexciting motives. The story itself lacks the depth and plot twists that characterize the Suikoden series. In the end, the plot falls significantly short of the standard set by Suikoden. The antagonist is a prop compared to Luca Blight (Suikoden 2), and yes, that's a high mark to compete with, but it falls SO short here.

Collecting all the characters has always been something that glues the games together; it’s entertaining and never too much of a hassle. However, here some characters are tied to these awful minigames, requiring several hours just to unlock a couple of characters. I like the characters for the most part, but by comparison, they’re not as fleshed out and some just seem awfully silly.

The war/army battles have always been a weak point in the Suikoden games, but here they’re worse than ever. I’m not even sure what my strategy is; I’m just glad I’m winning every time, as slow as it is to watch the battles play out.

The combat is also unbalanced. Battles where some of your characters will take 1 damage and another will take 150 from the same attack happen all the time. You’ll be forced to take along a new character, and they’ll have 160 HP max and they’ll be taken out with one hit. 
There’s hardly any reason to ever use the hero combo attacks; definitely not enough to strategize party layout for them. They look great and a few are useful in certain situations, but outside of boss fights, they’re often not applicable or simply weaker than the alternatives. The same goes for most rune attacks. At a certain point, I started giving most characters water runes just to ensure there was always enough healing available. Actual simplification of battles through the use of runes is virtually nonexistent.
The critique about fights is more of a quibble; it’s a serviceable JRPG there. But again, not at the level of greatness seen in Suikoden 1/2.

In my opinion, the graphics are simply good. The 2.5D visuals look great, and the scenery is beautiful. Characters, artwork, effects, and locations leave nothing to be desired and create a wonderful atmosphere.

The music is also a major highlight. While the often somewhat shrill (and thus iconic) music in the Suikoden games could sometimes annoy me personally, I can openly say that I actually listen to the music from Eiyuden privately for relaxation. The dialogues are wonderfully presented. The voice acting in this game is spot-on perfect.

To sum it up: Eiyuden is the continuation of a game series we never expected to get. In the end, it is a good JRPG with notable shortcomings. I give the game a 7.5/10 rating.

As a fan of the Suikoden series, I was really hoping this game would deliver the spirit of the older games to the modern era. It succeeds, with all the positives and negatives that were part of the original series. There are some annoying QOL updates they can make to the gameplay to make it more modern, but overall it was a fun experience. I really hope there will be another as I like the world. I would like to say it's very much Suikoden 1.5, it doesn't reach the pinnacle which was Suikoden 2, but it's still pretty damn good.

PS. I do recommend downloading the better translation mod in Nexus for this game.

First of all, please add a fast forward to the end credits. I know you wanna show love to the backers and I admire that but that credit was longer than any credits I've ever seen.

Now then, on to the game. This was billed as a Suikoden spiritual successor and it certainly lived up to the name. A wide array of goofy mini-games that brought levity to the main story of the game. 

The mini-games were hit and miss. For me personally, mostly it was a miss but I did appreciate them. The card game and "beigoma" were probably the best of the lot and they are relatively simple. Actually, the card game I found to be quite engaging and if developed a bit more, I felt it could challenge many of the top JRPG card mini-games out there. Baku-I mean, beigoma was not bad either, although it really came down to match ups for the most part - the rest was either button timing and mashing.

As for the other mini-games...I did not care for cooking, I did not even see the need to add the button mashing mechanic. A rhythm game style mechanic would have been better, or nothing at all. The challenge was getting everyone's favorite meals memorized. But I will say the story of the cooking plot was actually really amusing. I also wish the character that is unlocked from that game was slightly better (she's good but worth the time spent on that mini-game? Not a chance). I probably spent more time on that mini-game than anything else. I disliked this mini-game a lot but today I choose to focus on its positive aspect which was the plot.

Fishing is generic and I won't comment on it. I confess, I did not try the racing mini-game. It looked fairly deep but by the 60th hour I only really cared about finishing the story. You may refer to another review for that aspect.

Alright, that covers mini-games. So for me, that just leaves plot. so I will add mild SPOILERS WARNINGS. 

I want to make this clear, I did not expect a sophisticated story. But I'm gonna be honest. The main character, Nowa, is not all that interesting. If anything, Seign would have made a better lead because he seemed to have more backstory than Nowa. There is more interesting internal conflicts with Seign, as opposed to Nowa who was a victim of the empire and rose up from humble beginnings. Usually, I actually love that basic archetype but in this case, it was just not built up all that well. Even though time passes (after the first mission) and the player can guess that he rises up the ranks of the watch, optically, it felt like Perri just foisted command onto him with very, very little credit.

If anything, Garr or Sabine would have been great commanders! Sabine was criminally underused. She is a veteran of the Watch and she even rightfully questions Nowa in the beginning.

I know the budget was not like a big company budget, so the team didn't have time to really...flesh out that aspect of the story telling, but the transition from lowly new comer to commander of the resistance was jarring to me as someone who cares about the story being told, even if its one told a thousand times before. I would have focused on that rise up more, add in a mission taking mechanic to the game, or something. Sure it would have been a little repetitive but it could have also prepared players for other game play mechanics later on like dueling, or war, or even your mini-games. Also, you could have introduced your cast this way as well before being able to recruit them. I will talk about this later.

I will add this line singularly because I feel like it summarizes most of the review. You guys had a lot of great ideas! But they did not harmonize.

The recruiting felt very shallow. Now, I played Suikoden 5 and its one of my all time favorite games. Why? Because everything that unfolded later on was set up so beautifully in the beginning. We were introduced to characters they joined the cause via the story. Now, its a 100+ characters and they all can't have significance, I understand. But the characters that needed shine didn't get much. 

I want to talk about what I felt was one of your best ideas that was not used that much. And it was when you gave the side story missions to Seign and Marisa. I'll be honest, THIS should have been the focus of the game. This was your BEST idea. The fact that we only got two quests like this almost makes me want to rip my hair out, if I had any left.

Why was this the biggest missed opportunity? Because you could have done this with any character of mild importance and fleshed out the world of the game more. Again, I know, limited budget - but imagine this. Think of how Game of Thrones had various perspectives and such that made the world more and more complex the more view points were added. You could have done that with this. Added a perspective for Sabine and Perrielle when they escaped Eltisweiss and perhaps could have met other characters on that journey.

You could have had a perspective for Hurstwine during his escape. This is not limited to heroes, I legit believe Hurstwine could have turned if the story was written so. Or maybe a perspective of Elektra and Maxim on the run. A Garoo, CJ and Isha perspective would have killed it honestly - I loved those three. Leene on her random adventures meeting people before we got the chance to recruit them. There were a lot of ways this could have been utilized but we only got one for Seign and one for Marisa. If you want to a good case study of a game doing this well, Final Fantasy 9.

I really liked Marisa too. I don't have much bad things to say about her. I just wish I got more of her story that we could play through and not told to us. Like the history of her and Nil.

Again, I know, small budget - but please consider this for a future game. Or anyone with the ambition to create games, this would have been a wonderful evolution to the Suikoden franchise.

Now that I am tired of typing, I will add closing thoughts. The game is worth the time but there were just a lot of missed opportunity involving the plot that is frustrating. The story is not sophisticated (which is not a bad thing), but I wish we got more narrative driven stuff. Also, I felt like being allowed to pop back up into conquered towns was immersion breaking. I know you don't want to have missable early recruits but this could have been handled better. But I'm a person who cares about story and immersion so this mattered to me and maybe not so much to someone else.

Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes to me is a solid 7/10 coming from a fan of Suikoden and Radiata Stories and the like. I feel like this is a generous score for a low budget game. I appreciate the hard work from the team and I hope your future projects continue to improve. I wish you all the best in the future endeavors and personal lives.

Mediocre jrpg, onestamente. Sono un veterano del genere e non capisco come questo gioco possa andarvi bene perché ha dei problemi critici. Storia piatta e noiosa, personaggi privi di mordente e su 120 personaggi saranno caratterizzati solo tre! Combat system che alla lunga non diversifica i personaggi, ma le rune sono tutte uguali e cambiano solo dei personaggi le loro skills uniche, boh. Alcuni di essi, hanno delle discrete side quest per poterli reclutare, ma il resto è cercare un ago in un pagliaio e non appena lo trovi ti chiedono di fare una ricetta, sconfiggerli, o portare items, e una volta reclutati non hanno alcun valore aggiunto alla storia. Se devo recarmi da un npc veggente, che si recluta anch'esso, per poter approfondire la lore dei personaggi non ci siamo proprio! Minigame carini (tra cui il castle building che ho apprezzato tanto!), forse l'unica cosa che si salva.
Continuerò a giocarlo perché ormai mi manca poco per finire la storia, ma arranco perché è monotona fino allo sfinimento. È un peccato, perché il gioco agli inizi era proprio coinvolgente poi appena si apre al mondo la narrazione corale svanisce, lasciando spazio alla collezione senza senso dei personaggi.
Collezione, tra l'altro, inutile: alla lunga si utilizzeranno sempre i soliti pg perché gli altri sono deboli (no, ditemi, che senso ha reclutare Leon spadaccino mago e poi nonostante abbia un'estetica bellissima non si può usare perché è un trash pg in battaglia, boh!) o non ha senso fare team building perché le strategie alternative non ripagano, soprattutto in modalità difficile.
Ma veramente qualcuno ha il coraggio e l'ardire di paragonarlo a Suikoden? Siete seri? Posate il fiasco e smettetela di seguire youtuber che per quanto si profilano esperti del genere hanno sempre dietro il tornaconto professionale per vendervi dei giochi sui loro canali. E sono il primo ad esserci cascato.

This game really could have used more time in the oven. I tried to complete this game since I backed it on Kickstarter...but I just had to put it down right at the end. 

The main component of this game is tracking down every recruitable hero and never actually use them and just leave them in your town like the pokemon-people they are. This is thankfully the most fun part of the game. Most heroes don't take much effort to recruit so you can get a serotonin boost pretty easily. Some recruits will unlock extra dungeons and features, which is where the mechanic really shines.

The story is pretty decent. No big surprises or anything. It felt like a couple of moments were just thrown in there so they could add a few more recruits to the roster. 

Combat is not fantastic. There is customizability with runes, but most battles up until the end can be easily won with auto. Auto also makes battles go 5 times faster which is super helpful getting through trash mobs.

The polish just didn't seem to be here on this game. Dialogue boxes appear before and after fast travel, which can be annoying, mechanics aren't always properly explained, hero hints show up before they can actually be recruited, the mini games don't require much skill but can still be a pain.

I love Suikoden a lot, and I wanted to love this game but I don't. It has a host of issues Suikoden had and they should have been easily able to avoid had they played any of them. It does also have a lot of problems of its own... Most of the cast has terrible stats. Rune slots are a mess (70% of the cast are bottlenecked by inability to use higher level runes or lacking any kind of variety in the kind they can equip) with maybe 15% or less having any signature abilities to set them apart which is not helped by the sub par damage on combo/hero attacks. Difficulty doesn't exist even on hard things are just spongy and the strategies (if you want to call rinse repeat attacking and healing strategy) remain exactly the same. The writing is particularly dull. Having spent over 70 hours playing I can remember only a few lines Nowa said in the entire game that got a chuckle out of me while most of it is mashworthy and consists of them discussing or flashing back to something that happened moments ago because none of the characters have any other fleshed out connection that what we see the vast majority of the time. Add an easily missable character, a handful of poorly fleshed out and fairly unfun minigames, and I can tell you that while this game is modeled after Suikoden the closest it gets other than the coat of paint is in mimicking some of the things Suikoden got wrong. Dragon's Dogma 2 was the biggest let down of the year by far but this was a slow agonizing burn, because with all that it is this should be better.

Not a perfect successor, but still a solid spiritual successor to Suikoden. The minigames can be annoying and janky, and too much is gated behind them. But it's still good enough to be considered in the same vein as its inspirations.

DISCLAIMER: I backed this game during the first week it went live on Kickstarter, so I am heavily invested in it's success. I am also a HUGE Suikoden fan.

Let's get this out of the way, the English localization is absolute garbage, and the people who worked on that localization should never be trusted with another IP set in a fantasy world ever again. I set my expectations for the localization low, but I still found myself being disappointed by how many liberties the localizers took (there are times when the JP audio will say one thing, and the English text will say another).

Pros:
- The game genuinely feels like a spiritual successor to the Suikoden franchise, especially GS2.
- The 2.5D art style is endearing and very reminiscent of GS1 and 2.
- The music is great.
- The Japanese voice acting is fairly good.
- Lots of mini-games to do, should you get tired of collecting characters or progressing through the story

Cons:
- The English localization is so bad that it ruins immersion and takes you out of the experience
- The cooking mini-game's scoring system is weird, even after the recent patch to fix it.
- The boat racing mini-game is so bad that they just let you progress through the story if you fail enough times. The person whom designed the controls for this mini-game should never be trusted with designing vehicle controls ever again.
- Both duels and skirmishes are basically on rails. Choosing to play defensively is useless and will often times make you lose, so mindlessly pressing on with attacks is the only real way to go.
- You can feel the outdated design of the game right away. From not being able to save anywhere to having to juggle bag space, it can get pretty annoying if you've already gotten used to the modern QOL improvements that have become industry standard in recent times.

I recommend this game for die-hard Suikoden fans, and only die-hard Suikoden fans.

Side note: My original backer copy was for the Switch, but because it's basically unplayable on that console I asked 505 to send me a Steam code instead. It took them a week to get back to me, and by the time they'd given me the code, I had already bought the game here on Steam and was progressing through Hishan.

TL;DR Combat systems are confusing but the game is well worth your time and money, especially if you miss the Suikoden games.

For those looking for more of what Suikoden once offered, I recommend trying Eiyuden Chronicle but this comes with some pretty big caveats.

Firstly, if you were a fan of Suikoden, you'll feel immediately at home here. As it comes from several of the original creators, you likely won't be surprised that they nailed the feeling of building up a base, recruiting people from across the world, and getting to know all your many, many companions. The political storyline may be somewhat simple but it is still engrossing and the characters drive things forward, even when the overall plot may feel cliche to long-time fans.

Eiyuden Chronicle is also just a gorgeous game. The environments are varied and well detailed with the pixel art character sprites just bursting with characterization. Each recruitable character feels so distinct, an impressive accomplishment considering there are 120 of them and they ride on the back of a franchise with literally hundreds of characters in its time. The music is lively, although a bit more variety in the battle music would have been appreciated. What's there is solid but over the long runtime of the game, you may get sick of the one battle theme for all basic battles. I was already mindlessly humming it to myself after only a couple of hours.

The adherence to what came before is also Eiyuden Chronicle's biggest detriment too though. There are many quality of life improvements to the game, such as allowing plot-required characters to accompany you as non-combatants so you can use the fighting party you like rather than one required of you, but many things that were arguably problems have not been changed. Just like the Suikoden games, Eiyuden Chronicle comes with an extremely long prologue that leads up to the content most people came for. Looking forward to free recruitment and castle building? Expect it to take at least 10 hours to get there.

The primary problem though is the battle systems and how poorly explained (and possibly balanced) they all are. Your standard battles are similar to most JRPGs but you have 6 characters, more than in most games but standard in Suikoden. Battles are turn-based affairs where you choose all of your character's moves at the beginning of each turn and then the full turn plays out based on a visible turn order at the top of the screen. In the early game, characters don't really get any abilities beyond their basic attack, a defensive ability, and a special attack that doesn't feel very special early on. In the first 10 hours, I only had 1 party member that could reasonably use magic spells but the extremely small MP pool meant that after only about 8 heals, she was tapped out until I went back to stay at an inn. Remember you have 6 characters in battle so 8 heals means barely more than 1 healing spell per person and even at this point, 1 basic healing spell didn't even cover half of their HP.

Even later on, magic isn't a reliable option in the fairly long dungeons and boss battles the game throws at you. The 2nd dungeon of the game has 5 save locations spread out across its large maps and the boss battle took my average leveled party over half an hour to beat it. Needless to say, my mage was spent barely 3 rounds into the boss battle and I had to rely on items for the rest of it.

Perhaps the game simply requires more preparation or strategy than I was employing but that's where the obtuseness of the games' systems comes in. Despite having a dedicated Help section of the menu, Eiyuden Chronicle explains almost nothing about its many integrated systems. Each character comes with 8 stats and not once are these stats ever explained. Most are fairly obvious (Power = Physical damage, Magic = magic damage) but some, like Dexterity, could have many different possibilities, such as accuracy, dodge rate, damage with long range weapons, etc. In fact, some of the stats that seem obvious actually aren't as obvious as you may think. Above, I mentioned that Magic relates to your magic damage. You would reasonably assume this means that it impacts the damage caused by magic spells but that's actually wrong. From what the community has determined, spells don't scale with your level. Instead, this stat only has an effect on characters who have an elemental affinity as their basic attack. Things like this should be explained somewhere in the game but it just isn't and it's left to trial and error to figure out what the different systems mean.

On the other hand, some of the Help articles can make the system even more confusing. Early on, you're told that each character has magical affinities so give characters runes that fit their affinity. Not only are you given this information long before you're likely even able to change out anyone's runes, but you aren't ever actually told what any characters' affinity even is. In fact, affinities are hidden so you have to just experiment with different rune configurations for each character to figure these out. This feels so needlessly complicated when they could have just told you up front.

Lastly regarding the main battle system, the balance seems to pendulum wildly in a number of ways. With your 6-person party, you can put 3 characters in the front row and 3 in the back. Each character has a stated range so make sure your close range party members are up front and the long range characters are in the back. Seems simple, right? Unfortunately, the vast majority of characters are mid-range characters and can go anywhere. This may seem freeing but it means that new players who are still learning those hidden stats won't have any training wheels to learn where different characters ought to go.

Still, most will likely assume that your tankiest characters should go up front while the squishy ranged fighters and mages should go in the back so they don't get hit. This is how most games handle things but Eiyuden Chronicle has nearly every enemy able to hit the front or back row as often as they'd like. In every dungeon I've played, my front line fighters are typically fine while my back row rangers die frequently. It would be one thing if the game threw curveballs like this occasionally but this seems to happen everywhere. In fact, one of the most common enemy attacks has the enemy charge through your column, hitting your front and back fighter equally.

The TL;DR with all of this is that the standard combat system seems to assume you have extensive knowledge of JRPGs but also it assumes that you just know about the various nuances unique to its system that it never wants to tell you.

The War and One-On-One systems aren't much better. The only War tutorial you get is how to move units and that stronger units will beat weaker units. How can you tell who's stronger or weaker? I suppose you just guess? One-On-One seems to be a rock-paper-scissors match similar to the Suikoden games except I would find myself taking damage even when I was correctly guessing the opponent's moves. I'd counter his attack and only my health would drop so I'm not confident I understand that system either.

I realize this has been something of a deep dive in the nuance of these systems and it may sound like I'm bashing on the game but I really do recommend it. While my lack of understanding of the systems was frustrating, I was still able to regularly progress through the game and building up your base/recruiting characters is just as much fun as it has ever been. It's unlikely that Suikoden is ever coming back but Eiyuden Chronicle is picking up the mantle and running with it. I simply hope that in a possible sequel, a little more care is shown to these various systems and players are given the information they actually need in order to not feel like they're simply progressing based on luck.

C'est globalement un très bon jrpg, mais y'a quand même quelques points pas terrible. 
Pour le positif : c'est graphiquement magnifique ( le mélange 2d/3d fonctionne bien), les Ost sont très bien, le système de combat est efficace et relativement varié, le bestiaire est conséquent et la durée de vie du titre est plus que correcte. Le côté "collection de héros" fonctionne bien, on a envie de les avoirs tous.
En point négatif :
 Tous les mini-jeux sont ratés : trop simple ou répétitif, basé sur le grind et sur l'aléatoire, (par exemple une des dernières pièces de théâtre n'a que 5% chance d'apparaître dans une boutique spécifique. Il faut recharger en boucle ou attendre 30 min de jeu supplémentaire pour retenter sa chance).
 Le système de batailles, ainsi que celui de duels , sont beaucoup trop scriptés et sans grand intérêt ( alors que c'était toujours un moment bien cool dans d'autres titres, comme Suikoden 2). 
Le scénario est bien trop gentillet, je ne demande pas un drame horrible et gore, mais un peu de maturité dans l'écriture . Reprenons encore l'exemple de Suikoden 2 parce que j'ai l'impression que le projet cherche à lui rendre hommage :  c'était certes un Jrpg, mais il parlait de l'horreur de jeunes gens confrontés à la guerre, dont les rêves s'affrontent.
 Il y avait des morts innocents, un fond d'intrigue politique avec des rebondissements ,un premier ennemi marquant et cruel ( le prince Lucas), qui nous donnais du fil à retordre et qui finissait par mourir au terme d'une grande bataille, criblés de flêches. A 12 ans, ça m'avait marqué.  
Là,  l'histoire est toute lisse, presque naïve: personne ne meurt malgré la guerre ( ou alors on nous le dit dans une ligne de dialogue insipide), le scénario suit des rails, aucune surprise, et l'événement le plus marquant est l'incendie d'un village, sans aucune victime, et reconstruit moins d'un chapitre plus tard. Bref, pas top la qualité d'écriture. La fin du jeu est également complètement raté à mon sens, on laisse bien trop de choses en suspens.
En résumé, j'ai pas passé un mauvais moment, le jeu à d'indéniables qualités et à une esthétique qui raviront les nostalgiques, le gameplay est efficace, mais on bien loin de la qualité des anciens jrpg sur l'écriture et les activités annexe n'ont que peu d'intérêt . Si je devais mettre une note, ça serait 16/20.

One word sums up my experience with this game.

Disappointing.

Positives :

- Looks great (blends old school and new quite well)
- Good music
- GREAT Japanese voice acting
- Very humorous at the start of the adventure (first 10 or so hours) that slowly fades away but still occasionally made me laugh
- Recruiting 120 characters was a great challenge and I found it to be enjoyable 

Negatives:

- The story and the characters and the overall feel of the game. It was a huge let down. 
- The 120 characters are fun to acquire - but not to actually play. The overwhelming majority of them are totally useless. I used the same 10 characters or so for 99% of the game. I even spent time building up EVERYONE and yeah - most of them suck.
- A lot of systems and mini games are not fully fleshed out. They end up being cumbersome.
- Almost NO quality of life features. I wanted a fast forward/skip button SO BAD. Some aspects were painfully slow.
- Lots of useless dialog. Childish and pointless the majority of the time. I eventually stopped caring what the cast had the say. That's never a good sign in an RPG.
- Strange disconnects with the story.
- Poor inventory system. 
- Illusion of a great battle system and options - seems good at first until you get deeper into it. The magic system was quite lame.

TL/DR

I appreciate the ambition and goals they had in mind when they set out to make this but the end result wasn't up to par. 

Buy it on sale if you're itching for Suikoden of old.

This game isn't perfect. In fact, there are several issues, and, if you're paying attention, it becomes painfully clear when they started running out of time and money. This was developed through Kickstarter promising a spiritual successor to a series of games that are revered and near-mythical. Many are upset because, in several respects, this failed to reach those heights.

But speaking as someone who plays roughly 50-100 JRPGs in a year: This is something special and it's most definitely worth your time.

I'll get my two biggest complaints out of the way right off: 
The game is rated E for everyone, meaning a lot of the darker and more intense elements are completely offscreen. This feels rather inappropriate, and provides something of a tonal dissonance.
Additionally, the modern disdain for "missable content" had so impacted the development that there is a near-comical lack of consequences for various story developments, further undermining the tone and the sense that the world politics are a big deal in the grand scheme of things.

Both these decisions are somewhat reasonable in the goal of reaching a broad audience, but they do somewhat cheapen the final product.

Additionally, tying in to the previous comments of budget and time constraints, there are several design elements which feel poorly calibrated. Not enough to ruin the experience, but enough to elicit a sigh of regret.

All the complaints out of the way, what makes it good, even special?

The visuals speak for themselves, as the designers have accomplished a pleasing blend of hand-drawn pixel art characters on rendered backgrounds.

I consider myself a poor judge of music quality, but this is a rare game where I chose to play unmuted, granted that this was in no small part due to an excellent case of voice actors. And the voice acting is definitely a place where you can clearly see a dedicated budget, as nearly every interaction beyond conversing with random NPCs is fully voiced, to include "peanut gallery comments" from party members otherwise uninvolved in the event.

Character customisation is a generally pleasing blend of limited freedom with enough restrictions to give each character their own distinct identity. A particularly nice touch is the unique skills held by some characters, as well as "union attacks" performed by characters who have some special relationship. Even when such skills aren't especially useful, they serve to convey a lot of personality, to the point where you begin to love and care for a significant portion of your loads and loads of characters.

Which brings up the roster. You recruit over 100 special people to contribute in your effort, be they farmers, merchants, or soldiers. Around 80 of them can serve some sort of combat role, as well. Not all fighters are created equally, but the game is generous enough that you can probably have a viable team by choosing the folks you like the most (no one likes a game where you have 100 options, but 95 are unusable).

You gather people to your side. You build a town. Your people spend down time together, playing card games or discussing beard grooming. It's a wonderfully cozy environment where you won't think twice about spending hours making your most socially awkward friends perform a train wreck of "Romeo and Juliet".

It's not the best game I've ever played, or even the best game I've played this year. But I can guarantee that it's one I'll remember for a long time, and likely revisit.

L'histoire est classique et je n'ai rien à lui reprocher mais je n'ai pas de raison de l'encenser non plus, je l'oublierai quasi complètement dans quelques mois. 

Le gameplay est du tour par tour (presque) classique (on donne tous nos ordres au début de chaque tour au lieu de les donner au fur et à mesure). La possibilité de faire les combats en automatique est plus que bienvenue et en dehors de certains combats de boss, quasiment tous les combats peuvent se faire en automatique. 

J'ai rassemblé les 120 héros recrutables mais j'ai détesté que certains de ces héros nécessitent de participer à des mini-jeux pour pouvoir les recruter. Surtout les deux liés au beigoma (combat de toupies) qui est une horreur.

La traduction française est juste passable à cause des nombreuses coquilles qui restent (des espaces manquants, des textes qui sortent des bulles de dialogues à cause de trop nombreux retours à la ligne). Et elle est basée sur la traduction anglaise qui n'a pas été très respectueuse à certains moments. Lors des dialogues, parfois les personnages haussent le ton et cela se traduit à l'écran par une bulle de dialogue qui tremble pendant plusieurs très longues secondes rendant complètement illisible le texte de la bulle jusqu'à ce cette trop longue animation se termine.

J'ai aussi eu deux bugs que j'ai trouvé assez gênant. Le premier est arrivé 2 fois, une cinématique/scène se bloque tout simplement et on est forcé de la passer. Le gros problème que j'ai eu, c'est que la seconde cinématique, c'étais celle de fin... Et en parlant de fin, le second bug a été pendant le combat final. Le combat est coupé par des courtes scènes mais j'ai eu droit à des scènes buggées, non seulement elles se sont répétées en boucles 4 ou 5 fois mais en plus, les animations ne se déclenchaient que partiellement: j'avais le son, je voyais les personnages bouger mais les effets des sorts ne s'affichaient pas... J'ai vu le boss de fin mourir 5 fois sans les effets de lumières avant de passer à la cinématique bloquée, ça faisait répétition de théâtre sans les accessoires. Autant vous dire que j'ai eu du mal a apprécié le combat final ainsi que la fin du jeu en général.

Pour donner une conclusion, je dirai que c'est un jeu moyen malheureusement tiré vers le bas par un manque de finitions. Je ne recommanderai donc pas l'achat du jeu au prix plein, il a un peu trop de petits détails irritants pour cela.

I want to preface this by saying that like many players, I'm also a Suikoden alum so I did come into this game with certain Expectations and preconceptions. But I've tried to write this review with as objective a view as possible. 


The good: 
- In as far as traditional JRPGs go, this is a very solid addition. So if you're looking for a JRPG fix that's not a remake and are tired of digging through RPGmaker-based games or giving in to KEMCO... this is a good way to go. 

- This is a fairly pretty game. I won't go so far as to say it's perfect or gorgeous, but it has some moments where you look at your screen and think 'that's beautiful'... provided you disable the subpar depth perception setting. 

- The soundtrack has some absolute bangers, especially the main theme.

- I won't say the story is particularly complex, but sometimes the characters display unexpected depth considering we're dealing with such a large cast of characters (120+ just on our side alone!). 

- Speaking of which, 120+ characters, fully voiced? That is a huge addition to a kickstarter game. Huge. Even if you complain about the quality of the voice acting, the fact that it's available in two languages is a remarkable investment. 

- The rune slot system has a lot of potential. I think there's room for improvement, but I think it's a good system in general.

- I for one enjoy the optional auto-battle system. It's not as in-depth as say... FFXII's gambit system, but it does the job for the most part. Compared to Suikoden's original basic 'everyone just does their regular attack' auto-battle, this gives you some control over the party's actions and with some tweaks, you can breeze through most random battles just fine.

- Most of the gimmick battles are interesting, I just wish we had more outside of the boss fights.


The bad:
- Despite the fact that this game is a spiritual successor to an existing franchise and the team working on it were experienced in the genre, this game feels very much a proof of concept. I feel like it shouldn't be. We've had five similar games to show us what did or didn't work, and yet Eiyuden doesn't seem to have taken any of those lessons to heart so it feels... raw and half-baked in ways that it shouldn't.

- The UI is trash. There I said it. I think this is symptomatic of a lot of games these days that attempt simultaneous cross-platform releases, but in particular when a handheld system like the Switch is involved. The idea that 'we have to design this with a potentially smaller screen in mind' has resulted in horribly nested layouts and ugly mobile game-esque menus. And yet... ironically, there's also a weird amount of unnecessary info being given to us. My eye is frequently swimming through irrelevant info when trying to make the simplest of choices. 

- There's a curious lack of documentation in many aspects of the game. Whenever you encounter a new feature or mini-game, you get a perfunctory 2-3 short page explanation which... honestly only barely explains what the heck is going on. Equipment and combat-wise, most items and abilities are described in unquantifiable terms. Something 'boosts your counter rate significantly', a spell 'causes minor elemental damage'. You can't really tell how much is much actually significant, in fact, you're not even sure if the item is working at all so you don't know if you're wasting your accessory slot. 

- The game could do with many QoL additions that are already available in many newer RPGs or remakes of older RPGs. Among which are battle and movement speed options, auto-run, a more reliable quick-save. More efficient management of my huge cast of characters would also be appreciated. Trying to buy equipment for your party from the HQ armory is... An Experience. 

- While the towns are pretty and the dungeons are pretty interesting with some puzzles, the winding spaces and generally slow-paced traversal speed of your main character (you either have to equip an accessory or add a certain character to your party to get a bearable movement speed) make wandering around an exercise in extreme patience. In addition to that, there's a ton of wasted exploration potential because the only things you can pick up or interact with are only puzzle-related, treasure chests, or shiny resource points, most of which are immediately visible on the field, more on this point later. 

- There are mini-games, most of them aren't anything to write home about. Even the ones that are sort of fun begin to outstay their welcome before they can become remotely rewarding. I'm pretty sure I could write a thesis on everything I would've liked to improve about the game and most of it would be about the mini-games.

- One of the key features in the Suikoden games are the 1v1 duels and the big war strategy battles. These are included in Eiyuden as well but... a lot of effort has been put into making these as cinematic as possible, especially the 1v1 duels. But the price for doing so is that gameplay wise, we can barely tell what's working and what's not. The big war strategy battles were sort of fun, but one of its key features is that there's an ongoing 'stream' of faceless NPCs (made up of Backer names) dying the whole time, so you can't really see what's really important like actual impactful things going on during the battle. It again circles back to my complaint that there's a lot of information being given to you, but very little of it is helpful or explained meaningfully. 


The ugly:
- So many bugs. So. Many. Bugs. Most of the game-breaking ones have been patched by now, but it puts a bad taste in your mouth when you realise how many there were on release despite beta testing. 

- So many things in this game are reliant on RNG that it becomes tiring. There are characters and accessories you can equip to mitigate some of the pain of being reliant on random item drops from battles, but there are other times when I think to myself 'these items could've just as easily been found slotted into a bookcase in the environment, or hidden in this corridor that apparently has absolutely nothing in it, and just exists to make you waste 30 seconds hugging the walls to find... nothing. 

- With the exception of story-relevant characters, most of your recruits don't feel like they live in the world. With few exceptions, only the characters who are immediately recruitable (maybe with some minor requirement that's easily achieved) are visible on the field. Most of the others don't seem to exist until you can. This forces you to backtrack through towns repeatedly 'just in case' someone new appears. That's not only detrimental to engagement, but just plain disrespectul of the player's time. A recruitable character later provides a service to provide 'hints' of potential new recruits, but this doesn't change the fact that the world doesn't feel 'lived in', or that the people in your army really have a stake in what you're fighting for.

- If I'm to be perfectly honest, you'll get a lot of playtime out of this game if you just want to mess around with the mini-games and finish the achievements,  but I'm not sure you'll get much replayability out of it. The game forces you to invest way too much time into some of these mini-games to recruit certain characters. Replaying JRPGs is about reliving the magic, but being forced to slog through a not-so-fun mini-game for the best ending... isn't really my idea of that. 


All in all. if you really really like JRPGs or are a Suikoden fan still feeling kicked in the nuts by Konami, then this is the game for you. Despite my complaints, there is plenty of magic and potential here... it's just... more unpolished than I thought it would be.

Eiyuden Hundred Heroes is a game crafted with love and passion by early genre pioneers, reflecting their expertise in storytelling and character development. While it isn't perfect, it offers a mostly enjoyable experience and worth playing for fans of the genre.

Nostalgia plays a significant role in the game, balancing old-school elements with modern expectations. While some 90s and 2000s mechanics may feel outdated, the developers' commitment to their vision deserves credit.

The game's strengths lie in its world-building and graphics. The HD-2D visuals are stunning, with detailed backgrounds and impressive effects. The storyline, focused on empires, rebellions, and political intrigue, unfolds believably and avoids gratuitous twists.

Characters are another highlight, with strong voice acting and engaging personalities. However, the large cast can lead to some characters fading into the background post-recruitment. I always want more of certain characters and less of others, but that's the way the wheel spins when you have over 100 characters in your troop.

A major issue for me is the game's unbalanced experience. Combat difficulty spikes early but becomes routine later. The turn-based system, while nostalgic, can feel tedious, although the auto-battle feature helps. The inability to grind beyond a point and random battles offering little reward are also drawbacks.

Pacing problems emerge about a quarter in, making the game feel slow and aimless. However, I found for myself that playing on handheld devices can alleviate some of this frustration with multitasking. The music, mini-games, and base-building mechanics are adequate but not exceptional.

Overall, I'm glad I backed this project despite some mixed feelings. As a fan of JRPGs, supporting pioneers in the genre is important. I look forward to their next title, hoping they learn from Hundred Heroes and Rising to create something truly special.

*[Footnote: I did not address the English localization controversy, as it seemed rooted in bigotry and did not impact my experience during 70+ hours of gameplay.]*

The scenery looks dang good too, if you're into that sort of thing. 

The best way I can describe the down sides is that the whole thing just feels hollow. I didn't care about the characters or story. On the outside, you can see what they were going for but it just wasn't there. There were many, many times I rolled my eyes so hard at the tropes and writing. I did see a lot of people complaining about the translations and localization but I don't think that was the issue (minus Lian's "catchphrase"). The plots and story lines just were basic as hell and everything felt contrived. They knew it had to match the formula and it shows.

By saying that, I know I take funds away from the JRPG genre in general - But I'd feel worse if someone new to this genre and played this first, then didn't like it enough to not try any others.
