I was a kickstarter backer right when that first teaser dropped. Awesome sprite work. Fluid animations and battles. Great OST. However, from what I've seen in the first few hours of play though is a far cry from what I was anticipating. The entire progression of the game seems to be designed either unintentionally or deliberately to waste your time:

- Trivial overworld fights that don't self-resolve: If the fight gives me the option to "let the monsters go", why do we bother with entering the battle at all?
- Tedious backtracking: I met a character while leaving the city who directed me to a eastern gulch to fight a boss for her recruitment. In a town in the opposite direction, a character demands you prove yourself by slaying three generic mobs in that same zone.  Couldn't the fact that I had the initial character be proof enough? That's two visits to the same zone, two crossings of the same map,  over fifteen worthless encounters, a bunch of loading screens and a new party member who's got a really lame look and personality. I don't doubt this type of thing will be happening frequently in the future.



-Uninspired dungeons: When encounters are random, I want to spend less time in dungeons, not more. But nearly every fork in the path leads to a chest that you feel compelled to grab, which just opens you up to more random encounters. No optional bosses, no shortcuts, no real secrets.
- Auto battles: This is more of a personal gripe, but I firmly believe that a game that gives the option to speed up or allow auto battles is self-reporting that it's battle system and progression is bad. At least a game like Bravely Second doubled down on grinding by allowing chained encounters and action queues as well as giving the option to disable fights.

I only played the opening of Suikoden 2 on an emulator, but at least that game had a nice dramatic hook in the opening moments. I'm really not appreciating this slow windup when the pacing issues are front and center. I can't in good conscience recommend this JRPG over the hundred others that got it right.

EDIT: Apparently there is a journal and map, just not in the main item menu. Whoops.

J'écris cet avis en précisant que Suikoden 1 et 2 sont mes deux jeux préférés ever, du coup j'aurai un avis sans doute biaisé mais aussi très critique car j'ai attendu ce jeu depuis l'annonce kickstarter il y a 4 ans.

Le gros point négatif c'est que c'est un jeu très inégal;
Difficulté; un début difficile au début mais à partir du milieu tout devient très facile, que ce soit dans la construction de la base ou les combats (ressources infini et trop de lvl par rapport aux monstres sans grind une seul fois).

Combat; en début de partie, les mages n'ayant pas beaucoup de MP ne pourront pas lancer beaucoup de spells du coup vous êtes obligé de vous tourner vers les persos physiques, et la tendance change en cours de jeu, avec en fin de jeu un mage qui peut infliger 1600 de dégâts sur tout le groupe adverse, ce qui 3 shoots n'importe quel boss.
On peut parler aussi des types de personnages, les gros costauds ultra résistants avec de gros dégâts physiques (portée S), les mages un peu moins résistants avec de gros dégâts magiques (portée L magique), les hybrides encore moins résistants qui infligent moins de dégâts que les deux autres types (portée M et portée L physique). Bizarrement la courbe d'amélioration des personnages n'est pas linéaire, du coup ces fameux personnages hybrides deviendront vraiment forts qu'à très haut lvl, en toute fin de partie, dommage.
Et éviter d'utiliser les combos de héros, méga stylé mais qui font moins de dégâts par rapport aux autres attaques alors que vous utiliser plusieurs héros pour les faire.

Runes; Certaines runes sont inutiles, tandis que d'autres sont beaucoup trop fortes.
Les runes de soins ne servent plus à grand chose quand vous gagnez des items qui rendent full life toute votre équipe est cela beaucoup trop tôt, elles ne seront utiles qu'à très haut lvl (70-75) que vous n'atteindrez que pour faire les défis.
Il y a aussi les emplacements de runes, selon les personnages vous avez plus ou moins d'emplacements de runes qui sont restreints à un certain type de rune, et les personnages du jeu ne sont vraiment pas taillés pareil à ce niveau là.

Ecriture des personnages; certains personnages sont très attachants car dès leur introduction on vous montre toute leur personnalité haute en couleurs grâce à pas mal de lignes de texte ou du faites que vous les ayez déjà croisés dans Rising, alors que d'autres sont hyper plats avec 3 boites de dialogues.

Recrutement; certains personnages que vous devriez recrutés en début de partie (tout ceux qui gèrent un bâtiment dans votre base) vous ne les recruterez quand fin de partie (avant la bataille finale) ce qui fait que le bâtiment qu'ils gèrent ensuite dans la base n'aura aucune utilité car vous êtes déjà en fin de partie.
Et les personnages qui demanderont 1h à 2h de jeu complet pour pouvoir être recrutés avec des quêtes de farming/ultra redondante (toupie et cuisine) c'était pas obligatoire je pense, et même si on parle ici que de 5% du casting ça représente sur 50h de jeu quand même 8h de jeu, c'est trop.

Les descriptions des items; certains indiquent bien ce qu'ils font, et pour d'autres c'est à vous de le découvrir.


Un autre point noir, c'est un le manque d'optimisation qui ce fait ressentir, mais très rarement heureusement, j'ai pas eu de bug, seulement pour un recrutement mais ça a été patch.


Et pour le dernier point noir, c'est la traduction française, certaines phrases n'ont aucun sens mais se serait à cause de la traduction foireuse en anglais, mais ça mérite pas un avis négatif . Quand je vois certains idiots qui n'ont pas acheté le jeu mais qui se permettent de le descendre juste à cause de ça... votre bêtise vous tuera.


Les points positifs, j'ai mis (nouveau) si ça n'était pas dans Suikoden 1 et 2;
-120 personnages à recruter, mais plus jamais de quête de farming pour le recrutement
-Le système de combat, mon préféré ever, mais qui demande un équilibrage
-Le système d'emplacements de rune (nouveau), qui permet de personnaliser vos personnages, mais il demande un équilibrage aussi
-La construction de la base (nouveau), mais pareil il faut retravailler certains points
-Le shield break en combat (nouveau) et les types des dégâts (nouveau), mais hélas pas assez utilisés
-L'histoire, c'est du shonen, soit on aime soit on aime pas, moi j'ai bien aimé ^^
-Les gros clins d’œil à la culture du manga
-Beaucoup de personnages (principales ou secondaires) qui ont un vrai charisme
-La bande-son
-Les graphismes 2D-3D
-Le personnage de soutien dans l'équipe (nouveau)
-Le fait que certains personnages sont obligatoires dans l'équipe, mais ne sont pas obligés de combattre (nouveau)

Pour tous fans de Suikoden, je recommande ce jeu, pour les autres à vous de voir, il vaudrait mieux attendre un gros patch.

Je pense que pour un premier opus (car une suite est prévue) on a droit à un super jeu, oui il y a des erreurs, mais pour un jeu indé fait par une petite équipe on a droit à un super jeu quand même, si les développeurs écoute la communauté et règlent tout ces petits problèmes alors le deuxième opus sera un grand jeu.

This game is fantastic, and as a lover of Suikoden's, and JRPG's since Final Fantasy 3 as a kid, this is the kind of game that's been missing from my adulthood that was so readily available in the PS1/PS2 eras. A well executed, long, well written story-driven single player JRPG with all the side quests, mini-games, etcetera that the smaller attempts to emulate that era just don't have. If you miss the sheer audacity of that era, where one story could be played for days on end, littered with mini-games and side-quests and battle modes that would in modern times be ripped out into a DLC, or their own spin-off, then this is the game for you.

Don't let the whining about the localization bother you; anyone actually bilingual can tell you it was well done. Is it a perfect one to one translation? No. Is it an extremely good localization that brings life and charm to characters that would otherwise be bland and boring if translated instead of localized to English? Absolutely.

I honestly can't really sum up my feelings about this game beyond just... friggin' finally. Even the FF7 remakes fail to live up to the JRPG era, for the basic reason that they're chopping the thing up. This is how JRPG's are meant to be played, loaded with multiple systems and mini-games all in tandem with a world altering plot that covers leaving your village to changing and/or saving the world over tens of hours.
The best Suikoden-game in decades.

[h2]前言：[/h2]
先简单聊聊日式角色扮演（简称JRPG）。日式角色扮演跟角色扮演其实差别蛮大，日式角色扮演算是在角色扮演类型下走出了具有自己特色的分支。

养成方面并没有那么角色扮演，相反更像动作冒险游戏，装备武器系统并不以丰富著称，基本上只是承担一定的角色成长作用。战斗表现，得看开发组如何定位，有些JRPG的动作元素比较重，例如：碧蓝relink、最终幻想7重制系列等。但多数JRPG的战斗还是以回合制为主，本作<百英雄传>也是回合制战斗。

日式角色扮演有明确的主角，故事是围绕这个明确主角展开的，故事一般也都王道剧情。游戏体验主要是以主角视角进行冒险，跟随剧情与大量的角色产生情感（情绪）上的羁绊，战斗环节只要不是特别糟糕，讲一个能提供情绪反馈的故事，那就是合格的答卷。

[h2]<百英雄传>游戏体验[/h2]
比较慢热的游戏，毕竟游戏无法在开头就把百余名英雄放出来，加上剧情节奏也偏慢，还有游戏内容的解锁也拉得较长，像建筑设计内容是在好几章后面才开启。

初印象并不好，如不太匹配的性价比，像翻译表现不理想，图形技术比较落后；游戏节奏太慢，像角色对话和剧情演绎，都是不紧不慢的对白，即使重复游戏也无法跳过。存档也只能在进出城堡、存档点或旅店，有一次丢了至少2小时的游戏内容。

与英雄们的奇遇[u] 下划线文本 [/u]
渐入佳境谈不上，可确实随着游戏流程的推进会越来越有意思，当然这里面也有明显的短板。

<百英雄传>是游戏名字，游戏的核心体验确实也是结识各种英雄。在世界中与不同角色奇遇也是蛮有意思的，就是有些奇遇加入队伍的理由都比较戏剧性，其实就是加入理由不太经得起推敲。

每位英雄都比较有特点，从外观来看都有明显的差异，这些英雄角色的能力表现基本上属于独一无二。细心经营这个队伍，慢慢壮大这个团队，这种感觉是很棒的，比较有成就感。

剧情方面比较差强人意，似乎游戏想强调主角诺瓦跟塞恩的“宿命感”，可剧情中这两人的情谊剧情并不多，因此羁绊感感觉并不强，所以当他两对立时，那种冲突感大大降低。

[u] 养成的深度有限[/u]
本作的角色扮演内容比某些JRPG要丰富一些，也就丰富了那么一点。技能系统的设计比较有意思，但深度也比较有限，类似符文镶嵌的核心体验。单名角色的可用武器不多，其实也很难多，毕竟有上百名的特色角色，这一点还是比较能理解。装备系统没有角色要求，主要是根据角色职能类型进行划分的，例如：偏战士职能的角色，都可以使用板甲装备。饰品方面倒是没有什么职能限制，基本上可以通用。

其实每个角色装备和饰品，也就可以穿戴4件，主要是承担角色的成长，但成长的多样性是不高的。加上装备主要是靠商店阶段性刷新获取，并不是以战斗掉落或者其它方式获取为主。

等级系统依旧是比较传统的机制，有意思的地方在“经验追赶机制”。获取的新英雄等级一般都会比出战的角色等级要低几级，等级稍低的角色每次战斗后会获取更多经验，直到跟等级最高的出战角色的等级一致。遗憾的点，放在旅馆的角色经验不会涨，也是需要出战后进行经验追赶。这对于有100名英雄的游戏而言，感觉还是有点肝儿疼。

[u]有一定乐趣的战斗[/u]
本作游戏的战斗机制不少，但整体有种割裂感。本作的战斗环节很多时候是无趣的，但作战编辑系统有点意思。提供的部分机制Boss却比较有意思，例如：猜边触发额外攻击，触发机关等机制。

本作提供了传统回合制战斗的相关内容，如普攻，法术攻击，防御，物品使用和组合技，也有先对比较特殊的“魔导透镜”的技能，需要用称之为SP的资源释放。这里建议MP可以省着用，SP不用太省，有了就用。还有躲避机制，这个机制大多数时候是比较无用的，只有极少数情况比较有价值。

为什么说有种割裂感？
在触发战斗时提供了三个选项，作战、自动和逃跑。这就说明了自动作战是被鼓励的，是重要的内容。加上游戏还有“作战方案”系统，这一大块系统就是为了自动战斗服务的。可以编辑小队作战风格，角色行动优先设置等内容。这一系统虽然没有《圣兽》那边细节，但也有不少的内容可供玩家设置。

只要不是遇到Boss，基本上自动战斗就可以。自动战斗能够节约不少时间，每个角色同时（快速）完成攻击指令，直接观看战斗过程即可。真要是自动战斗的过程不对劲，还能随时取消，下个回合便可进入手动回合。

后面还有军团战争的战棋玩法，改完发出场率不算高，但策略性更强。这里有一个奇怪的情况，在移动回合，敌人箭头明明是向左，不知道为何开战后，敌人却向前行进，这让对战难度提升。

战斗最不满意的环节，还是触发战斗的音效。该音效令人非常感受是难受，刺耳且惊悚。每次都让人心里一颤，是特别糟糕的体验。

[h2]性价比这回事[/h2]
游戏价格从游戏制作和内容来衡量，如果一款游戏的售价足够高，那么其制作水平与游戏内容都应该与之匹配。这无关其它，这是对玩家的一种尊重。

似乎只要打上经典二字，就可以理直气壮的敷衍，大地图和关卡场景的敷衍肉眼可见，中文本地化的敷衍毫不掩饰。长期有个疑问，不符合时代发展的（所谓经典的）JRPG，有何底气售价198元，这还不包括98元的季票。只因它的产地或经典二字，就可以为所欲为的定价？

这款游戏是慢热的，也是有趣的，立绘和像素角色很棒，招纳百名英雄的体验不错。当然也是有不少问题，场景图形质量高低不齐，场景建筑会挡住视角，剧情高开低走，养成内容的深度有限，战斗多数时候无趣，乐趣主要在战斗策略编辑和对战机制BOSS。

如果你是富哥，如果不在乎图形表现与本地化问题且非常喜欢JRPG，那么你可以随意选择是否购买。否则，最好还是等折扣。

最后感谢各位队长的阅读！

Eiyuden Chronicle is an absolute delight so far, and bursting at the seams with nostalgic vibes. I really missed JRPGs like this, and even if I barely played the Suikoden series, I already enjoy games with lots of characters to play as or collect. The story, gameplay, music, and visuals are mostly on point here. There's a few glaring issues, such as text that doesn't display what the voiceovers say, annoying inventory limit, and an oldschool JRPG challenge that requires you to absolutely be prepared or you'll find yourself with no healing items. The latter isn't that much of an issue, because I enjoy that this game can be pretty challenging at times. But I really hate how you have a limit to the items you can carry, it is obnoxious! This issue with items also extends to MP items being rare and scarce... what is with these oldschool JRPGs and not wanting your spellcasters to have enough MP if you like to cast spells more liberally?

Despite Eiyuden Chronicle having a decidedly oldschool feel, there are some damn solid quality of life improvements. Grinding is almost not a thing, because if your characters get to a certain level threshold, they will earn less and less XP from enemies lower and lower levels than them. You will earn the inverse if you have characters lower and lower levels than your enemies, meaning even more XP for them. Yes, characters not in your party won't earn XP. You will also have an objective marker that will tell you where to go to progress the story, making knowing where to go a breeze, and checking out side content easier.

The biggest feature of the game is the massive roster of characters. Some can't fight alongside you in battle, but can help run things back at headquarters. Oh yeah, you manage a cool castle town and fortress, which is your HQ. You level it up, grow your population, gather resources during your adventures, build new facilities, and recruit characters to run said buildings. It's really quite a joy.

Eiyuden Chronicle is a fantastic return to a bygone era, one that I've been missing for awhile. Games like Octopath Traveler 1 and 2 also fit nicely into this growing collection of oldschool style JRPGs. More, please!

Un très bon J-RPG. Evidemment, ceux qui ont joué à Suikoden 1-5 auront de plus un petit effet "Madeleine de Proust" ajoutant encore a l'experience. 

Pour les autres : 
- Le jeu est un J-RPG en 2D, les combats se font a 6 personnages, et peuvent être parfois relativement hardu - le jeu dispose de plus d'un mode difficile qui rend encore plus complexe les affrontements
- Plus de 100 personnages recrutables, certain qui contribueront a ajouter des features au jeu, une grande partie étant jouable, chacun ayant des caractéristiques, possibilités de builds différents (cf. phrase d'après)
- La customisation passe principalement par le système de "runes", chaque personnage à différents emplacements pour y placer des runes (passifs, up de caractéristiques, magies, coups spéciaux) 
- Plusieurs mini-jeux, certains plus sympa que d'autres.

En bref, le jeu est très bon, et est une excellente base pour une potentielle suite qu'on espère voir venir !

Is it a perfect game? No. Is it enjoyable? Heck yes. Does it remind me of the Suikoden series? Heck yeah!!!! Is a carbon copy? No. Did the devs make mistakes? You bet. Do I regret my purchase/support? No.

Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes has its pros and cons like every other game. Below, I will review some pros and cons and some comparisons with the Suikoden series.

Story/Characters:
Pros
-Very similar Suikoden vibes.
-I like the diverse cast of characters in terms of how they look and different races/tribes of people. Thats always been something the Suikoden game excelled at so it was reminiscent of it. And yes there is a LGBT+ character in this game and its not that deep.
-The story makes subtle references to other places that you do not see at the end of the game. Such as a University known for education and its observatory. Even some characters are from this university or has been there in this game. This was similar to Suikoden I and II where they referenced other places and then introduced them later in the series.
-There are lots of heroes to collect and I believe there's about 120 characters.
-There are lots of minigames to play. My favorite is probably the card game. There is a beyblade-esque game too.
-Has a killer/catchy theme song that is mostly in Japanese but then goes "hundred heroes" which was awesome.
-They definitely acknowledged the backers that helped make this game and I thought it was cute seeing people on reddit say they found themselves in-game.
Cons:
-The story could have been written and told better. Everything was there for a reason. They did not focus on building the characters relationships with one another. Lets just say even the game itself had some scenes where you see a black screen and it just says 6 months later...a few weeks later...etc.
-They tried to copy the bond/rivalry of Suikoden II between Riou and Jowy but failed with Nowa and Seign. This made their duel anticlimatic because they knew each other for a day before war split them which as a reader/gamer, you did not feel the emotions they were suppose to feel. 
-Localization could have improved but I understood what was going on just fine. The dialogue from certain characters was questionable. I found a lot of very annoying characters, mostly hyperactive/loud/obnoxious female characters but I think that's a JRPG trying to make them cute thing which I personally don't like. 
-They skip over a lot of important lore or things that could have expanded the world. I'm not sure if this is due to them wanting to expand it later, but they missed a big opportunity here and this is probably why a lot of negative reviews says it feels rushed. They focused on the storyline and that was it.
-There are parts in the game where they just tell you to literally go find characters to recruit which doesn't flow well and seems forced.
-They released the game with a bug that caused you to be unable to recruit a character but they fixed it within the week of its release.

Battle/Turn-based Gameplay
Pros: They improved on the rune system in my opinion. Adding rune slots beyond the 3 from Suikoden's head/left/right arm was such a great improvement. This provided an opportunity to make some characters fit what you want them to do while still giving characters some uniqueness with exclusive runes and restrictions. 
-Most characters will have at least one level 3 magic rune and a few stat enhancement or skill runes. Some even have an anything you want rune slot. One special character even has all of their runes at level 4 as anything you want. 
-Removing rune charges for MP was also the best thing they could have done and having MP restore items and rune shards. This allowed you to kinda tinker characters stats and in this case you can adjust their MP should you want. 
-The auto battle system works well for lazy people if you know how to set it up properly and pay attention to your characters speed/sp/mana management.
-Characters will learn and open up new rune slots as they level up. Some exclusive runes are learned this way instead of being found which Suikoden didn't offer and locked behind rune charges.
Cons: 
-The instructions on battles can be confusing but once you know the basic, its actually quite fun. 
-A lot of people will struggle with how SP is generated and the game does a poor job of explaining it. Basically SP is randomly generated based on the luck stat. Not all character will use SP or have the ability to do so. If you have high luck, you have more chance of gaining 1 or multiple SP after each round. 
-Stats of some characters can be very random and unappealing such as a mage that has higher strength than a warrior or a mage with less MP than a warrior. The consistency seems a bit random and I'm not sure who worked on these numbers. Personally, it didn't get in the way of the overall enjoyment.
-They removed the dojo's/skill enhancer/grades which I really loved in Suikoden III/V. This means that many characters can hit multiple attack counts, but it doesn't seem to make any difference in terms of hit counts/overall damage. In fact, multiple hit counts are pointless and does not offer any incentive.
-The hero combos cost too many SP from each character and the damage is not worth the turn or SP cost.
-There are no range physical skills that are good which makes rangers inferior. Its a mage/warrior kind of game. There's like 3 useful tanks, but tanking and covering is all rng and luck based.

Dueling
Pros: The cutscenes during the duels throughout the games are pretty cool and fun to watch.
Cons: The combat itself is not enjoyable because it forces you to select certain options to continue with the animation so you can't just attack them to the end or use your special whenever. In previous Suikoden games you could do whatever you want and it made a big difference.

Warfare/Strategic Battles
Pros: You see (what I believe to be) random backers and their names being killed in battle lol. Besides that there aren't really any pros.
Cons: I found the war battles so boring and useless. You can't really edit your team. You select and move them and have little to no control otherwise besides some 1 use skill that can't be improved upon. Your characters stats doesn't matter so you can't just obliterate everything and can still die from something stupid. I'm not sure how this is calculated but this is the worse part of the game. I wish they stuck to Suikoden III and how you can still influence the map yet still choose what you want to do.

So yes, I wrote a lot, but I also enjoyed the game for what it is. Did it exceed my expectations? No. Was I happy with my purchase? Yes. Because I supported a game and it delivered a game that brought joy and memories. Can it improve? Absolutely. I hope people give it the chance to because there is so much to this game and I hope the dev's will listen and improve on these things.

좋은 의미로도 나쁜 의미로도 올드스쿨. 옛 방식의 JRPG를 선호하는 사람에게는 단비와 같은 작품이지만 그렇지 않다면 초반 10시간 안팎의 이벤트와 진행이 고통으로 다가올 것.

익숙해질수록 나름의 맛이 있는 것은 사실이지만, 그 빌드업까지 버티기가 쉽지 않다는 점에서 매력을 어필할 기회조차 얻지 못할 것이라 정말 옛 향수가 필요한 플레이어 외에는 와닿지 않을 것이라 본다. 나 역시도 와달지 않는 쪽에 가깝고, 정가로 살 만한 게임은 아니라고 평한다.

무라야마 요시타카의 유작이자 어떤 의미로 만들고 싶었지만 그렇지 못했던 한을 푼 작품이라고 봐야겠지만 그러기에는 시간이 너무 흘렀음을 안타까워해야 하고, 받아들이기 어려웠고, 차라리 환상수호전이 더 나았음을 받아들여야 할만큼 아쉬운 것들이 가득한 게임이다.

스팀덱에서도 문제 없이 동작하는 대신, 해상도 조정 문제로 본성 아르카디아에 들어서는 시점에서 그래픽 잔상이 남는 오류가 있다. 전체 화면으로 옵션을 설정해 해결할 것.

2024. 055. 10 수정) 아르카디아 본거지 3레벨을 올리면 일부 지역에서는 해결되나, 여전히 다른 지역에서 같은 문제가 발생한다. 이는 화면을 불러놀때 원본 해상도를 일단 불러온 뒤 이걸 스팀덱에 구겨넣으면서 남은 잔재로 보임. 아마 고치지는 않을 듯.

그리고 505게임즈는 번역회사와의 관계를 다시 재고해 보기 바람. 일본어 기반 번역인데 미묘한 곳에서 죄다 엉망임.

For fans of Suikoden or old school turn based JRPG in general, This game is very recommended. Made by the team that make the original Suikoden game, it start as Kickstarter project and after it released, it really brings nostalgic feelings to the fans. 
The graphic is 2D pixel with 3D movement with animated pixel background. The pixel quality is very high compared to old RPG, it looks very good on high resolution monitor. The story is rich and engaging and the gameplay is interesting. The story is about civil war. Its quite serious though there are many light jokes. There are many reference to popular series like the card duelist guy that look like Yu Gi Oh character or the beigoma guy that look like Bakugan character, and of course many of the recruitable character are reminiscence of Suikoden character
Pros:
- There are 120 character to collect, Some could help in battle, some give support, and some are important for story or HQ upgrade
- HQ progression. by collecting resource, fund and some character, you could upgrade your HQ
- Lots of minigames
- There are normal turn based battle, map battle, and duel battle
Cons:
- I saw many review that the dialogue is chiildish. This is mostly because the English translation is bad. I use Japanese voice and its often have different nuance. The translator often put american cartoon jokes and slur in the dialog. Making many character seems like joking and childish in serious situation. Though this is easily fixed with mod.

Overall this game is a strong recommend from me, though not an unqualified one. It’s a better JRPG than it is Suikoden spiritual successor despite the superficial similarities. 

This review is going to be a long one so I’ll put the conclusion first: An incredible game with large flaws that may not satisfy long standing fans of Suikoden but is nonetheless well worth purchasing and playing.

The Good:

Succeeds wildly in making most the characters feel like characters and not just checkboxes on a list – whoever you bring with you will comment on what’s going on like they’re a ‘real’ party member and I think this an aspect Eiyuden succeeds in that Suikoden didn’t always. The theatre is great for this as well and the voice actors did a really good job across the board. 

The world is good, and the locations are quite varied. The music knocks it out of the park and the overall length of the game feels good. Its good to see a breeding/racing minigame, even if it was somewhat rudimentary I had a lot of fun with it. I liked the card game though I fell off it about 1/3rd of the way through the total possible matches.

Regarding the antagonist I thought he was quite well done [spoiler] and his motivations were great, as was the final act reveal about why he was so invested in what he was doing[/spoiler]. 

The game can look very good and the animation quality is superb. I was engaged for the entire story. Almost every Duel was great and they’re a highlight when they show up. I felt a level of joy playing though most of this game that I don’t get out of a lot of games and it was clearly made with love.

I found the puzzle design to be quite good and as long as you enjoy puzzles as an aspect of jrpgs you should find a lot to like here as well. They space the puzzle areas out enough that I never got tired of them when they showed up.

The Bad

The game CAN look very good but unless you mod you won’t be able to see that, which is disappointing. I feel bad for players on a platform where you can’t fix the shadows, weird lod stuff or strange chroma. 

Lian. Don’t know what happened here but Lian is kind of just a bad person who does annoying things for no reason, and no one properly calls her out on this. It’s like someone took the ‘genki girl’ character type then added a dash of sociopath and dialed them up to ‘unforgivably anti-social’. The main character is also probably the least interesting character in the whole cast, and isn’t given much to do or react to on a personal level. Most of what you’d expect out of a main character gets offloaded to Seign and Marissa. A few of the characters are a little inconsistent in how they act though it wasn't usually enough to break them for me.

Beigoma is terribly boring and the game forces you to do way too much of it as part of recruitment. There’s a moment right near the end of the game where I was like ‘this would be very cool, if only the minigame wasn’t terrible’. The sand racing game has controls right out of the ps1 era when they were still figuring out 3d movement I don’t understand several things about the decisions made here. The fishing minigame is very shallow, and very annoying for recruitment purposes. 

The game in general tends to involve a LOT of waiting for animations, especially for pre-battle support buffs but also throughout almost every aspect. Battles themselves should be faster. It’s in dire need of the ability for more than one person to attack at the same time if you’re just autoing, something that even the first Suikoden managed.

The war battles are also very, very slow and not only aren’t engaging, they make the cardinal sin of abstracting things so much that I never felt like my recruitment efforts were assisting me on the war level. The duel’s rarely show up and there’s only a handful in the entire game. Worse, there are many points where it felt like there should have been a duel and there was either a 1v1 regular battle or just nothing.

Though the locations are quite varied you will find yourself going to back to some of them way too often. I don’t know why everyone wants to hang out in the mines underneath my castle but I wish they wouldn’t, and cutting the ‘harvesting’ dungeons into time locked pieces ended up feeling cheap. On that matter I don’t feel that the base construction ever justified itself and I would have much preferred if the castle automatically built itself as you recruited people instead of having to engage with superficial resource management. 

The Different

The biggest difference is it’s missing almost all of the darker edge of the Suikoden games. The political machinations are much reduced and there isn’t much in the way of shocking moments. The main character feels like an observer in his own game and desperately needs motivation for his actions. The Rune Lenses are nothing like the runes and despite them taking the same place in the world they don’t seem to have and sapience or affect on the world directly. The Suikoden series was at its best when it exploring the interplay between the machinations of the Runes and the politics of an area, as well as the every day lives of the people they affected.

Eiyuden has some flashes of this with Seign’s story, but its brief and not a focus so while it’s a fun jrpg filled with bright, colourful characters and locations, it feels like the core story is lacking any meat that would make it properly one of the greats. It’s a little odd because the antagonist feels like a Suikoden style/tier antagonist but he ends up feeling tonally out of place with most of the rest of the game.

I’d liken it more to something like Grandia than Suikoden on every aspect that isn’t ‘there’s over 100 recruitable characters and you have a base.’

For people who are coming in without having played Suikoden (for starters go back and play Suikoden 1 and 2, they’re not that long and they hold up) they’ll probably find more to like about this game than fans of s1/2/5 will, so don’t let having not played the old games put you off.

Conclusion: See start of review. I understand that in many respects this review is what could be termed a ‘write-only document’ but if you got this far I hope it helps.

很少对一款日式RPG如此失望。以100名可用角色为噱头宣传，让人误以为这是一款自由度极高，讲究构筑，核心玩法具有深度的RPG。结果发现选择最高难度可以轻松用全自动战斗解决几乎所有杂兵。BOSS战也是简单的使用机关和过程重复。每个角色只有1种技能，功能作用的机制模糊，有时有效有时无效，游戏内也没有解释这种机制的帮助。这样100个角色可以提供的玩法也不过相当于20多个角色每人拥有4，5个技能的游戏。队形系统也没有太大实际意义。总之核心玩法乏善可陈，作为一名看重战术构筑的玩家，这个游戏的战术构筑体系让我非常失望，100个角色根本名不副实。一开始忍受着落后时代20年的画面技术玩的时候我还告诉自己，慢热的日式RPG是这样的，知道玩了将近4个小时我才发现，不，他就是这么垃圾。尽管游戏采用了全语音，但游戏拖沓的剧情和低于预期很多的核心玩法都远远不值200块这个价钱。我最终决定退款，然后steam告诉我超过2个小时无法退款，我发誓再也不会买这家公司的游戏。
总体8分，比幻水2差了那种宿命感和剧情上的反转，音乐也比幻水2差一档，希望能出2，当年幻水也是2才是巅峰

[h1] 英雄永远都不是一个人。 [/h1]
本作是曾经幻想水浒传系列的制造者村山吉隆通过KICKSTARTER众筹的方式所完成的一部作品，也算得上幻想水浒传系列的精神续作  不过遗憾的是村山吉隆先生在今年的2月份因病去世，本作可以称之为村山吉隆先生的绝唱了。

[h1] 故事背景。 [/h1]
这是一个架空的世界，这里拥有非常多的国家，他们有着不同的文化，不同的价值观，人类，兽人，精灵 等不同的种族，不同的国家，都有一个共同的目标，那就是一个名为符文镜片的神器，在故事的开头以及游戏的序章，可以得知帝国是充满野心的，他们渴望获得原始棱镜，获得可以放大神器威力的技术，因为只有这样他们才可以从实力上压制其他的国家，从而统治这片大陆。一位来自偏远村庄的少年怀着梦想加入了守备队，与当时寻找原始棱镜的帝国军合作，并且结识了跟自己相等年龄并且才华横溢的帝国中尉，本来的故事应该是美好的。可是命运的波折将他，将中尉，将所有的英雄们，拖入了战火。他们都要重新去审视，曾经认为是正确的一切，现在是否还正确。

[h1] 游戏的玩法以及体验 8.5 / 10 [/h1]
这是一款王道水平的日式RPG，在游戏中会有上百位同伴加入你的队伍，游戏的自由度非常的高，我们可以根据自己的喜好去组建我们的小队，这也算是游戏的一大魅力了。游戏的剧本非常宏大，有着大规模战争的场面，并且以战争作为游戏的舞台，英雄永远都不是一个人，每个种族，每个国家都有属于他们自己的英雄，这里在游戏系统中，融入了策略战术的玩法，可以招募，可以去进行城市的建设，抵抗帝国的入侵。王道的剧情，宿命的对决，画风精美复古的立绘，也许有人说这是旧时代的残党，是的，放在如今来看，这款游戏，确实不怎么好，像素的人物，脱离了时代的设计，我们的背包容量比较小，经常要丢弃物品，把珍贵的道具存在仓库里面，战斗前没有明显的提醒，直接就进入战斗了，可能这也是RPG游戏的普遍风格，有时候还没补给好，就进入战斗了，真的很痛苦，在迷宫中没有回复点，只有存档点，不过游戏的道具都比较便宜，像恢复的草药，还有复活药，都很便宜。符文的更换要去城镇里面的商店更换，比较麻烦，前期是比较慢热的，可能也是大部分JRPG 的通病。但是当我们度过了前期的慢热时期后 游戏真正的好玩了起来，我们可以建造我们的城镇，不断的去与这片大陆上的英雄们相遇，去真真正正的沉浸于王道的剧情中，不同的英雄有着不同的背景，不同的人生，不同的价值观，这才是这款王道JRPG的专属魅力所在。

[h1] 总结 [/h1]
也许你说这款游戏是旧时代的残党，可是我却不这么认为，在如今的时代，这么一款高水准制作的复古JRPG，上百位英雄的故事，庞大的战争作为英雄们登场的舞台，王道的剧情，慢热的节奏也不再是缺点，在当今快节奏的社会，很少有一款游戏，能让人慢慢的停留下来，去体验，去品味。这是一款非常优秀的JRPG 游戏，如果你拥有空闲的时间，如果你想去体验这片大陆上面所发生的英雄们的故事，那么请你一定要来尝试一下这款游戏。纸上得来终觉浅，绝知此事要躬行，亲自体验后，你们一定不会感到后悔。

There's so much to love here for JRPG lovers in general but especially fans of Suikoden 1&2. In fact, there's a lot that it does better than Suikoden, particularly quality of life changes suited for the modern era, such as having a reserves section of the party to store mandatory party members that are typically unused. The game also takes inspiration from Octopath Traveler in its art direction and some aspects of the gameplay, such as the SP system.

Don't let the reviews about localization fool you, Eiyuden Chronicle has fantastic voice acting and the writing is spot-on. Localizations are not supposed to be a direct translation of the source material, instead adapting the material to fit the cultural norms of where the game is being played. In that regard, there are no complaints. Furthermore, there's just so many lines that are voice-acted that you could probably play the main story without the dialogue text boxes and follow the entire thing. It's incredibly impressive and lets you focus on the beautiful animations and expressive art rather than splitting your attention by reading.

The story of political intrigue and the horrors of war found in Suikoden can also be found here. Some of the depictions of evil are toned down some (Luca Blight remains unparalleled), but there are many shocking and heartwrenching moments regardless. I never felt like it wasn't going as far as it should in providing a captivating narrative.

I strongly recommend playing it through to the end, even if you don't go for completion like I did, since stuff like Beigoma and the cooking battles can become tedious. The card battler is actually pretty fun, though underdeveloped; I wish the attention on the card battler and Beigoma were switched, but alas.

Very excited for the upcoming DLC.

If you love Suikoden and have been longing for a worthy successor, Eiyuden Chronicle does not disappoint. I read some reviews about this being buggy, or riddled with localization errors or even being 'nostalgia and nothing more' or "Suikoden without a soul" and I MUST ADAMANTLY DISAGREE. I think the folks complaining about errors are majorly nitpicking when a project like this was really something diehard Suikoden fans like myself have long thought of as an impossible get. APPRECIATE it for what it is, which is a MARVEL of storytelling prowess. Murayama's legacy and last gift to us and a wonderful reminder of the true soul of Suikoden, what people who share a common goal can achieve when they come together, be it in a castle or via Kickstarter.

Did I miss Suikoden whilst playing? Yes, of course. Carrie is no Viki...Code L is no Jeane. There is no comparison to the beloved characters we hold dear to us, but the great news is...we can always go back to them. They are immortalized already and there is ample room for a new cast of characters just as quirky and memorable as their predecessors. They aren't replacements, nor are the new towns, lore and music....and you shouldn't view them through such a lense because you will inevitably be making comparisons instead of enjoying the narrative, However, if you see them through the lense you viewed those OG Suikoden characters and locales for the first time, as a blank canvas,  you will be awed and intrigued and want more just as you did back in the 90s. I found myself rooting for Perielle, enjoying the unites with Mio & Hakugin, Riufan and Lam, the cooking battles, the puzzles, the grind...all the pieces are there...and to say it lacks soul is an insult to the people who created this. It has its own unique soul which is very worth exploring so I would definitely advise any reluctant fans to give it a chance...I don't think you'll be disappointed.

Growing up playing the Suikoden games, I had a lot of hope for Eiyuden Chronicles to live up to it's mantle of "spiritual successor". Like many people, games in the past 10 years that I have looked forward to have often fallen flat and I've found myself not getting my hopes up anymore. 

However, Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes has completely blown me away, and really revitalized both my optimism for releasing games, and for gaming in general. 

The game is beyond any of my expectations. The story is superb, the character's stories, personalities and content is gripping and emotional (though some of their English voice acting is a little cheesy, I'll admit), and the game is packed with so many collectibles, mini-games, resource gathering, and just enough classic "JRPG grinding" to not be overbearing while remaining true to the genre.

With over 300+ games in my account, I can honestly say this game is among my very top favorites. I have binged an UNHEALTHY amount of time into this title within the three days I've played it, and I can't remember what the sun looks or feels like, but I find myself nearing the end of the game and DREADING not having more to play. I can only hope that developers take note and follow the example this game has set in staying true to a genre, reviving classics, and publishing a FINISHED product. 

Cheers!

For those that want more of a breakdown, I changed my review from recommended to not once I have completed the game. This is a game that is shallow in every aspect but let's break it down by category.


Story: 

Let's get the obvious out of the way. The story is a paint by numbers, dollar store knockoff of Suikoden 1 & 2. 

Main characters have no arcs whatsoever. Their entire personality is a flat line throughout the story. 

There are no greater depth of characters like Viktor, softening of Filk, sacrifice of Mathiu, or tough choices of Jowy. 

Of course there are tons more characters that have amazing moments in Suikoden series but the point is all the characters in Eiyuden Chronicle is a parody of the well written characters. 

Localization is abysmal. You'll hear a lot of current day words that suck you right out of the world. 

Deus Ex Machina rules the story with no smart writing. 

Main characters are bland and you can tell that splitting it to three characters galvanizes a lot of much needed payoffs. 


Gameplay: 

Tons of bugs with gameplay balance where physical damage is king, mana is weaker and cost too much, and hero combos are weaker than just attacking individually. 

INVENTORY is purposely designed to annoy you and I found that out recently playing today. If your inventory is full, you'll get a message that you cannot add the item till you make room. HOWEVER, IF YOU GET AN ITEM FROM THE BAYBLADES MINIGAME AND YOUR INVENTORY IS FULL IT AUTOMATICALLY SENDS IT TO THE WAREHOUSE. Why on earth they didn't implement that feature for the entire game is maddening.  

EVERYTHING is SLOW. From conversations, to walking, to battle, they're all about .5 the speed it should be. 

These are some massive problems considering finding all the characters and seeing what combos you can create was a major appeal of gameplay for Suikoden. 

Bosses have cool gimmick mechanics but they aren't enough to save the gameplay. 

Auto battle mechanic is archaic compared to Unicorn Overlord. You'll find auto battle either wasting MP or not using the preferred attack. 

Recruiting feels meaningless with someone that will give you hints and massive gameplay imbalance. 

There is even a character that you find that requires you to barter $50,000 PROFIT to recruit. You'll find yourself wasting 1-2 hours of your day just bartering and waiting for items to refresh.



This game needed a lot more QA.

Music:

Probably the best part of the game. Battle music is solid and for the most part I have no issues with it. 

Mini Games:

All the mini games are designed to WASTE YOUR TIME.

They are not balanced, well thought out, and REQUIRED for characters.

- Duels are only about like 4 or so and they're story related. You feel no challenge, agency, or satisfaction from them. 

- War Battles are also story driven, require no strategy, and are always 100% anti-climatic. 

- Bayblades knockoff you'll be excited by first until you realize you cannot get them without fighting monsters which means you need to progress the story to even play.

- Card Game is the best of the mini games in my opinion but instead of walking up to people to challenge you can only do it in a static menu. The balance and thought of the card game is great but it's sad that Bayblades trash mini game got the love. 

- Fishing is wasting your time to just press a button at the right time

- Cooking is heavily bugged and you will realize that all the rules set don't actually apply. I beat it using 3 appetizers every time. No challenge or preference of characters needed. Time waster. 


Summary: 

This game makes me appreciate of the storytelling of JRPG's in the mid 90's and early 00's. You don't realize you had it so good until something is gone but if you haven't played Suikoden 1 or 2 i'd highly recommend it even with all the flaws.

The game isn't perfect, but it is still a very good JRPG. The 3d world and 2d sprite of characters blend very well, creating amazing visuals. The hero system makes it fun to explore, especially considering low-level heroes get xp scaled to catch up to other heroes in levels. Some heroes aren't even for battling, but gives buffs to your party or the home base.

The hero combo attacks are really cool to look at, and makes you wanna mix with other heroes just to see what kind of moves they can pull off. 

Soundtrack is very good too! You will be humming to the tune in no time.

There are some drawbacks; the tactical battle games aren't too interesting, there are lots of backtracking when traveling the in-game world, combat can be hard, and because there are more than 100 heroes not everyone has their characters fleshed out. took my time before writing a review
realisticaly i'm somewhat around 30 to 35 hours in by now.

i never played any Suikoden past part 2 (still a game i fondly remember and i finished atleast 10 times), i'm just not that into jrpgs anymore.
but thankfully they stayed true to their initial sales pitch: a jrpg for oldschool fans
and that Eiyuden is in all the best way, but for newer/younger people it will take some adjustment

as an oldschool(er) player i absolutly love the freedom and lack of constant handholding. even early on you can take pretty substantial detours and explore; heck you can miss quite a lot. quite some of the content is kinda (very) hidden, just like it is supposed to be. 
most of the core game should be understandable even for people just used to modern day gaming: you find a character you can possibly recruit, character gives you some fetch quest (can be specific rare drops for example), you solve fetch quest, you recruit character. but often characters and items are quite well "hidden" behind special conditions or special locations, etc. . i'd strongly recommend not using guides for your first playthrough. 

the rest is kinda like you'd expect a "new" Suikoden-like game to be: turn based tactical combat with a party of up to 6, building up your base (castle), doing strategic light turnbased strategy battles, doing a lot of minigames (like a card game, a chisel combat, cooking, etc.), collecting everyone and anyone who cannot run away fast enough, either for your actual party roster or to unlock more functions in your base, leveling up, collecting loot and ressources, etc. 
a) it is all done very competent; yes, there might be some rough(ish) edges here and there, but those were way rougher back in the day, when you couldn't even just patch a game
b) you definitly get the impression a lot of the team actual played the old games and wanted to do this homage
c) the name is nigh unspeakable for an european...i cannot tell how often i miss speak or miss type Eiyuden

i get the impression a lot of influencers or reviewers didn't actualy realy play the game. 
unlike what you might have heard: it gets quite complex, the challenge definitly ups.
there is a lot of stats, elements and even damage types and while early on you might just ignore most of it, it won't take all to long (for a game like this) to make quite a difference if you understand what gives damage boni against what or which rune synergizes with what character and what skill. 
gear comes in helm, armor, weapon, for some a shield, 1 equipable and different runes (you unlock more slots as you level)
damage types are very varied: it is not just the elements (wind, fire, earth, water, light, dark), but also slash, thrust, throw, grappel and the list goes on. most damage types are good against some sort of defense: aka grappel ignores armor, throw gets boni against flying enemies, etc. 
then you ad in the extensive Rune-system, which definitly is on par with the old titels, which can range from magic-spells, special attacks, passive boni and the list goes on
you also basicaly have 3 ressources in fight: classical HP, classical Mana and SP which you normaly get 1 each turn of and can spend on special attacks (kinda an easy to "grow" and spend ressource).
and then there  is character specific special (locked) runes, which net you either special boni (a mage might for example get a significant mana-cost-reduction, a samurai-lady an insta gib slash attack)
an evergrowing number of different accessories, which start out pretty basic, but expand into a wide variety of potenial options
now you keep in mind how gigantic the possible party-member-pool is
and you might understand what a "meaty" game you got here (unlike what some previews/reviews implied).

one of the easiest build examples would be a carry-over-samurai-character from the prequel: he gets a unique slash-attack that increases it's damage the more SP you keep (which means not using special attacks for some turns), then you ad in a rune that ups the melee-damage depending on how much SP you'r character currently got, equip some more STR-buffing gear and buff him up to unleash the equivalent of a small tactical nuke after some turns (when you reached max SP).

mechanical the game is rock, and i do mean rock solid. you just gotta keep in mind that it is large, so the build up, even until you unlock most mechanics (like fast travel, the base with more functions, etc.), will take a while.

writing is always subjective. the plot, as is typical for it's inspiration, is somewhere between war-geo-politics-drama and classical "gotta save the world from evil monsters"-jrpg-tale. imho. it's absolutly well done and the mix between a more grounded gameofthrones-like approach mixed with the more outlandish elements works aswell as it did in Suikoden 1 and 2. nearly everything is VO, and the cast you can recuit (look at the name of the game) all got their own VO, lines and "personalities".
with times many characters you will always get goofy ones, cringy ones, standout ones and forgettable ones; but i found most of the cast atleast entertaining (some horribly obnoxious ones are around aswell, but that is par for the course), and quite some pretty good (again: a matter of taste). 
Francesca will be probably the one i remember the most: the well and soft spoken cliche healer-lady with a quite "expressive" other side. the VO hear nailed the role just perfectly.

visualy it's quite pretty. the level design has it's ups and downs, but there is real sunning places, especialy when light effects, etc. come into play and the art-team let go. woodland areas, mystical (Runebarrows) dungeons, desert oasis: it's a gigantic world. the 2D-Art is spotless. animations are also great and the magic'n skills are often quite "cool", snappy and still nice to look at. the way enemies have been modeld can also look quite good: kinda 3D models with 2D texture ontop, almost looking like 2D-art come to 3D live. 
you can see videos and screenshots; art is always a matter of taste. i quite like the look of the game.

the OST is not as bold as Rising's OST was, but this comes mostly down to the fact that you "have" to listen to each track way longer. apart from this the OST an absolut masterpiece. at first you might not get how long some tracks are and how much they develope, some quite "normal" appearing indle town music might get a vocal chorus half way in between; a forest-biome starts out with kinda african/carribic rythms, to get some electronic tunes and finaly classical european music ontop. it's very well produced.

for the first 5 to 10 hours i wasn't very impressed. don't get me wrong it was still a good game, but after a certain point it just clicks, when some of the buildup has been done and you get more complexety-options for your party/equip and the world gets more filled with context'n lore. from that point foreward i absolutly love(d) the game.

i had a total of 0 technical issues, running on a HDD, a 3070 and i5 and 32GB, everyhing maxed and 1440p. stable FPS, no stutter and very quick loading times.

on the negative side are some wonky translation issues, nothing gamebreaking or realy standing out, but you will encounter the odd line here and there and some (very rare) strange sounding VO-file-quality; 
also there's some fluff-party-banter (kinda the light version of a Tales game) outside of the voices stuff you get anyway, but it's postet to the lower left corner of the screen and is easy to miss on a big screen. 
for people who do not know how oldschool games worked: you will miss stuff, 100% without a guide, but i'd still recommend a first blind playthrough...it's kinda how this type of game was ment to be played and you got the option for multiple saves.

This game is more than just a spiritual successor to the famed Suikoden series of games, it is able to stand on its own while hitting all the notes of Suikoden, and with good reason! I have avoided spoilers but it features over 100 recruitable characters, each so far has fun and interesting personalities and fun moments. So far it features about 3 different mini games, A spinning top battle game, card game and culinary battle mini game. Unsure if there is more, this review is written at about 17 hours of game play.

If you enjoyed the Suikoden series even in passing this game will be for you, combat isnt fact paced. It handles exactly like Suikoden right down to the combo attacks, My only gripe so far would be that the Lens system for magic misses some of the charm and awe that the runes had from Suikoden but thats a shallow gripe based on the aesthetic of the Lens vs the Runes that I loved so dearly. 

If you pine for an ps1 era rpg this will certainly scratch that itch, The story is solid, combat is interesting and many bosses WILL put you on your arse if you dont take them seriously. Music is good but not great, I havent heard any really memorable tunes yet that stick with me  but again only 17 hours in. 

I leave this review with one last note! There is a fishing minigame :P Its not bad, Just cast the rod and press A when a fish bites and bam, you catch it. No epic fish battles like Breath of fire 2 or Stardew valley! (And i think thats a good thing!)

[h1]TL;DR SCORE: 7/10[/h1]
I've been thoroughly enjoying it so far.  I'm something like [strike]60[/strike]180 hours in (completionist, just can't help myself) and all in all, it scratches that retro-styled JRPG itch very nicely.  It feels like a pretty decent successor to the PS1-era Suikoden games as well.

The localization does suffer mildly here and there. There's the occasional joke that doesn't land well, and a bit of less-than-stellar voice acting, but I can easily forgive those things given the budget dedicated to a game with so many individual characters that need unique voice acting.

[b]EDIT:[/b] I wanted to come back and touch on this review again now that I've finished the game.  With over 100 hours on it, given I'm working on getting the 'all achievements' achievement, I feel I have a far better feel for the game now than when I originally reviewed.

The game's script picks up a fair bit around the start of the second act, and a lot of my favorite moments are from that point onwards.  The story itself seems to lose a bit of steam right at the end, it almost feels like they realized how long the game was and figured they needed to wrap it up, but they hadn't sorted out a particularly graceful way of doing so.

The minigames are also, by and far, the weakest part of the game.  Even the best of the bunch, the card game, makes you play way, WAY too much of it for the trophy given how shallow it is.  Even if you manage to make every round of it take only three minutes, it's going to amount to 6 full hours of a game that has very, very little real strategy and no need to change strategy between rounds, since what your opponent does has little to no bearing on what you do.

It's pretty clear the game suffered from some pretty serious bloat thanks to obligations from the Kickstarter they decided to put as stretch goals.  I was telling somebody that, were I to rate the game on a 1-10 scale, I'd probably put it at 7/10.  But if they actually stripped out all the minigames and the poorly implemented war mode, I'd actually kick it up to an 8/10.

If you can play it in japanese or don't at all care about story or dialogue I'd reccomend it. If not, Id wait for a fan translation or a retranslation of the game if the company does one. Now on to the rating.

I find this one hard to rate accurately. Its an overall good game, but the localization kills it for me. You can argue its bad writing and not the localization choices, but the issue still stands. A large portion of the dialogue comes off as overly childish or jarring. Along with quite a lot of repetitive phrases. It frequently pulled me out of the experiece due to how odd or just bad it was. Another argument I've heard a lot is  "all JRPGs have cringe", and while I disagree sure there have been several JRPGs that had odd or hammy/cringe lines but not as frequently or in some cases as bad. The English voice acting cycles between being good for some character to either sounding exceptionally bored or just downright awfull I cant tell if thats due to direction or what. Japanese voicing sounded solid for all the lines I've heard so far.

Ignoring the dialogue, the games pretty good. There are the normal mechanics you would expect with a JRPG, along with many minigames, etc. Getting more and more heros is intersting it gives a solid amount of choices for party comp. There are some oddities with some mechanics like the lack of info on exactly how far the range of chars attacks were but it looks like there is a short medium or long identifier now at least that seems  clear enough. As well the length it takes to get random encounters in some areas being very long. Nice when you want to get from a to b, but terrible when grinding. Plus you unlock teleportimg later so it seems even more odd to lower the encounters that much. There are supposedly some issues with recruitment, but I haven't ran into any yet I don't think they also seem to be getting fixed with patches. As well as there are some text mistakes for names in the bestiary and menus. The minigames aren't exactly complex, but are they're fun enough and are a nice add to the game. The story is alright. Mind you I haven't finished the game yet so I can't give a complete review of the story. Its pretty standard jrpg territory, though so far the story isn't really that complex. There are bits of lore to look for as well so world building is pretty solid. The design is phenomenal, some may disagree, but I really liked most of the areas Ive seen so far as well as many if the character designs. I also just have a soft spot for 2.5d games. 

Overall its a decent game. It does somethings better than other JRPGs even. It just seems to be held by the terrible localization. If I totally discount the localization I could probably reason giving it a 7.5 or an 8 out of 10. Pretty good but definitely not perfect and shows the designers put in effort. With the localization it drops down to roughly a 4 out of 10. It just really ruins the flow and overall feel of the game. As someone who focuses on story and dialogue that just kills the game for me. 

As for not rating it higher i almoat never rate games higher than a 7 or lower than a 3. On a 1-10 5 is just a normal fine game 9 and 10s are exceptional to literally perfect and anything less than 4 is terrible to basically unplayable at 1. 

So yea to be generous a 4.5/10.

    [*]The story is quite predictable, and it feels like a solid third of it had to be cut out at some point. Characters are introduced at the end that feel like they're from parts of the game that don't exist anymore.
    [*]On a similar note, there's only really one main character despite what the key art shows. Seign and especially Marisa don't have enough time spent on them (probably why the DLC chapters exist, same with Markus.)
    [*]Having over 100 characters to recruit ironically makes the game feel smaller than ones with less playable characters. So many hint at areas you never visit, or don't fit with the playable areas at all. 
    [*]Combat is very dull. Just set to auto then forget, especially in the late-game.
    [*]Most minigames are just unfun time sinks. Card game is decent enough, but not to the point of doing it over 100 times.
[/list]

制作组介绍页面的原文是 【以现代风格向玩家再现经典的JRPG游戏】

JRPG黄金年代的复古设计堂堂登场（喜忧参半），实际上就是暗雷+老式固定位置存档机制+背包捡垃圾限制+王道白开水剧情。粉丝众筹意味着一切都还原20年前的老旧设计。前期节奏相当慢，整个游戏2倍速玩起来刚刚好。
目前最大的雷点是简中翻译有很大的问题。只能用繁中。
但是经典的108将建设梁山这种设计应该会让人暂时克服一切困难原地糕潮吧！

更新：长达14小时的坐牢体验之后，我的1300度粉丝滤镜和情怀滤镜被击碎。
对曾经幻想水浒传的拙劣复制，看不到任何对游戏制作的热爱和态度。
粉丝众筹想要圆梦再见到老IP是吧，直接复制粘贴，没有任何设计和对自己作品的爱，隔了二十多年原封不动的照搬一切设计，没有核心卖点的强化，也没有对不足的改进，也没有把当初没能来得及实现续作就被科乐美雪藏IP的不甘转化成养料。  纯粹的照搬。纵使是超级神作也经不起时间的淡化，更何况再当初就是小众作品的幻水。

作为粉丝众筹，第一要务当然是满足超级遗老，这方面只能说堪堪及格，你要的皮我全给你，但是核心丢失严重。
复古系统复古玩法也可以做得很有乐趣，而百英雄传只能说把最糟糕最简陋的东西还原了，gameplay部分可以说是让人晕晕欲睡毫无乐趣可言。

音画表现：3D背景+像素画面是为数不多的正向体验，不拖后腿，甚至可以说卖相还可以。前期大桥的对决在神秘运镜的加持下还有那么点表现力。音乐不难听，但也没到支撑起整个游戏记忆点的程度。这方面无疑是合格的，但距离佳作还有一段距离

地图设计：极致的无聊与简陋，无论大地图小地图还是迷宫都突出一个敷衍，我们的设计就是没有任何设计

战斗设计：哪怕放在二十年前也是在同行里垫底的那一档，严重拖后腿。可以说是摸到了回合制的触底下限，JRPG这么多年里好玩的设计有很多，但这么无聊的我已经很久没见过了。还别说莫名其妙的龟速战斗。 拉胯的后果是 连带着108将的队友核心卖点也变得食之无味，build特色的缺失导致队友收集的快感严重被削弱。

剧情表现：白开水中的白开水，诚然大家一直诟病的王道RPG爱与羁绊拯救世界这一套已经吃吐了，但即使是在白开水赛道里也是最脸谱化最普通的那一档。显得其他的白开水和这个一比都算是跌宕起伏有深度的有意思的了。

核心卖点的108星收集建设梁山泊环节：家园系统乐趣感很少，虽然做了但现在实在是觉得没把玩点做出来，前中期就是卡队友才能解锁基础功能，而且解锁了也没有显得很方便，大多数功能都是食之无味弃之可惜。基础功能-基础功能分支-效率提高  这一套整个七七八八就是几十个队友功能性工具人带过去了.最需求的传送不需要家园升级，但是拿到的时候已经是十几个小时坐牢过去了，内心毫无波动

队友的人设/立绘/存在感也是全方位的无聊，没有任何记忆点，极致的普通。初期这几十个走下来也就嘴臭牧师和一开打就闹麻了的马猴烧酒有点印象.

正常的粉丝向在核心驱动力的加持下，再多的缺点都可以靠粉丝滤镜和粉丝自适应无视掉，百英雄传目前全方位拉胯的体验让我想为这十几个小时体验里找些优点夸都夸不出口，可能只剩画面比预想的好.

我真的很喜欢这种每个队友都有用，都能招揽到麾下一起建设理想乡的氛围，作为半个幻水粉丝只能说非常遗憾，没能看到它容光焕发的一天。
good game ruined by bad translator or localization team. stop trying to insert cringe jokes and translate 1:1 as the original script.

I have not been updating my review recently but as far as I am aware no major patches have released since I finished the game.

The game is good overall, it is indeed what Suikoden fans were waiting save a few shortcomings BUT you need to know this game isn't actually finished! Not in the sense that the story isn't complete but in the sense that entire game mechanics and systems range from unpolished to completely broken.

THE BEST RECOMMENDATION I CAN GIVE YOU RIGHT NOW IS WAIT FOR A FEW PATCHES. 

I'm fairly certain I am going to change my recommendation into a positive one if the fix the biggest issues, all things that shouldn't have gotten past QA and should be easily solved by the devs in a reasonable timeframe. 
_____________________________________________

Here's a concise list:

- The scaling for all low level magic in the game is broken. They DO NOT do more damage depending on the character's magic attack attribute.

- The scaling for all team combos in the game is broken, apparently whatever damage the combo is supposed to do is reduced (divided by the number of characters participating). Therefore some combos hitting all the enemies are still somewhat viable for random encounters but any other is a net damage loss.

- Currently one character is easily and permanently bug-gable out of recruitment (one was fixed, one more remains).

- Text speed cannot be changed and it's slow (this makes the next point egregiously bad).

- On non-voiced dialogues tapping A/X on the controller skips any dialogue bubble entirely even if it's not finished yet! (in any other game your first input would fill the text and finish the sentence, allowing some time or waiting for a second input before skipping). 

- Battles and menus have weird wait times in which you're locked out of inputs, it adds up quickly in a game with un-skippable random encounters and constant menu navigation.

- The english localization is not great. Some use of puerile jargon, obscure wordplay, weird made up words that don't fit the game can be off-putting at times, especially in the beginning but it's not a disaster like people say.

- The way the camera follows you is inconsistent and often completely off, at times negating all vision while at times zooming out to no end. Weird and it takes you out of the experience.

- Any configuration of the battle plan for auto-battle that would take priority actions into account is broken. THE ONE THING you want to do when engaging with it, choosing priorities while avoiding MP consumption, is THE ONE THING you cannot even try to do because there is no option for that.

- The screen-shake cannot be turned off and the main character's first skill, which he will use in almost every battle, has the most obnoxious case of excessive and unnecessary screen-shake in the history of the genre. 
If you have photosensitive epilepsy but are usually ok with this kind of game, beware of this one.

- The Eggfoot racing minigame is the most evil timesink scam I've ever seen in a videogame on top of being one of the most boring. It's an insult to gamers and their time.

Played Suikoden I-IV, this is very much in the same vein, if it's the feel you're going for, this game has it. Those games had bugs and load screens galore as well and I'm glad the encounter bug and several others have been fixed. Keep an eye out for possibly recruitment bugs and game locks although I personally have not encountered any, fingers crossed they'll get to them.

Seems like devs can't please everyone with either old English translations (Unicorn Overlord) or more modern ones such as this. Do I like every character's "speech pattern"? No, but that's 100++ characters that can't end up all sounding alike and I did not love all of the old characters either. Suikoden did not have 100% perfect and 1:1 translation only, those games were localized as well. If you know Japanese, you can play in that language so that's an option.

There is politics and war and humor and comedy, like the other games, not sure if it will hit the drama of the Suikoden games, but I also don't know if that was the vision for this game or they just wanted to establish a lighter tone. There are other game directors that simply didn't want that dark tone in their later games, and I'm not sure if that's the case here.

My personal check(ed) list:
- Cooking plot
- Characters reacting to each other (bonus character selection / removal dialogue)
- Mini games
- Callbacks to Suikoden (character archetypes, mechanics, dialogue, and the return of a name)
- Theater
- Character investigation
- Bathhouse interactions
- Silly dialogue choices characters react to
- Silly hero combos

Overall  ---> 8.5/10

Great Start for a New Franchise  that in my eyes is most definitely a spiritual Successor of an old franchise

Excited to see what the future has in store for this Franchise.  It may even be able to stand on it's own. Without fame from previous franchise.

I did make a lot of comparisons to the Suikoden Franchise, and I apologize if that comes across as a bit harsh.

Gameplay  ---> 9/10

The first hour or slow is a bit slow as are most Suikoden Games, but once you start getting access to the Base/more features open up, the gameplay starts to pick up as well. It is a pretty classic (Not Generic) JRPG aside for the Suikoden styles Staples, and nothing wrong with that.

Story  ---> 9/10

Story is exactly what you would expect from a Suikoden Game, I only took off a point because it's not as dark as most other Suikoden Games, but completely understandable. Different standards today, and I am not sure if it would be a smart choice to make it so dark, I just prefer darker stories. I won't get much into the story to prevent spoilers, but if you have played Suikoden Games, you know what to expect. Warring Factions, Leading An Army, Uniting People.

Graphics --->  9/10

I love the 3D Backgrounds and the Art Style.  It really feels like eye candy sometimes, and it's beautiful.

Sprites are HD2D , to give you that Classic Suikoden Feel.  My only nitpick here is just that some of the environment is inaccessible when you should be able to go there (invisible barrier.)


Music/Sound ---> 8/10

Don't get me wrong, it's still got some pretty great tracks that are very catchy, but it's hard to beat  the Suikoden OST for me. I grew up on it. Suikoden was like Celtic Medieval music, almost impossible to top that for me personally.


Translation ---> 8.5/10

I love it,  it's like any other JRPG from the 90s, so if you didn't grow up on it, you might not enjoy it as much as some.

It can be silly and over the top at some times, but that never bothered me. I grew up watching English Dub Dragonball and Digimon , and playing games like Lunar.

There is some wild overblown hate going on right now over the localization because of a few sentences/words. It's nowhere near as bad as the claims & accusations

Polish ---> 7/10

More Polished than the first Suikoden Game, that's for sure, but it does lack the polish of future Suikoden Games. Nowhere near as polished as Suikoden 3/5.  

There are definitely a handful of nitpicky things with some of the mechanics and UI Designs but nothing major.

Not a fan the way the damage numbers appear in battle. Wobbling down to up. Also prefer that each  hit of a single attack has a different Damage number  instead of just showing the total damage after each hit.  Hero 1st Hit does 5 damage, 2nd hit does 8 damage, but damage number shows 5 than 13 instead of 5 than 8.)

Like I said, most of the issues I have are silly nitpicks like this. Nothing that actually takes away from the enjoyment.

To the racists: Yes, there are black characters in Eiyuden. As there were in Suikoden. Suck it up, or don't. There are also lycans, a bag and a whole host of other, weirder things. There are racists in the game too, but they're kinda the bad guys, as they were in Suikoden (Falena for Falenans). You probably won't like it.

For the normal people: It's definitely Suikoden's spiritual successor. If you've played those games, you will be on familiar territory. Thus far, all the things I was once amazed to find and explore the first time I picked up a Suikoden, I'm happy to find once again in this.

I will say, thus far the one thing I feel I sort of "lack" is a sense of... threat? But I also reckon I have much more left to experience. However, when I played Suikoden 5 (most freshly in my mind), I remember feeling a little bit worried for many characters. A sense of looming, possible danger (reinforced when one of my decisions got a character I quite liked killed). Thus far, I feel nothing like that in Eiyuden.

Oh, and Lian is annoying as all hell, but that's just par for the course. I hated Nanami and Lyon as well, so I always expect there'll be a manic pixie glued to the main character for me to hate until I can get her offed or benched permanently.

As for negatives... some animations and graphics look a bit odd? I dunno how else to put it. And then some things, like the pop-ups when fishing and some interface stuff feels sluggish and slow and not snappy/responsive. That alongside repetitive and shouty voicelines make some side-activities (like fishing) kinda annoying. And one time the game froze on me, a few minutes after a boss-fight, before I'd been able to get to a save point. The autosave triggers pretty darn rarely, so I ended up having to kill the game and re-do the boss.

Anyways, I'm loving the game, as a fan of Suikoden. Make of that what you will.

A very flawed gem suffering from way too many technical issues.

I wish I could recommend this game; I truly do. There are so many things to like here, but the flaws, bugs, and non-functional features make it hard to recommend.

The developers have left multiple progress-breaking bugs in the game and are very slow to address them. Loading screens are everywhere, and there is no frame cap in the game, except for half refresh rate V-sync or full refresh rate V-sync (aptly named as 30fps and 60fps caps in the game settings). Thus, one needs to use RTSS or another frame-limiting software to cap the fps. Otherwise, if you play in windowed mode, you will see 1000 fps. You know something is missing when both the opening intro and credits are bugged and unfinished.

Many game systems do not work as intended or are bugged or even outright broken.

The game's core revolves around collecting multiple heroes. Unfortunately, quite a few recruitment events are bugged and require either a workaround, a mod, or a patch to complete. There are also quite a few recruitment quests that are time-gated, so prepare to spend hours recruiting just a single character.

The game does not explain anything, so be prepared to check the game's help menu to understand what is going on.

Localization has received a lot of criticism from others. It's passable, but the English script differs from the Japanese script. The English script contains many typos, even with something as basic as "your" vs. "you're." The English voice acting is horrible. I do recommend switching to Japanese voice acting, which is better but suffers from a really bad audio mix, as does the rest of the game.

When the game is good, it really is enjoyable. Collecting a vast array of characters and building your own city feels rewarding. The story is pretty mediocre—it’s not bad, but it’s so forgettable that it’s a shame the characters aren’t utilized better. Almost all of the characters are underused, and even if you want to build your own party, most of the game restricts you to a few specific characters. It seems many elements were cut from the final product, leading to some odd dialogue both early and very late in the game.

Wait until the developer, if ever, fixes most of the issues, and this game could be much better. At this point, it's a solid 7/10.

*Game completion edit: 100% recommend. For all it's faults, it's an amazing title that I'd throw up there with the likes of Grandia, Star Ocean, Suikoden of course, and more. Whether you're comparing the storytelling, the art direction, the gameplay, or the side stories/quests and optional things, it's toe to toe with any of those and excels in many regards. Alright so having played the game far longer and have better grown my understanding of the base mechanics of the game. I would like to clarify some things and change my overall opinion about some of these mechanics. 


1. This game gets in it's own way when it comes to some of the mechanics. If you for example use a fire rune to buff a teammate, what it does is it adds fire type damage to the weapon. This scales off of the characters Mag Atk stat and that's why you'll see +1's a lot of the time when you think that buffing the melee characters just added static fire damage. 

2. It also doesn't really explain the party slots all that well. While not available all the time due to the story, you can often put mandatory party characters into the three attendant slots on the far right. So if you wanted to never use the MC in battle you can avoid it for large portions of the game. 

3. Some of the abilities that the middle slot of your party, support are really vague as to what there benefit will be. What's sorta of extra lame is you locked a movement speed buff to one. I'm the guy that kept the Godspeed rune in the entire game with me as well. That's more of a me complaint though. I also think there could've been a few swaps in the support/fighter roster as well. 

4. As of this updated review, the cooking minigame is still bugged and treats every round as an appetizer round, so you can Omelet, Miso Soup, and Marinated Seafood your way through every single culinary match so this entire side story is sort of a wash since there's no real engagement with the actual minigame portion for me.

Still, with these complaints they did really do an excellent job. The story is as good as it's spiritual predecessors and they did an excellent job making pretty much every character unique. There's a few tropes here and there but it's impossible not to with the amount of characters there are. I do think they could have made "alternate routes" to earn some characters if say for example you *hated* the beigoma side game as some do, just let us drop 300k on the character you get from finishing it instead as a work around. Just my thought though.

I played with Japanese dub as I heard the english dub is pretty bad so no comment on that. The Japanese VA's did an excellent job though. This is still a 100% recommend if you like JRPG's or ever played/enjoyed the Suikoden games.






Previous Review: 

Alrighty, a proper JRPG. 

There's a lot of dissent about the quality of this game looking at the reviews of others. Really it is going to boil down to a pretty simple question. What do you enjoy about playing a video game? If it's story, this hits. If it's visuals, this hits, if it's customization it can sorta hit, if it's about freedom, this game will not hit. 

It's a JRPG. a Japanese style, role playing game. Why is the J, in JRPG significant? Well, usually it's due to the nature of the game, and the "numbers up good" feels that come with it. There is grind, there are loopholes, and there are ways to break it. Just like any other JRPG, like the Chrono series, the Final Fantasy series, so on, so forth. All JRPG's.

This is the spiritual successor to the series of Suikoden. Some may agree, some not. Nevertheless with my play time, I genuinely feel like I'm playing a Suikoden game. This isn't always a good thing though. 

I remember when I first played Suikoden as a kid. It was wild. So many party members, so many interesting folk, so many combos of party members. It was wild. I loved it, and I love this. Full stop.

This does not mean there aren't flaws. I will follow up with the things I do not like about the game currently.

1. Limited inventory space, but a need to gather - Fuck this combo. If you want me to gather shit give me the fucking inventory to carry it. Fuck you and your 30 slots for items. If you're going to limit inventory space, then give some kind of method to quickly improve the situation. I shouldn't be juggling healing herbs, runes, and equipment like this, 11 HOURS into the game. It's idiotic and bad game design. You fucked up on this part of making it too similar to old school RPG's. Inventory management is *not fun* for most anyone. It's not a quirk, it's not a good choice, it's not challenging, it's fucking annoying. You already balanced against healing item abuse in how you do combat. I'll come back to this.

2. You hid a bunch of fucking characters. Time and again I fucking *hated* this about Suikoden. You've created a situation where players have to go to all of the locations on the map over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over and over, and over between every. single. fucking. story bite. Don't want to miss anyone, because you old Suikoden developers taught me early on that if I don't recruit everyone, Gremio dies for good (reference to Suikoden 1. No spoilers, except for Suikoden 1.). I do not like your visuals, your cities, or your dungeons, jungles and mazes enough to do this between every story bite. It's exhausting. Maybe it gets better later on, but at 11 hours all I have seen is evidence of the opposite. 

Beyond this though, it's a fucking excellent JRPG. It hits all of the notes. The story *so far* moves at a good pace. It lets you infer and make easy guesses as what's going to happen early on, but from there the tropes start to become less relevant. The characters are so far pretty well written and made. The story has been good so far, too. I am invested. 

Combat. It's easy. I've been playing on hard so far, and only the boss fights really have any difficulty. Nevertheless, you can grind out a win regardless of how you play simply because of the JRPG numbers up system. The visuals are good, the Hero combos are good, and there's plenty of surprises as to who can combo with who, but that said *make it easier to find these combos*

I do appreciate they add a "you're too strong for these guys, lets bounce" option once you're overlevelled for a guaranteed run from an encounter. I have seen that there are FAR less encounters on 60 fps versus 30. So congrats on using dated technology for rpg encounters in a new rpg I guess. Still, the good comes with the bad. 

Overall though, This game takes me back to my roots of playing video games. These frustrating things that I mention were the norm when I was younger. I'm used to it. The reviews show that many are not. There's a middle ground, and this company could reach it with a few patches.
Loving it - Been waiting for something like this for one or two decades.
