This game brings me straight back to the good old days of Suikoden 1&2! So far, I am having tons of fun playing the story and while I can recommend buying the game, here are some details for pros and cons:

Pros:
-beautiful art style
-voice acting is surprisingly good, even the English ones (the THEATHER MODE is genius. Try it out, do it Anakin!)
-well known & entertaining battle mechanics with tons of interesting combos (party members, hero combos, runes, etc.)
-beautiful music
-interesting characters / personalities & story (while being a bit similar to Suikoden 2 in particular)
-low running speed can be dealt with via items and/or support-slot heroes

Cons:
-a bit slow at the start with many mini-cutcenes that can get a bit annoying at times
-the sudden running animations while everything moves at normal speed (e.g. fire in background) are disturbing any immersion and are quite silly/ distracting
-grinding is a bit slow since monster encounters are taking a bit of time until they spawn (good for exploring, bad for targeted leveling)
-some illogical things, e.g. a mine cart blocking a way... climb in it/ over it? Or how running straight next to a soldier makes him not spot you during stealth missions. Or... being wanted and running around freely, even talking to enemy soldiers in cities.
-the running animation when you walk feels weightless. There are no foot prints, no sounds, no dust, nothing. It feels like you would figure skate / slide over the ground.
-cooking minigame is bugged
-magic is too weak and MP costs are too high to use it regularly
-routes are linear & open world feels EXTREMELY empty
-yeah yeah, translation issues are well-known by now but I am not talking about that woke/ anti-woke nonsense. Some translations are outrageously wrong (I play with Japanese voices and English texts). I get it that some Japanese expressions cannot be properly translated since there is no equivalent, but the interpreters went into completely different directions for no reason. One example: In Japanese, they say 'uh, sou da ne' which means 'uh, right' but the English text reads as (paraphrasing since I didn't take a screenshot) 'yes, the three of us will have our backs!'. Makes general sense in the context the scene is presented in but very liberally translated... not the only one but the most recent I remember. Nothing game breaking but irritating and ruining immersion when you hear and read two completely different things.

Love the original two Suikoden games? Well then, this game is for you. If you do not like JRPGs, or the Suikoden series, then skip on this. Eiyuden Chronicle Hundred Heroes is made for the fans, and the developers have made that really clear. 

Sometimes I play games that are supposedly spiritual successors of other games that I loved, and I feel underwhelmed by the spiritual successor. Like I can see how and what they went for, but they failed to capture the essence. This game does NOT fail to capture the essence. It quite literally feels like a Suikoden game. Sometimes I forget I'm not playing Suikoden, and that is a great feeling.

Edit: Oh, I forgot to mention, it's much, much better with Japanese voice acting. Don't get me wrong, some of the western voice actors are okay, and even good in some cases but the western localization kind of sucks. What's bad is that when you understand the Japanese there are times when you read the English and you're saying, "that's not what they said". Unfortunately, there is no option for Japanese characters, just voices, or I wouldn't waste time with the English text at all. All things being fair, I just wanted to disclose that before you decide to buy.

*This review is based on having played the closed beta and 20 hours of the full released game*

It's hard not to constantly compare Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes to the beloved Suikoden series (1 and 2 in particular). I've been a fan of the games for as long as I can remember and am one many who've waited for a sequel to Suikoden. Although we never got it, we have be fortunate enough to experience Eiyuden Chronicle. 

- The visuals are truly stunning. Eiyuden manages to combine tradition with modern and does it effortlessly with gorgeous, colorful backgrounds, mixing 2D sprites with 3D elements. 
- The music has been both soothing and epic when it calls for it, creating a sense of adventure.
- My first War battle had me nervous, haha, but I quite liked what they've done with it and can imagine just how epic it would be as things progress with the story and you control more units in a larger scale.
- The voice acting has been a mix for me - there are some I REALLY love, and others.... could either use some work or perhaps have a mute button for, lol. But overall they've done a fantastic job with the variety of ethnicity in the characters and their voices.
- Eiyuden has outdone it with the Castle and the amount of things you can do with it. I can certainly see this giving players hours and hours of gameplay just trying to improve and build on it. Not to mention the sheer number of side things that can keep you occupied (fishing, farming, guild/hunting/missions, card game, collecting all the cards, etc.) A huge highlight for me for sure.

Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes is truly a love letter from Murayama-sensei and team to all of us Suikoden fans.

overall, a solid 3.5/10 game, would not recommend, it was not worth the 4 year kickstarter wait, and it is insulting to claim this is a "spiritual successor to suikoden." i am actually upset at this game.

Overall: While it won't set the world on fire Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes is a competently made game from a veteran team at a reasonable price point. Even if you aren't a fan of the Suikoden series from which it derives its a solid traditional JRPG in its own right that will entertain you for its forty plus hour run time if you can get past its flaws. A definite buy even at full price, especially the Digital Deluxe Edition which gives you both the soundtrack and a season pass for just three dollars additional.

Pros:
[+] Combat: It might be turned-based but its extremely busy. You have six characters to play with at a time, each of whom will have four to six runes slots, plus combat gimmicks, initiative positions, formations, teamwork attacks and support characters. Regardless of how you play you'll have plenty to do and customize once the game hits its stride at around Level 10-14.
[+] Presentation: While its not Cyberpunk 2077, the game is beautiful; The use of 3-D backgrounds and forced perspective coupled with very expressive and highly detailed 2-D sprites gives the game storybook feel, as if it were playing out on a pop-up diorama.
[+] Music: Both Naruke and Sakurabe are industry veterans with impressive resumes (Dark Souls, Tales of Destiny, Wild Arms, etc) and they deliver a solid soundtrack that is a joy to listen to. Getting the soundtrack as part of the Digital Deluxe edition was a real treat though unfortunately it isn't the Complete Soundtrack, only covering the first third of the game.
[+] Size: Setting aside the plot and the titular hundred heroes, there is a lot to do in the game; Exploration, base-management, a half-dozen minigames and collectibles.

Neutral:
[~] Traditional JRPG: Eiyuden Chronicle is definitely done in the vein of the JRPGs of the 80 and 90s. Meaning it does not have many of the conveniences that modern players have gotten used to; There's no hand holding when it comes to the mechanics or missable content, points of no return/lock-in pop up out of nowhere, resources are always tight, no fast travel, healing is sparse, fights can be unforgiving, dungeons can be really long and save points can be few and far between (Heck you can't even save on the World Map!).

Cons:
[-] Localization: Even a cursory glance at the Steam forums will tell you this is a massive issue for a lot of “players,” many of whom have sworn that they won't buy the game unless Rabbit and Bear redoes the entire thing to be faithful to the original Japanese text but really its just another overblown manifestation of the culture wars sweeping the industry. While there are indeed some Americanisms, like Mio's infamous gender joke or Lian's use of the word “chud”, it does not really appreciably its characters or its story. All told its more akin to Tidus' Macarena joke in Final Fantasy X than the completely unhinged ADV dub of Ghosts at School. Of greater concern are mistranslations that actually impact the game, whether causing needless ambiguity in the game's mechanics or UI and, in at least one occassion, providing outright wrong information (Reyna's recruitment condition). 
[-] Dubbing: Clearly this aspect of the game was remotely done and was impacted by its slim budget because while voice acting for the main characters voices are passable, the side character VA's performances are uneven. Some VA's just can't act or at least did not receive any direction from the studio (like Francesca) while others' have been subjected to atrocious sound-mixing (example Cassandra), resulting in delivery that is off-key, garbled or overly loud.
[-] Underdeveloped Mechanics: While as mentioned there is a lot to do, its pretty shallow. Many of the mini-games are mechanically simple (heck fishing is just hitting a button when an exclamation point shows up) and some of the new systems added like castle-building are ultimately just pointless fetch quests used to pad out the game. Of special note is the War-system which is a definitive step back from Suikoden II and V, both of which gave you the ability to customize unit rosters and unit types while fighting on a large game board with Advanced Wars style special abilities. In contrast the current iteration has more or less degenerated into a scripted shoving match.
[-] Technical Issues: The game has quite a few, mostly borne out of having adapt to simultaneous console releases. Though most have been patched, several still remain to be addressed like ghost inputs on joyticks for controllers, non-rebindable keys on MKB and noticeably slow menu speeds.
[-] Bad UI Communication: This game has a lot of mechanics. Unfortunately many of them are either hidden from the UI or unexplained in the Help menu (they don't even tell you what the character's stats do!). For example, the game doesn't tell you that all characters have affinities for the six spell elements in the game but nowhere does it appear on the individual characters' sheets. So might end up giving a favorite mage a bad element and they end up underperforming for seemingly no reason.
At least we meet again!!! Buy, play, enjoy, and have fun.

RIP to one of my childhood greats, Yoshitaka Murayama. 
Even though you're gone and you never got to witness the full release. I'm glad at the very least you manage to finish creating your magnum opus as your legacy. So much love and passion put into what's essentially a spiritual successor to Suikoden (let's not beat around, THIS is Suikoden 6). A series that I still hold close to my heart as the JRPG series that influence a large part of my life growing up.

With many legends along the way to help bring this passion project alive, such as legend music composer Hiroyuki Iwatsuki and Koji Igarashi (director of Castlevania and creator of the Bloodstrained series). Who helped his former Konami colleagues on the Suikoden side of things (to pattern the framework/strategy they've used when they kickstarted Bloodstained by the way). It's no surprise that said mentioned former colleagues would be on this project as well thanks to Iga, like Junichi Murakami (art/director of Castlevania and writer for Maken X). Not just him, but the other original creators of Suikoden, Junko Kawano and Osamu Komuta in order to help give us a classic JRPG (Suikoden) experience.

Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes is a testament to what made the Suikoden series great, politics, drama, war, love and hope, themes that were certainly not unheard of nor where they revolutionary during the late 90's/early 20's in the JRPG scene, but what was revolutionary was how a series like Suikoden presented these themes and the frantic battle system of having six star of destiny strategically placed on the grid-field, it still remains one of my favorite battle systems in the genre and I'm so glad to see it's still present all thorough Eiyuden Chronicle. Same goes for the series trademark 1 on 1 duels, dramatic showdowns that made the player felt like an important part within a much larger conflict and those massive tactical warfare scenarios that had you command an entire army on the field. It can't go without saying but even though there's some quality of life changes in place that not only help new players who are not familiar with JRPG's but also make the combat/U.I navigation run as smooth as possible when your grinding. This game was by created by developers with a very old-school philosophy in mind, back when JRPG designs didn't have these QOL improvements that you see in modern JRPGs. For most modern gamers, this will definitely feel out of place of familiarity Since there's no hand holding, no direction, no guide on how you should play. You'll often be left blindly experimenting and hoping for the best through trial and error along the way. To me, this is right up my alley. 

Party experimentation is also part of the fun, with over 100+ characters to recruit (all with their own goals, motives and choices for joining your cause) certain party members can also team together that (if they have emotional attachment to one another) can do some really neat looking tag-finishers, and sometime, will defend other party members if their HP is low enough and will continue to defend them till the party member heals themself. Much like Suikoden, if it's you're first time to this type of game where you have hundreds of members to pick from. The game may start to feel a bit overwhelming for you when you're deciding rune/team setups and it'll require you to really think outside the box on how you should abuse the game's system to your advantage. 

With that said, there's also the elephant in the room that must be addressed. Something that's been a known issue with many localized Japanese titles since the 80's. Unfortunately this time it was at the hands of the translation team bastardize of a localization that betrayed/disrespected all the hard work Murayama's team has created. 
The local writers (who had no respect for the original writer) made major changes that deviates way too far from the original script. Because of this blunder, this might well be the nail in the coffin for many people who wanted to try this game. In my opinion, if you don't mind the American slang sprinkled here and there, then I still recommend on trying the game as the story/game-play is very enthralling despite it's shortcomings with some odd character identity choices due to poor localization. If the English dialogue is that insufferable, best option I could recommend is to switch to Japanese, since the voice work, although not the best, it's tolerable enough. There's also another thing that's been bugging me. The complete lack of ambient sound. No audio identify that move through the world, the same applies for character making inaudible footsteps, no weapon/armor clinks and changes either? Overtime it starts to become off-putting once you begin to focus on it. Also, the maps themselves, as you explore a town, dungeon, zones etc, there's no real ambiance either. It's just a music track that plays, that's it. There's also this weird audio artifacts. Like the music not fading out/transitioning correctly when you're moving between different areas. Character voices will be far louder than another, some will suddenly have way more bass to their line compared to their previous comment.

After 100% the game, there's also another glaring issue about this game.

Because of power scaling and inaccurate damage calculations, this game is in dire of a balance fixes. Much skills (like magic) are either downright terrible mid/early game or not worth using at all, like using hero combo. So much so that it's flat out better to do a normal attack than wasting SP trying to do a combo that does 2-digit damage. As for magic users, using water/wind runes are the only thing worth using early/mid game. Just for the heal/speed buffs. Honestly though, healing spells have set numbers that heal for and won't increase through stats so healers are pointless when you can just bring items that do the same job. MP consumption cost is so instantly high, does so little damage and MP replenish items are so rear to come by that there's very little reason to use magic till late game. Because magic gets a astronomical damage boost once you hit level 60+ and a lot of this reason is because of the broken damage formula and nearly all late game enemy encounter are weak to magic, funny enough. Again, all these issues can be rectify with a simple balance patch so I hope that the devs haven't given up on improving the game because there's still a lot of great things that keeps combat engaging.                                     

Although the voice acting can be iffy at best,camera work can be awkward in moments where you NEED to see things in the background but with an amazing soundtrack, beautiful 2.5D visuals, compelling narrative and an engaging combat system that brings out the best elements of Suikoden to this game. You can tell Murayama team tried to bring the magic back and fulfilled what was promised to long time fans of the series/genre.   

Edit: As of now, there's a mod that fixes all the grammar error and "corrects" all the slang from the English translation.

Being a day one backer who was one of the handful of people that got a copy free, I hold no regret. It was such a wild ride watching this game's development over the course of a few years and being able to participate on such a monumental passion project. I'm happy I was able to be part of the journey. Hopefully the studio will continue to improve/fix some of these glaring aspects overtime and also take the criticism and make the sequel even better. It does sadden me greatly knowing the translation team spit in the face of Murayama's legacy-title. I just hope the journey to bring this game to life, and the knowledge that it "made it through" brought him some measure of contentment and pride. Reviving a classic with any degree of respect these days is damn near necromancy. For that, I owe him much respect and for the game he created. 

Sleep well Murayama, you deserve the long rest.

As of writing this review I'm about 3/4 through the game (will update when done) and I'm happy to report that the years of waiting were worth it!

Eiyuden has the classic turn-based JRPG feel, slightly revamped. The graphics are a gorgeous 2/3D mix and the music's been stuck in my head since day 1. The story touches on the same themes as their previous games so the overall direction of it seems fairly predictable if you've played them, but I'll add the caveats that A) I'm not done with it yet and B) if you were hoping this would be a spiritual successor to those games this should be fine, since an actual successor to those games would have been just as formulaic. The story takes a while to ramp up but has been quite enjoyable, with the most epic moment to this point leaving me breathless and on the verge of tears from how much my heart was aching at what was happening.

I was worried before playing that I wouldn't get attached to the characters since I didn't like a few of the designs, but playing the game alleviated those fears for me almost instantly. I've fallen in love with most of them and haven't found a recruitable I dislike yet. Some characters get only a cursory introduction while recruiting them and some get a full quest, but even if they were one of the minor ones, if you bring them with you you'll get to know them via their battle lines and them speaking up at random points in the story. If you like collecting characters but want to avoid gacha games, this is the game for you.

Speaking of characters, you can bring *every* character with you, even the ones that can't fight; there's a support character system where non-fighters will grant you passive effects and count as in your party, so they'll also chime in during story moments. The story will also often require you to have certain characters in your party but there's a 'reserve' party system that you can shunt a character into if you don't actually want to use them, and they'll still count as 'with you' for story purposes instead of occupying a party slot. It's a great system that avoids player frustration with being forced to use characters they don't have built or find clunky, but also avoids immersion-breaking moments where a character that's not actually with you pops up out of nowhere.

If you're the type to do all the turn based fighting yourself, you'll love customizing party compositions and rune-lens layouts to find the perfect team for you and the perfect strat for the job. If that's not your thing, there's a per-character customizable action plan that they can follow in battle on auto mode. Just don't expect to use it on tougher enemies/bosses, since those require particular strats. The boss Gimmicks are an interesting new way to add mechanics to boss fights and I've mostly found them enjoyable; the only exception thus far was a completely RNG one early on.

Duels are fun, you just have to pay attention to what the opponent says each round and mentally map it to an action so you can win. War battles are less fun, and the controls for them are a bit clunky, but I imagine they'll be up *someone's* alley that isn't mine, and may get better as I recruit more characters.

There have been a few minor typos in the text and an instance or two of someone using slang that felt a bit too modern, but those are the worst localization issues I've seen. Given that some of the characters straight-up look like they're wearing modern clothes, I wouldn't say it's any more out of place than some of the character design. Thankfully we're in the era of digital games with multiple language options, so if you dislike the localization, you're free to play the original Japanese version (which I assume you can do if you're complaining about the localization in good faith).

The game suffers a little from its Kickstarter origins since some of the backer names/tributes are immersion breaking. However there are also a lot of pets around as one of the Kickstarter goals, and the game bursting with adorable animals everywhere is more than enough to make up for that in my opinion.

The minigames all live up to what was promised and I've enjoyed most of them. Beigoma was a little difficult to get started on since it relies on monster drops but once you're in the swing of things it's fun. The cooking storyline is stuffed with awful puns and over the top drama that made me laugh so hard I woke up my spouse. (I say this as a positive).

HQ building has been smooth, and thankfully not grindy. It's incredibly fun seeing the castle build up around me and seeing where my recruited characters hang out. If you're missing materials there's a button you can hit on the blueprint screen that should show you where they can be found, but sometimes they're deeper in an area than you're allowed to go at a moment and it can give you a false sense of having access to the item just because the zone is unlocked.

Fast travel DOES exist and you'll unlock it later - make good use of the Dash Boots you find in an early dungeon to walk faster until then.

My personal biggest gripe with this game is that there's no option to lock the minimap facing north on the overworld map. That can easily lead to getting turned around while traveling.

Given that *that's*' my biggest issue, I think it's safe to say I'm more than satisfied with the game overall. It won't be for everyone (no game is) but it's something I can recommend to anyone that looks at the Store page and has their interest piqued by what they see. I'd rank this a solid 9/10, with the possibility of bumping up to 9.5 if some of the more easily fixable things get fixed.

This negative review is entirely off of the back of the localization. After reading a bunch of other negatives, people might get the wrong idea so it's important for me to emphasize. The quality of this games translation is bad. Embarrassingly bad. Your college professor would flunk the game outright.

To get more into detail, there are consistency issues with formatting, grammar, and characters. It starts pretty simple and balloons outwards. The least offensive is menu information.
[b] To emphasize again, these are things that would normally never even rise an eyebrow and are only included for completeness [/b]
[list]
    [*]Some moves state they affect 1 enemy (e.g; Inflict [X] damage to 1 enemy) 
    [*]Others effect one enemy (e.g; inflict [x] damage to one enemy).
    [*]Some state that they deal enemy  (e.g; Inflict enemy [X] damage)
    [*]Revival medicine states "Revives incapacitated ally and restores [X] HP
    [*]Superior Revival Medicine "Revives ally and restores [X] HP" (again, minor stuff)
[/list]

We get into more moderate things now. A tutorial states "you can plan new facilities for headquarters, raise headquarters funds, and harvest resources.
That last part is noteworthy as it's meant to say "increase harvestable resources". A passive function that happens through upgrading, and not a direct action you do.
[list]
    [*]Enemy bestiary has some enemies in Dappled Forest (which is what it should say) and 
    [*]Material Dungeon (Forest) which is ALSO Dappled Forest. (I originally thought this must have been a mistake in the Japanese script, so I swapped the language and no it correctly states the Sunny/Sunshine Forest.)
    [*]Enemy bestiary just makes up a location that doesn't exist
[/list]
There's also more than a few grammatical, typing, and punctuation issues but those are minor. The more important annoyance is the actually quality of the translation.
A certain amount of "creativity" is to be expected from a localization to have it flow well. The people localizing this game went above and beyond in an extremely poor fashion

[list]
    [*]Characters have new personalities contrary to what they're originally meant to be
    [*]Characters don't properly converse in side text anymore so a character saying something that a party member reacts to now has the party member saying something completely unrelated to the conversation
    [*]Character consistency is a bust in non main story content so the new invented personality they've made for one character (cool and reticent) has her morph into a country bumpkin in her barks in one of the minigames. 
    [*]The language used has many of the same phrases and "personality quirks" across multiple different characters from multiple different regions.
[/list]

The phrase "i'm here for it" is stated like 6 times by 8 different characters and whoever pucnhed up the script either didn't care or realize and even if they realize their limited pool of phrases show their limited expertise with language in general. Half the cast toss in southern/country nomenclature including when it's out of character for what they were changed to be. A prim officer of the empire has a line where she off handle brings steortypical southern dialect including a few 'darlings'. 

Entire personalities are either exaggerated or changed to the extent that they're completely unrecognizable to the characters they're even meant to be. This goes well beyond the scope of just taking liberties and encroaches into fan fiction.

In most lines of dialgoue both the intent AND conversation flow is completely different which re-contextualizes the characters motivations. A character who in the original script abhors war is now eager to participate in fights, for example. A stoic somewhat shady character is now turned into a hyperactive genki girl which is especially jarring when a conversation that includes her later on refers back to the stoic nature she no longer has. This is awful.

It's distressingly bad. I'm not a language nitpicker when it comes to localization. If the same intent of lines, events, and characters was even [b]loosely[/b] accurate to the original authors work we wouldn't be here. There are movie and pop culture sayings, references, and idioms inter-spaced all over the script. Characters who play a scene straight in a serious manner are now making language based puns and cackling in English.

I have quite literally never recommended against a game for it's localization before this point. This is the first game I've ever done this for. It's the English version of Breath of FIre II level's of incomprehensibly bad. 

Even now I [b]STILL[/b] don't want to get this game a thumbs down. Because in regards to aesthetics, feel, and some aspects of gameplay they nailed what they set out to do. But I can not in good faith blindly tell somebody to purchase this game in service of a script that is this distressingly awful.

Après 4 ans d'attente du Kickstarter, c'est une déception que j'éprouve avec un jeu particulièrement inégal sur bien des aspects, avec des pics de qualité ponctuels et des chutes bien basses.

Visuellement, le jeu brille tout particulièrement lors des combats, avec des sprites détaillés et variés pour chacun des personnages jouables qui réussissent à marquer leur individualité. Le tout couplé avec des animations réussies et de bons jeux de caméra pour rendre l'action plus dynamique. Les environnements peinent à tenir la cadence cependant, avec un jeu qui aime abuser d'effets de flou pour masquer la pauvreté de ses décors, notamment en donjon.

Stratégiquement, le jeu est malheureusement bien pauvre : la magie y est tristement faible, peinant à rattraper les dégâts des équivalents physiques et se fait violemment dépasser sur le soin par les objets qui sont abondants, peu chers et bien plus rentables. Un aspect qui a l'effet retors de vous pousser vers les compagnons orientés physique qui ont moins d'options à leur disposition. Même en Difficile, les rencontres aléatoires deviennent vite du bruit de fond alors que l'on délègue le jeu au combat auto. Les boss tendent à offrir des moments plus intéressants notamment via l'addition d'éléments interactifs pouvant influer sur le déroulement du combat. Ils tendent cependant à vite devenir des tests d'endurance qui durent bien plus longtemps que la sensation de nouveauté apportée par leurs gimmicks.

En parallèle, la customisation est particulièrement limité, avec trois (parfois quatre) slots d'équipements dont la plupart n'apportent que des statistiques défensives qui peinent à étendre les options stratégiques au delà de "mourir moins vite".

L'un des gros problèmes du jeu réside cependant dans le manque de fonctionnalités QoL qui amplifient drastiquement les points faibles du jeu. La navigation dans les menus est d'une lenteur abyssale avec des fondus en continu qui retardent des actions simples comme la manipulation d'équipement ou gestion de l'inventaire. Certaines informations ne sont disponibles qu'au fond de sous-sections de la fenêtre Statut qui cumule les tares. Mention spéciale à l'amélioration d'armes, qui vous fera voir la même animation impossible à accélérer, pour chaque niveau d'arme, pour chaque personnage. à noter par ailleurs que la gestion de l'équipement de membres hors de votre groupe n'est pas possible en début de jeu et uniquement auprès d'un certain PNJ plus tard, multipliant les manipulations lourdes si vous avez le malheur de vouloir changer votre équipe active. Un comble pour un jeu qui pousse introduit autant de personnages jouables.

Un autre problème, cette fois-ci durant les combats, est l'absence de vitesse rapide lors des combats voir de Skip d'animations. Absence qui met d'autant plus en exergue leur manque de variété lors des donjons, malgré un effort fait pour tenter d'accélérer les attaques standards en cumulant celle de plusieurs personnages au même instant si alignés. Problème d'autant plus décuplé lors des batailles de grande envergure plus loin dans le jeu, qui sont soporifiques et qui plus est bien moins belles à voir. La vitesse rapide serait aussi bien souhaitable pour les dialogues, tant le rythme de certains est glacial, avec des pauses bien marquées entre chaque bulle de dialogue pour la moindre animation.

La vitesse de déplacement initiale digne d'un octogénaire en plein jogging vient rejoindre les problèmes de lenteur des combats cette fois-ci pour l'exploration, vu que les donjons sont assez larges et plutôt vides. Un problème avec une semi-solution néanmoins, vu qu'un accessoire (que l'on peut rater ce dit-en passant, fouillez-donc bien la grotte...) vient enfin mettre un peu d'élan dans les jambes du protagoniste, après 4-5 heures de jeu. Ajoutez à cela que les sauvegardes ne se font qu'à des points spécifiques ou en transition vers l'overworld, et vous vous retrouverez assez vite à pester lors des donjons.

Parmi d'autres points plus mineurs, je noterai l'absence de reconfiguration des touches clavier, le manque de repères visuels sur la carte pour les éléments interactifs comme les téléporteurs, certaines features mal expliquées comme les runes ou encore l'impossibilité de voir les détails des magies et compétences octroyées par une rune avant de l'avoir équipée, sachant que cela n'est possible qu'auprès de certaines boutiques.

L'intrigue ne vole malheureusement pas très haut, la faute à un rythme discutable où l'on attend péniblement que l'histoire décide de commencer en passant par un bon nombre de poncifs du genre. La version française est également assez bancale, avec des sautes de ton parfois malvenus, d'autant plus si vous utilisez les doublages japonais (qu'il serait bête de manquer car de qualité) où des écarts choquants se forment entre les voix lors d'un dialogue et la traduction affichée. La traduction médiocre ne met malheureusement pas le cast en valeur : le personnage principal est dans un rôle tristement banal de "gentil qui veut être gentil" et ne va pas bien plus loin que ça. J'apprécie néanmoins la présence de certains choix d'options comiques lors de dialogues, souvent en rupture avec le personnage mais qui tendent à avoir des réactions amusantes de ses collègues. Lian devient très vite insupportable par son caractère et devient pire encore en doublage anglais. Seign est plus intéressant sur le papier, moins dans l'exécution. L'un des points décevants notamment autour du conflit politique est son côté très manichéen avec un empire très très méchant, dont les personnages recrutables se disent tous qu'ils sont du mauvais côté de la justice avant même que la guerre n'éclate. On attend alors juste que le revirement arrive sans grand suspens sur le pourquoi ou comment. Quant aux 120 héros recrutables, s'ils sont très distincts les uns des autres par leurs designs et voix, leur recrutement se rapproche plus de la quête FedEx dans laquelle pignouf_du_93 va vous exposer l'histoire de sa vie en un temps record de trois boîtes de dialogue avant de vous envoyer paître en plein désert récupérer 5 cailloux/tuer 3 sangliers/retrouver <être cher d'importance significative> (note:  le synopsis accéléré prend parfois lieu après la dite quête).

Une note positive cependant pour finir cette critique bien terne, la bande-son est superbe et brille principalement lors des combats, tendant à faire oublier la monotonie qui s'y installe rapidement. Les thèmes de certains boss sont des plus marquants que j'ai pu entendre dans un jeu vidéo et c'est un plaisir de les écouter dans le jeu comme en dehors.

EC:HH n'est pas dénué de qualités, mais il souffre autant de problèmes de forme que de fond qui tendent à se tirer mutuellement vers le bas. Si certains aspects liés à la QoL auront peut-être l'occasion d'être rectifiés par de mises à jour futures, il est difficile d'imaginer qu'il en sera de même concernant l'intrigue et le système de combat.

I'm going to review this without the Suikoden nostalgia glasses on.

I'll make this short and sweet; this game is a throwback to older, classical JRPGs. While it does have some modern QOL, it also still includes the older stuff. So yes, your inventory space is limited, and you will need to manage your items and magic usage. And I think some people are forgetting that JRPGs back in the days of Suikoden had the same idea.

The world and characters are charming and every bit a Suikoden game, with a lot of hidden easter eggs or throwbacks to previous character designs (Carrie vs Corselia).

There are some issues, of course. no game is without it's issues. Ignoring the giant elephant in the room (the English translation can be a bit overbearing at times, but I've enjoyed it for te most part), my gripes are more along the hand-holding the game does with your next objectives.

The game is VERY CLEAR on making sure you know where to go a lot of the time. It will tell you your current objective and stick a pin on the map. Up until a certain point where it asks you to find "someone to help you get to X" and then it just kinda stopped helping for a moment. With 0 hints on what to do.

The other issue I had was with regards to your base and the game never mentioning how to backtrack into the mine. And how the naming of the castle is done (FOR THOSE READING THIS, "LET ME THINK ABOUT IT" => GIVES 3 NEW NAMES!)


Overall, I think Eiyuden Chronicle is worth the money. It's scratching my classic JRPG itch, and I've played a ton of them. Just don't go in expecting a carbon copy of a Suikoden game; it pulls from all of them in a nod to them, but doesn't fully rip an entire game and rehash it to us in 2024.

This game is really the spiritual successor of Suikoden. As someone who grew up playing Suikoden from the get go, this game really sparked some needed flames in my heart especially since most of the games now lack the old-school flair of games like Suikoden. 

The game starts a little slow, slower than most Suikoden games. But it is to be expected as it is a new entry for the series. Imagine it being a combination of Suikoden 1 and 2 and a little bit of 5 due to how long the introduction is. 

Graphics: 8/10
Even before, Suikoden was not really cutting edge technology. Eiyuden Chronicle follows this train of thought. It's more about the gameplay, the intricacies, the world building, and the characters. Do not get me wrong, for the art style that they were going for, this is a homerun. It is not for everyone though, which is why I gave it this score. There are also some visible camera glitches here and there on release.

Music: 7/10
I like Eiyuden's music, do not get me wrong. It just didn't hit home run with me as much as the first 2 Suikoden did. I never had a "I need to have that music" moment or I love that music, I'll look at it on Youtube kind of thing. It fit the atmosphere and the vibe of the game, it just didn't make me wanna listen to it all day.

Gameplay: 9/10
This is where the game really shines even at the start of the game. It feels nostalgic but with a lot of quality of life improvements. It's not perfect, sure there can be more like being able to see what magic a rune will actually give you without socketing it in, but for the most part, battle, movement, and overall gameplay blends with almost everything. 

Story: 8/10
This may very well get higher in the future. I am only at 6 hours of the game but the story that I have seen and characters that I have interacted with makes it fun for me. I have yet to see the main character become more than a "Vaan" or a boyscout who loves doing things for other people.

Value for money: 10/10
Though some of my ratings above are not that high, the game is not really that expensive. In my area, it is not even around 60 USD. It's not a AAA game but the value that you get out of it really compensates for what you paid for and then some. 

Who is it for? 
This game is really not for everyone. This is a love letter to Suikoden fans and JRPG lovers of old. New players can play this, but not all of them would appreciate a gem like this. If we compare it with cars, this is a Mercedes S500, while the newer players would love to have a Tesla instead. It's an acquired taste for late millenials and genz but a love letter to those born in the 80's and 90's.

People looking for Suikoden will likely be very pleased.
People looking for Suikoden but better might be disappointed.
I'm kind of in the middle. I don't need every modern QoL expected these days, and most archaic annoyances are mitigated later with unlockable features later, but not all of them. This game really feels like they're leaning too much into the PSX archaic minimal QoL era too much and entirely on purpose. And after my 300th random battle where I just hit Auto and stare at the screen for 3 minutes I started to really wish for a fast forward button.
None of my irks are game-breaking to the point of unplayable, and the game is really borderline good, but there's just too much reliance on archaic anti-QoL design. I could go either way on a thumbs up or down but in its current state I think I'm going to go with thumb down for now.

Probably the biggest example that the devs are trying too hard to be old-school is that the Dash Boots, an item that increases your movement on the field, is not only easy to miss, but they take up a party member's accessory slot.  And the ability to reduce encounters takes up an important slot too. Why is there only ONE support slot!? Come on, stuff like this just isn't necessary and it shows they just don't care about convenience.

Also what's the deal with the fact that every character has rune affinities but the game just won't tell you what they are??

The nostalgia in this game is really something else. Feels like I've been playing a new Suikoden and I'm loving every second with it. I do hope this will have sequels in the future. For now, thank you and I'll enjoy the moment.

RIP Yoshitaka Murayama! Head writer for Eiyuden Chronicles and my favorite games of all time, Suikoden I and II.

Review Summary:

Eiyuden Chronicles is a must-play for fans of Suikoden I and II, and classic JRPGs will likely love this too. It has a nostalgic appeal and a mix of old and new mechanics. Despite many old mechanics and some roughness (that was common in that era of video games), and the modern updates like introducing new mechanics, 2d pixel art in a 3d world, the game overall retains the charm and challenges of 90s-era JRPGs that I grew up on.

Pros:
Richly nostalgic for fans of classic JRPGs, a real spiritual successor to Suikoden I and II.
Beautiful visuals blending pixel, 2D, and 3D art.
Great soundtrack.
Familiar yet updated turn-based combat.
Somewhat new spin on mechanics to the rune system.
Well-defined objectives with room for exploration.
Over 100 unique characters (even if some are unimportant or 1 dimentional)
Mini-games and other special mechanics! (Sadly no iron chef competition :'( ... )
Fully voiced storyline.

Cons:
Pacing and scene transitions can be awkward.
Reliance on old-style save points without autosave...
Difficulty can be inconsistent at times 
Camera controls aren't always available, but when they are they feel clunky.
Some poor voice acting (looking at you Lian) 
Inventory space feels too limiting
Tutorials leave you wanting more, while simultaneously feeling cluttered 
Outdated menu design and navigation

Mixed Feelings:
Battle mechanics are deliberately retro, which can be both charming and frustrating.
The combination of pixel art characters in a smoothly rendered 3D world creates a strange, albeit intriguing, visual contrast.
Translations and wording choices are generally good, but occasionally the phrasing feels more like conversational speech rather than well-crafted text.

If you're a fan of Suikoden I and II, or old school JRPGs in general (think story-driven adventures, turn-based combat, random encounters, deep world-building, and plenty of character development with a healthy dose of grinding), then this game is definitely for you. I backed this project on Kickstarter four years ago and have participated in both the closed and early access betas. Despite some mixed feelings about certain aspects, I've been swept up in the same nostalgic joy I felt playing Suikoden II as a kid.

In the first few hours, you might find yourself conflicted. There's an initial surge of nostalgia followed by frustration with dated mechanics like fixed save points, excessive button pressing if you opt out of auto-combat, and random battles.

Save points are a quintessential element of classic JRPGs, but you don't realize how inconvenient they are until you're in a rush and can't find one—echoing those childhood memories and feelings of desperation to save before you could leave the house all while your mother is screaming at from the front door for you to get of your game and get in the damn car because we're going to be late. (Love you and miss you mom!)   

Despite these annoyances, true fans of the genre will find these issues minor and enjoy the game's overall charm.

The combat system will feel familiar to Suikoden fans, offering traditional turn-based battles with the option for auto-fighting, which allows for different tactical approaches such as conserving items or MP. Boss battles and character-specific combos add variety and depth to the combat.

Interactions between characters are dynamic and can change depending on your party composition, adding layers of replayability and engagement. The main character, Nowa, could use more development, but the game provides interesting choices that affect conversations, enhancing the experience for those who enjoy multiple playthroughs.

The game's settings, from villages to cities, are beautifully rendered, bustling with NPCs, artwork, and wildlife, though they can sometimes feel sparse with few interactive elements. Eltisweiss, the first major city you encounter, illustrates this with its distant base location and one exit which feels like an eternity of running away after youv'e done it a few times.

Difficulty can be inconsistent, particularly when entering new areas with stronger enemies. Such encounters can be punishing, for example I had a random encounter with 6 heavy hitting enemies that punished my party and forced me to use many of my limited health potions to keep exploring to the next story point. This is especially difficult when resources like health potions and money are scarce at the begining of the game. 

Pacing generally varies, with periods of inactivity or awkward transitions where it should be a single cut scene but its split up by a simple walk a few steps, before the next one comes in.

I'm looking forward to seeing the rest of the story unfold, I remain optimistic despite some hitches with the Kickstarter campaign, which, while my experience was better than many, still had its downsides. Yeetee who facilitied many of the interactions with backers were terrible, though the Devs were usually great. The 'physical copy' is an incredible disappointment, a waste of money for everyone involved, and a waste of plastic for what is essentially art you've seen before in a cheap case with a cardboard cutout in the shape of a CD with a Steam key on it. Hopefully the other physical backer rewards will be great.

In summary, I can't stress it enough that for fans of Suikoden I and II, this game is a must-try. Despite some rough edges and questionable development choices, it's an invitation to step back into a simpler era of gaming. It's worth picking up to let the modern gaming world fade and revisit a time fondly remembered.

Ein wirklich tolles Spiel das lange Warten hat sich gelohnt! 
Das Spiel ist ein Liebesbrief an alte JRPG Tage, klar fehlen QoL Features die viele heut zu tage gewohnt sind aber für mich persönlich ist es als würde ich wieder ein JRPG auf der PS1 spielen und ich fühle pure Nostalgie. 
Ist es perfekt? Nein, es hat hier und da kleine Bug. Die Lokalisierung ist naja sagen wir auch auf dem Standard von vor 20 Jahren. Hier und da hat es durchaus auch kein perfektes Balancing. Aber wer gerne oldschool JRPG's mag und vor allem große Liebe für Suikoden empfindet der wird hier sicher viel Spaß haben! 
Bisher nicht durchgespielt werde mein Review eventuell später updaten.

- Gameplay [8/10]: Wirklich sehr unterhaltsames runden-basiertes Spiel, auch die Taktik Einlagen machen viel Spaß und selbst die Duelle aus Suikoden sind zurück. Aufbau der Basis macht auch viel Spaß! Allerdings hier und da Balancing-Probleme. 

- Grafik [8/10]: Sehr hübsche Pixel-Art Charaktere alles andere ist ein Mix aus 2,5D und Live2D alles in allem sehr hübsch.

- Sound [9/10]: Der Soundtrack ist wirklich schön. Sound-Effekte sind auch sehr gut gemacht!

- Story [8/10]: Eine schöne Geschichte mit einem runden Ende. Kein Meisterstück trägt aber das Spiel sehr gut. 

- Technik [7/10]: Der definitiv schwächste Punkt. Es hat LOD Probleme hier und da auch mal Texturen die erst rein-geladen werden wenn der Charakter nahe kommt. Es läuft dennoch flüssig. Hätte over all irgendwie mehr polishing gebrauchen können. 

- Overall [8/10]: Es war mir eine absolute Freude es durch zu spielen! Es ist ein tolles Spiel vor allem wenn man alte Zeiten des JRPG Genres vermisst. Ich bin mir sicher das ich auch mit dem Rest vom Spiel viel Spaß haben werde. Es ist sicher kein Meisterwerk und wird vermutlich auch eher Nische bleiben aber ich kann es jedem JRPG Fan empfehlen besonders allen älteren Fans des Genres!

其实我不推荐这款游戏，已经不适合现在这个时代了，但我又不愿意给差评。

Growing up with the old Suikoden games, I was really looking forward to this game. 
And from what I did play of this game, it truly felt like a successor to the old games. 
With the familiar battle system, rune system, recruiting new members etc. 
A lot of the old ingredients that made the Suikoden stand out from the many JRPG games are there, and i have enjoyed the game so far on that level. 

But my problem with the game as it is right now, is the English translation. 
I personally prefer Japanese voice and English subtitles over an English Dub in games, and normally that have been working just fine for me. But in this game the translations deviates too much from the original Japanese lines, to the point where it is too obvious to ignore. The vibes a character gives and what is written in their text-box is often a clear miss match. 
I understand that localization is more then just 1 to 1 translation, and they have to adapt. But here it is too far off from the original to be called a good, or even a decent localization. 

It's a shame they gave the job to translators that don't respect the original work, and I truly believe there is a good game in there. But it's hard to enjoy a story rich game, when the story is tainted by a bad translation.

Note: This is a mid game review.

Eiyuden Chronicle is a love letter towards Suikoden series, specifically Suikoden 2 looking at Nowa, the main character, in fact they both have the same creative director (Yoshitaka Murayama), however I think the game doesn't quite live up to its predecessor.

[h2] Story [/h2]
I'm not sure how much I have progressed into this so I will refrain from giving my opinion at this point but mostly it's about politics and kingdom invasion caused by some individuals pulling the strings from the shadow.

[h2] Characters [/h2]
As the title of the game says, it has over than a hundred playable characters that you can recruit over the course of the game which a good amount of them will join you automatically as you progress the story. A good number of them will join you without any requirements, they would just require you to find and talk to them but lots of them will require you to deliver some items or monster elimination after you talk to the characters.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
Eiyuden Chronicle has basically the same gameplay as its predecessor, turn based combat with up to 6 characters participating in the combat. There are some addition to the game that do add more flavor compared to the older games but it all boils down to the same thing. 
Most of the game, you'll be spending exploring and listening/reading the story, having played a lot of other JRPGs, Eiyuden feels weird for having the random encounter being scarce or rather, you could almost go in an area without any random encounter.  Luckily, the amount experience you get from the battle is quite generous and would give more to underleveled character so you don't need to grind as much when you're trying out new characters.

In addition to those the combat, you'll have several minigames which would be something like a beyblade but much simpler, card games which is basically like trump card, fishing game and kingdom building (not sure if we'll have some more)

[h2] Exploration [/h2]
The exploration is mostly linear and will give you a trivial rewards, occasionally you'll get a good accessories but that's about it, I don't think I've had a moment where I'd be thrilled getting rewards from a chest that gives me a good piece of equipment. There would be a lot of closed off path that will be unlocked gradually.
Some village/town is definitely a bit too big for its own good and the lack of fast travel can be a little bit annoying sometimes, especially in your own headquarters.

[h2] Personal Rant/Opinion [/h2]
[list]
[*] I've been playing the game on Jp dub and I speak and understand Japanese up to some degree, from that perspective, I'll have to say that, they did not do that well in the translation. A lot of the original meaning from the Japanese dub is lost in translation and replaced with some weird sentences that is out of characters.
[*] UI does what it needs which is fine but it feels extremely sluggish, you'll have to wait for the current animation to be done before going to the next section, it gets annoying having to wait 1 sec for every section you go through just to find which menu you need.
[*] I played the game on hard mode at the beginning and realized it wasn't worth because how dragged out the boss felt over time, I'm not sure what hard does to the game but a good amount of time I have already seen what the boss had and they just show no sign of dying.
[*] I wish they would spend a little bit more budget into the music and sound design considering that we'll be spending most of the time exploring, at least a good dynamic environment ambient sound would be nice.
[/list]

Overall, 15 hours into the game, I will have to say that the hype that I have after waiting since the kickstarter have died down a lot, I don't think it's that much better than the original, I'm not even sure if it's better than Suikoden 2, if you're unsure wherether to buy it or not, either wait for sale or wait a little bit more for Suikoden 1 and 2 remaster.

Amazing game that modernizes, but still captures, the old school charm of Suikoden—from recruiting characters, to fighting battles, to building your castle town.  The characters are unique and likable; the voice acting and soundtrack are both amazing; and the combat is fun.  Although there are random encounters, they're pretty rare, so you never have that frustrating experience where you fight, walk 10 steps, fight, repeat ad nauseum.  If anything, I wish there were more battles (this may be related to a but though) and that it were possible to speed them up slightly.  “Auto” battle helps a lot with this, particularly for easier random encounters.

My only complaints so far are that magic is very weak for all characters and that there’s a lot of backtracking.  I’d also recommend reading a spoiler-free recruitment guide, as in true Suikoden fashion, it’s not always clear how to recruit characters or where to locate them.

科乐美当年放走了合金装备系列的小岛秀夫，放走了恶魔城系列的五十岚孝司，放走了幻想水浒传系列的村山吉隆等许多有才华的制作人，如今他们都在Steam上通过众筹的方式走出了属于自己的新道路，遗憾的是村山吉隆今年2月已经去世了，所以即便这部百英雄传很可能是绝唱，虽然制作组还说会继续开发续作。(;´Д｀)至于幻想水浒传感觉更不用等了，因为上一作已经是2013年的游戏了。

本作是村山吉隆通过众筹而开发的第二个游戏，第一个《百英雄传：崛起》应该是磨合团队的试手之作，目前游玩体验良好，在如今这个浮躁的游戏圈子里算是品质上乘的JRPG了。自从Falcom进入3D建模时代开始转为以DLC卖服装为主后基本就对轨迹系列越来越失望了（虽然南梦宫的传说系列也是，但人家至少价格便宜打折力度大）。而SE则是一边各种复刻重置着自家的传家宝游戏，一边把游戏定价为“奢侈品”来卖。虽然ATLUS近年看似逐步加速在往PC平台拓展，但目前业务重心其实还是在主机平台，不过暗喻幻想还是未来可期的，只是希望别再去搞什么砸自家口碑的手游。当然JRPG更不可能指望靠光荣的炼金系列和地雷社的海王星系列来发扬光大。至于国产RPG更是前途未卜。

由于游戏刚解锁，开的又是困难模式，之前没玩过试玩版，所以剧情推进的比较慢，还不好评价后面剧情怎么样，但目前游玩下来剧情以外的其它方面都还是很满意的，回想起小时候在NDS上玩幻想水浒传的时光了（虽然没通关）。如果要让咱选的话，其实比起八方旅人咱更喜欢百英雄传这种，可能是因为八方旅人没有给主角们起名字的缘故，所以代入感和游玩后的留下的游戏回忆没有那么深刻，当然也不能说百英雄传通关后就一定能给咱留下深刻的回忆，给咱留下深刻回忆的JRPG恐怕只有小时候玩过很多遍的ED6三部曲了。

咱还是很推荐这部百英雄传的，不仅对游戏系统和世界观设定，对美术风格，对配音配乐都非常满意。本作也算是幻想水浒传与百英雄传系列制作人去世前给喜欢JRPG的玩家们留下的绝唱了。
如果对JRPG苦手，不希望花时间刷刷刷的话，建议开普通难度就行，游戏本身难度已经很低了，普通难度基本只要专注跟剧情任务就行，路上遭遇的战斗足够让玩家在BOSS战时平稳应对了。
虽然是遇敌是暗雷，但是遇敌间隙时间比较大，可以明显感觉到是有意为之的，想让注重剧情的玩家能专注于剧情而不是频繁应对遇敌战斗。
另外游戏里还可以设置通货膨胀功能，由于刚玩没多久只在第一个村子里看到了类似交易品之类的道具，不知道是不是后面应该能通过在城镇间倒卖各种商品赚钱。
最后的最后，不建议用修改器游玩，如果不想多花时间就选普通难度。ːChiaki_DGRː

A good RPG. Unfortunately not a great one. It feels a bit amateur around the edges and lacking some polish in areas. It's more a vision than an actual game. Menus are a pain to go through and unresponsive, combats have a weird delay at the end of the end screen to pop for no good reason, there's a bunch of very questionable design decisions like an equippable accessory to run faster that you feel forced to always have equipped otherwise you waste time on slowly running (the maps are really big compared to most other RPGs so you do want to run fast), the MP vs SP balance feels totally off and casting spells overall feels like a bad idea in almost every situation imaginable.

I'm having fun so far with it, and I will edit my review if my view on the game changes drastically but it's a bit unfortunate to see seniors of the industries making such an aggressively average RPG. Artistically it's very inspired: the visual, sounds and lore is quite solid (though audio mixing in english is pretty bad). But then the gameplay feels like it wasn't thought out through at all.

As for the alleged bad localisation honestly nerds you really need to go out and touch grass. The localisation isn't remotely bad. Some lines in some instances feel a bit weird: Mio mentionning to Nowa that the golem/boss they just defeated might not be a "him" is often mentioned and while I did found it very weirdly placed because Mio is up to this point very quiet and never teases anyone I didn't minded it too much. In some sense I feel that the english localisation is very "human" if that makes sense. Characters don't feel as much as archetypes as they often do, sometimes they say some weird or cringey stuff but it feels more because the characters are like that rather than the script being cringe. Lian got me annoyed at first but the more you see her interacting with different characters the more she gets charming in the end.
Anyway, go touch grass, for real.

Beautiful game. Hits on all the right nostalgia points for those bygone PS1 RPGs while modernizing the parts that need it. This was arguably my most anticipated game of all time as a longtime fan of the Suikoden series, and it has not disappointed in the slightest. Complaints about the "cringy" English localization are hilariously overblown since it's the only thing even remotely contentious about the game, so people who are incapable of having fun and want to gripe about everything latched onto it like a vice grip and refused to let go, because, surprise surprise, the game is actually good and delivered on what was promised by the original Kickstarter which is more than I can say about certain other crowdfunded games.

If you like PS1 style RPGs in the slightest, you'll like this game. If you're a fan of Suikoden, you'll love this game. That's all there is to it.

Основные плюсы:
- Приятный визуал как персонажей, так и графики
- Интересный, эпичный, но все же приземленный "средневековый" сюжет (без "избранных богами" и "великого зла")
- Яркие, запоминающиеся персонажи
- Есть множество вариантов билдостроения вашей боевой группы
- Неплохая реализация системы развития вашей базы
- Интересная боевка, которая не наскучила за все время игры. Бои с боссами хорошо продуманы и требуют своего подхода

Минусы тоже есть:
- Мини-игры: карточные бои, катание волчка, гонки... О боже, кто додумался их ввести в таком количестве?! За ними еще и контент часто спрятан, но их реализация посредственная. Благо, что они хотя бы опциональные
- Не совсем продуманная система битв армий - в ней маловато стратегии, затянуты анимации ходов, скучно. Только одна битва за всю игру на меня произвела впечатление неожиданными моментами, на остальных - засыпал.
- Есть баги, хотя и не критичные, но пару раз перезагрузиться пришлось.
- Странная реализация случайных встреч. Мне лично пришлось залочить FPS на 60 кадрах в игре и на панели NVIDEA, чтобы они перестали происходить каждые 10 секунд)) Дальше уже находятся внутриигровые способы снижения\повышения частоты встреч.

Субъективно - игра берет количеством доступных героев, а не их качеством. Их действительно 120 штук. Многие из них "прописываются" на вашей базе и в боях не участвуют. Тем не менее глубокой проработки истории\бэкграунда\характера этих героев ждать не стоит, хотя стоит отметить их яркие образы и разнообразие. Есть тут и суровые воины, и коварные маги, и JoJo-персонажи, и девочки-волшебницы, и даже ручные драконы!

While it's got some unpolished edges as to be expected of a kickstarted game this big, it still really captures that beautiful spirit of Suikoden and other PS1 JRPGs of that era. The sprite work is gorgeous and you can really tell a lot of love and passion went into this game. My only real crticisms are:

-The main unpolished issue of the game is the constant loading screens, something most JRPGs don't really suffer from nowadays (heck suikoden 2 definitely didn't have them for their battles so the fact this game does is surprising) the loading is fast enough to be an almost non issue tho (like half a second to a second at most), it's just surprising that it's there at all.
-The localization quality isn't quite the best as I expect nowadays from games, mainly in side stuff/throwaway lines, but it's not bad either cus other scenes will be super well written and performed, just very hit and miss unfortunately. 
-English VA can be wildly hit or miss as well, my guess is some weren't given great direction or context for their lines.
-The difficulty is very very easy, even on Hard mode. This was true of the first two suikoden games as well though so it's not that big an issue, and this game's hard mode is definitely harder than the majority of Suikoden 2, and despite that difficulty Suikoden 2 is still a JRPG masterpiece, so I see no reason why this can't be the same c:


EDIT!!!! 

So turns out the difficulty really does kick up right around when you get to the great forest, hard mode's actually been kicking my ass now in boss fights, really make sure to stock up on healing items, especially AOE healing items or you may be forced to turn the difficulty down

Regardless of what I have as little criticisms though, I still adore this game so far, I'm enjoying it a lot and I'm really glad this game I kickstarted so many years ago turned out as good as it did, I've missed Suikoden, I hope it's something Yoshitaka Murayama can be proud of, may he rest in peace.

Unfaithful localization full of cringey words/sayings, weird unfunny jokes and to make it worse, changing a character from the original work to the point it's basically a different person. I supported this game for the japanese developers vision, not a rogue localizer's reinterpretation of it.

I'm an European Player who always chose english in every game I played, I never had any problems understanding these same games, this includes more recently, Baldurs Gate 3, which is heavy with dialogue and story.

Yet with EC, even the first minutes present terminologies specific to the American Culture and does a poor job, in fact, detracts player connection to the game's dialogue and story.

Chub - apparently, this refers to a political side in America, and I ask, is english only meant for Americans? Why would this word be appropriate in the EC world in any context? 

"Rub a dub dont be a flub" - is apparently a rick and morty joke, why would anyone assume non-american but fluent english speakers would understand, relate or connect with this sort of joke?


Incidences like this keep happening in the game and makes the entire gameplay experience bad. 

I tried giving it another try after the closed beta - but the way they changed the Lian character, that appears to have a significant portion of the script is just too much - I am aware the character is supposed to be a vocal, silly comc relief - but the way the EN localization portrays her is not the same as how the author did,

Shame on you all that support this sort of behavior and devalue the original work - this is what allows this sort of shenanigans to persist in every other game.

Lo zainetto: Sicuramente all'inizio avere solo 30 di spazio può risultare un problema se non ci si organizza bene .Calcolate che sarà possibile depositare oggetti solo a castello ottenuto se non erro .Più avanti avrete un compagno che mettendolo nello slot del supporto , aumenterà il vostro zaino .Fino a quel momento state attenti e usate il magazzino del castello per depositare oggetti .

Meu JRPG favorito da vida: Suikoden II

Uma breve história: nos meus 13 anos, fui na casa do meu amigo da escola [Rafael Cascaes] para fazermos trabalho, e numa caixa e sapatos, haviam inúmeros CDs  de Playstation 1 onde ele falou que poderia escolher 1 deles e levar emprestado. Dentre eles, haviam um que a capa me encantou: Suikoden II. Li aquele CD pirata e percebi ser um JRPG e na hora o avisei e coloquei na mochila. Ele estranhou e disse que achou esse bem chato. O trabalho termina e chego em casa.

Adiciono aquele jogo no PS1 que meu primo havia emprestado e foi amor à primeira vista! São 108 personagens recrutáveis e lembro de ter pego uns 94, sem detonado, cheat e entender inglês! Levei dias com esse jogo e mantinha um dicionário Inglês-Português ao lado para ir traduzindo cada diálogo desse jogo enorme. Este é um dos jogos que me ajudou a aprender o pouco inglês que sei. Juntou o amor pelos games com o tempo livre de adolescente vagabundo, rs

Enfim, Cascaes pediu de volta, pois era do irmão dele. Antes, pedi à Letícia [uma oura amiga] para gravar ele para mim numa cópia. Gastei uma fortuna para comprar um CD-RW e ainda tenho este CD que deve ter uns bons 20 anos. Joguei tanto Suikoden II com ele... passava desse jogo religiosamente todos os anos. 

Sabe o melhor, é ir amadurecendo e ir jogando nesses tempos, pois passei a entender mais à história, às intrigas políticas, o valor da amizade, trabalho em conjunto... Enfim, amo este jogo.

Espere o Hundred Heroes há 4 anos, desde quando vi o Kickstarter recém lançado lá em 2020. Na época, não pude contribuir e isso foi dolorido, mas foi necessário usar melhor o dinheiro que recebia/guardava.

Agora falando do jogo em si, como me remeteu aos meus tempos de menino travesso. Sei lá, emociona algo te deslocar para um período da sua vida de forma tão gratificante. Saber que à equipe dos Suikoden's originais se juntaram para criar algo assim é bonito. Sentar aqui, com o controle nas mãos e aproveitar esta retomada dos JRPGS, sendo ainda um "sucessor espiritual" do seu jogo favorito... é maravilhoso demais!

Sinto aqui um tipo remake/reboot feito com carinho e direcionado aos fãs de outrora com os possíveis novos.

Agora, por favor, deixe-me retomar à aventura.

R.I.P. Yoshitaka Murayama [infelizmente, morreu antes do lançamento]

I'm still relatively early in the game, but I'm enjoying it a lot. I read that the creators intended it to be a callback to older JRPGs and intentionally omitted some features that might be in a modern JRPG. I think because of that, the game may not be for everyone, but as someone who grew up playing PS1-era JRPGs, it's bringing back a lot of nostalgia for Suikoden I and Suikoden II. There are [i]some[/i] quality-of-life improvements over the Suikoden games, but they're minimal. For me, that's fine, and I'm just happy to play another game that feels like Suikoden.  

[b]Gameplay[/b]
The combat is fun and can be challenging (I'm playing on Hard difficulty), but as with most JRPGs, you're going to auto-battle for a lot of your standard combat eventually. Minigames so far are a mixed-bag. I've enjoyed some (like the card game) a lot, while others (the beyblade/spinning top game) aren't for me. The headquarters/base-building aspect is interesting and has evolved from what was in the Suikoden series. It now requires resources to build up your HQ (as well as recruitment) and you can choose which buildings/improvements you want to build first. The duels are very similar to Suikoden I & II, though I've only done one so far. Tactical/War battles are interesting and seem new, but I can't remember if they used a system like this in one of the later Suikoden games. Again, I've only done one so far but it seemed like with more characters in my army it could have a lot of interesting complexity. 

[b]Story/Localization[/b]
As for the negative reviews that are complaining about the English localisation, in my opinion they're blowing things way out of proportion. The nuances in Japanese culture and formality of the language don't always translate to a western audience, so direct translations are very often harder to understand, dialogue becomes formal and boring, and characterisation is negatively impacted. English localisation almost always differs mildly (as it does in Eiyuden) from Japanese because of this. 

In the few cases I've seen where the localisation team took strong liberties with dialogue, I think they ended up with more interesting characterisations when I've compared to what was originally said in Japanese. The dialogue is very silly and on the nose early in the game, as characters are being introduced and the dialogue hits you with a very strong impression of who they are. However, as the game progresses, the characters and plot become more nuanced and complex. However, you'll note that most of the negative reviews complaining about localisation have a playtime of around 10-12 hours--before the nuance starts to show itself. I don't think these reviewers really intended to give the game a chance, and I think many of them just wanted a platform for expressing their own personal grievances, but that's just my opinion.

If the localisation is the only thing holding you back from playing, my advice is to give the game a chance and make your own decision, because the examples being circulated are exaggerated at best and pedantic at worst. 

[b]Audio[/b]
The music in the game includes some great tracks and the battle theme in particular is very good. Town themes are calming and fit the theme of the town, and some of them feel very reminiscent of classic Suikoden themes.

The voice acting is surprisingly good. Again, in the early game it does feel a bit more jarring as you meet characters but they balance out eventually. I have been impressed by how the voice acting for story-related scenes often feels like the actors are speaking and replying to each other (rather than reading lines in isolation, which often leads to strange emphasis and mixed conversation tones). There are a few minor issues here and there, but nothing that has ruined a scene entirely for me. 

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Those who enjoyed "old school" Playstation-era JRPGs, and haven't been too spoiled by modern conveniences will probably enjoy Eiyuden Chronicles: Hundred Heroes. Those, like me, who fell in love with Suikoden as a teenager and have missed its unique style of gameplay will probably love this game. It isn't perfect, and I hope that the developers add in just a few QoL improvements with patches, but it's a respectable entry and follow-up to the Suikoden series, and I truly hope the developers continue to make more games like it.

First off, thank you and rest in peace, Yoshitaka Murayama. Your dedication towards continuing the Suikoden legacy, if only in spirit, is greatly appreciated and I'm saddened at the thought that you don't get to see people enjoy it.

To give some background behind my review, I am a longtime Suikoden fan that played through the original series and even Tierkreis. I have long been a vocal supporter of the series, for what it has accomplished and what important lessons I have taken from the series. It has always been near and dear to my heart, and it is clear that Eiyuden hoped to remind me of that.

For fans of the Suikoden series, this game will bring about a sense of nostalgic familiarity, particularly with regards to Suikoden 1 and 2. In many ways, this is exactly what I wanted, a brand new Suikoden experience to revel in all over again. It is both very new and very familiar at the same time.

I am loving building a base all over again, filling it with a wide variety of interesting and unique characters. The music by Motoi Sakuraba and Michiko Naruke are absolutely fantastic, and while I had to adjust a little since I'm not used to hearing their styles in an experience like Suikoden, they have quickly grown to feel truly natural and wonderful to listen to. The games' aesthetic is impeccable, and the 2D pixel art is beautiful especially when overlaid onto the 3D environments. This couldn't be truer than during the duel segments, which are eye-poppingly gorgeous.

The game is not perfect, however, and while I have greatly enjoyed my time playing it, its flaws were hard to ignore. I take no umbrage with the localization specifically (it's pretty standard JRPG dialogue, as far as I'm concerned), and I feel like the general complaints regarding it are overblown and highly dramatic. There are errors, to be sure, but to suggest that alone can ruin the game is sheer hyperbole. My bigger concern is less the localization and more the actual game's story. While enjoyable, it carries a much more light-hearted and optimistic tone than the Suikoden series, and I feel that it loses a drastic amount of emotional tension and weight as a result. The Suikoden games were often always bittersweet and had left me with serious considerations about war's impacts on humanity. This game had no such impact on me, and I'm saddened by that. There were no real stakes in this war at any point in the game, and I just felt like it was hard to get behind the characters motivations.

The game also had a plethora of questionable design choices that led to less efficient gameplay than I'd expected from the Suikoden titles. They weren't gamebreakers for me, but they did take some teeth grinding until I'd gotten used to them as quirks of the game.

Aside from all that, I did genuinely really enjoy playing the game. While it wasn't quite the game I wanted it to be, it did a great job of nailing a lot of the core Suikoden experience and was a lot of fun if not particularly impactful. I don't regret backing it, and I sincerely hope the devs continue to give it some TLC over the next while to soften some of those rough edges.

本来以为支援后面三个位置可以放吃经验的角色，结果只能放任务必要角色，有点无语。
跑图时候升级不回复状态，你要不要看看队里小脆皮被敌人摸一下掉30~40多血，奶妈一碰就残血，两下就要倒。
另外吐槽一句澪的面板，魔法攻击比物理攻击高砍人一刀30多被打一下掉30多血，评价是不如勇哥能扛能打（勇哥也就是不能防御一些aoe之类的攻击，但防反近战攻击还是可以的）。
还有多格角色的面板也有问题，小孩伤害不如两个人各砍一刀……emm，对于多格角色的面板数值设计还是太保守了啊。
连携方面有搞怪元素保留了一部分情怀，但数值上很感人，莲的连携技双方消耗2sp伤害没莲一个3sp的技能伤害高。
符文方面很鸡肋，虽然看似可以自由搭配，但也就是给你加了几个可以放的技能（类似轨迹手机嵌石头那样的操作），我目前习惯2水1风确保自己前排和后排各有一个回复角色，剩下的看情况来配。
补充：树人试炼场真的是粪关，暗雷来回跑很好玩是吧？限制物品携带量还没法关内补状态，逼着你用传送石回去睡觉，笑死。

The game delivers on exactly what it promised at conception: a spiritual successor to the Suikoden series, very much in the style of a modernized Suikoden I and II, and everything that implies. If you liked those games, you'll like this one. They really succeeded in capturing the way you remember those games in your head, through the nostalgia-lens (pun intended!).

It adheres pretty hard to the classic JRPG style, arguably to a fault sometimes, but succeeds at giving me the feelings I had when playing these games 20+ years ago. The characters are fun, the story is good (if possibly a bit standard), the voice-acting in both English and Japanese is well-done, and the game-play and combat are both a lot of fun.

There are some descriptions that are a bit vague and could stand to go into more detail, and there's a few bugs at release that need to be fixed, but nothing gamebreaking that can't be avoided or worked around for now, and I've seen the bugs acknowledged and that they're working on a fix, so I have faith they'll be rectified soon.

You might see people complaining about the localization (and which seems to be hyper-focused on one specific line from Mio), but personally I feel it was well-done. The localization feels natural and captures the feeling of the game, presenting it how it would likely have been written had it been done in English by a native speaker in the first place while still getting across all of the information and characterization, which I feel should be the goal. The particular offending line is, in my opinion, at worst a joke that didn't land and not the start of an overall theme of "Did you just assume my gender!?" like people seem to be implying. The game isn't politicized, it just deals with it's own internal narrative political struggles.

All in all, I'm so glad I backed this 4 years ago, they delivered everything they promised and everything I wanted, and I'm very happy with it!

ストーリークリアまでプレイしたのでレビュー。
このゲームは『幻想水滸伝』という名作RPGの開発スタッフが携わって開発しているPRGです。
そのため、幻想水滸伝を踏襲したシステムが多く、幻想水滸伝が好きだった方はとても懐かしい気持ちで遊ぶことができると思います。
キャラクターやシナリオも同様で、プレイしていると様々な箇所で「こいつ〇〇に似てるな」や「これ幻想水滸伝であったシーンだな」と感じました。

[h3]多彩なキャラクターがいて楽しめる[/h3]
このゲームは百英雄伝の名の通りキャラクター(仲間)が非常にたくさんいるのでパーティ編成をするときの選択肢が非常に多く、何度でも楽しめると思います。
ただし、その分、仲間集めは大変です。
ストーリーを進めることで仲間になるキャラクターもいれば、いろんな都市を訪れて特定の条件を満たさないと仲間にならないキャラクターもいます。
(アイテムを渡す、戦闘で勝利する、ミニゲームに勝利する、などなど)

[h3]ミニゲームなどやりこみ要素が多い[/h3]
百英雄伝には仲間集め以外にも本拠地拡張やミニゲームといったやりこみ要素があります。
ミニゲームは種類が豊富で、ミニゲームに熱中しすぎてメインストーリーが進まないこともあるかもしれません。
こうしたやりこみ要素が多く、仲間集めやミニゲームのすべてを遊び尽くそうと思ったら100時間は遊べると思います。

[h3]不便に感じた個所[/h3]
・戦争イベントというシステムがあるのですが、各部隊が戦闘をするシーンが長く、戦闘中はプレイヤーは基本的に見てるだけなので手持ち無沙汰になりがちでした。
・一騎打ちイベントでは、幻想水滸伝では「攻撃、防御、必殺」という３すくみの要素があって敵の発言をもとに敵の行動をよみながら裏をかく心理戦があり、３すくみを活用した遊びでしたが、このゲームの一騎打ちイベントは３すくみになっておらず、テンションゲージを貯めて仕掛けるだけになっているのであまり楽しめなかったです。
・アイテムが宝箱からドロップするのですが、ルーンという強化アイテムがお店にもっていかなければ使えないため、ダンジョンでたくさんドロップすると所持品の枠を圧迫してしまい、所持品を捨てなければならなくなりがちです。
・所持品がいっぱいの状態で宝箱を開けようとした場合、何が入っているのか確認できないので所持品を捨てる必要があり、宝箱を開けたときに不要なアイテムだったとき所持品捨てなきゃよかったなと思うことがあります。
・MP回復のアイテムがお店で購入できないため、魔法が使いづらく感じました。

[h3]不具合について[/h3]
一部進行不能となってしまうバグがあるようです。
なので１つのセーブスロットに上書きするよりも、小まめに分けてセーブしておく必要があります。
なお、ロードが遅いという意見が発売前にプレイヤーから出ていたようですが、PC版ではロードはとても早く、特に不自由なく遊ぶことができていました。

[h3]さいごに[/h3]
幻想水滸伝が好きだった方には懐かしさも相まって楽しめるゲームになっていると思います。
幻想水滸伝を未プレイの方はもしかすると古臭かったり、遊びづらいゲームに感じるかもしれません。
